However, the third-party company interacted with the data subjects of the data controller under its own logo and in the English language, making it confusing for the data subjects to figure out who exactly was responsible for the data processing. This means that the original data controller breached the principle of transparency as per Art. 12 GDPR, and failed to fulfill its obligations to provide information as per Art. 15 GDPR. Moreover, the data protection authority discovered that no written contract had been established between the data controller and the third-party company, leading up to a breach of Art. 28 (9) GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company unlawfully processed personal data of data subjects, including health data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company failed to take the proper technical and organizational measures to ensure the accuracy of personal data transmitted over the phone regarding the concluding of contracts. This means that specific contracts were concluded over telephone on behalf of other data subjects.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Various documents related to the personal data of a public tender were published on a website.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company had not cooperated in full with the data protection authority.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The community unlawfully published on its website personal data of various data subjects, including places of birth, names, birth dates, places of residence, and more.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The company failed to comply with a data subject’s request to access information in a given time period.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: Entrepreneur running a non-public nursery and pre-school
allItems.type: Failure to comply with Data Processing Authority's orders
allItems.summary: The person was fined for not answering repeated requests for supplementary information from the data protection authority, regarding a data breach.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The employer did not update the private address of an employee and delete the old address.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The community illegally published personal data on the community’s official website.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. L34-5 CPCE
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company sent advertising emails to various data subjects without being able to provide evidence of prior consent.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company unlawfully used a video surveillance system to monitor a residential community, which was not in compliance with the regulations of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Estonia
allItems.controller: Apotheka e-apteek, Azeta.ee e-apteek, Südameapteegi e-apteek
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Estonian DPA fined the three pharmacies EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA fined Gaypa s.r.l. with EUR 20,000 because the data controller had kept the email address of a former employee active. The company had constant access to the data subject’s inbox, even though their contractual relationships had been concluded. The data subject wasn’t informed of this continued use of his/her email account, or about the continued storage of his/her incoming and outgoing emails on the servers of the company, or about the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA fined the company for having installed a video surveillance system that recorded three data subjects during their time at work. In this sense, the data subjects had not been properly informed about the processing of their personal data as part of the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data subject had subscribed to the newsletter of the data controller. However, after changing his/her email address, the data subject continued to receive the newsletter on the old email address. Upon asking the data controller to update the email address, the data controller claimed that it had done that. Still, the data subject continued to receive the newsletter on the old email address.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The municipality had been unlawfully processing the personal data of employees and users of TuPassi booking system used to manage appointments and various other services since 2015. The Italian DPA found out that the data controller had infringed upon several of the GDPA regulations related to the processing of personal data of employees and customers that had made appointments using the TuPassi system. Moreover, the municipality had not informed the data subjects of the data processing, and it also did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to safeguard the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: This company is the provider of the TuPassi booking system, which had been used by the Rome Municipality since 2015 to book appointments on the website of the data controller (www.tupassi.it) or through the app. Miropass S.r.l. collects personal data of the users for this reason, though the Italian DPA found out that the company had no legal basis to process personal data (health data regarding appointments at healthcare facilities), thus violating the principle of storage limitation.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f), (2) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 (1), (5) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The mobile operator assigned a data subject’s phone number to a third party, thus causing the data subject to lose control of his/her phone number. Moreover, the SIM card of the data subject has also been deactivated, leading up to unauthorized access from the third party to personal data of the data subject, including call history, WhatsApp, Facebook, PayPal accounts related to the number. The data breach took place between September 16 and September 19, 2019.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The phone company had assigned five telephone lines with five numbers to the data subject. One of the numbers associated with the contract was used by the data subject’s son. When he did not want to use the phone number anymore, he contacted the company only to be told that the mobile data had been cancelled due to the number no longer being in his possession. Apparently, an unauthorized third party had pretended to be the data subject only to transfer the number to another third party, and the data controller did not request any authorization for this. The two third parties then pretended to lose the SIM card, only to demand and actually receive a replacement SIM card from the data controller. Following this, the son’s SIM card was blocked.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA fined the company EUR 150,000 and its subcontractor EUR 75,000 for not taking the adequate countermeasures against stuffing attacks on its official website. Between June 2018 and January 2020, the French DPA (CNIL) received numerous notifications of personal data breaches on a website where millions of customers did regular shopping. The CNIL then went on to investigate the company and the subcontractor managing the website. It discovered that the official website of the company had received substantial credential stuffing attacks. This attack implies the usage of unencrypted personal identifiers or passwords on the internet to access the accounts of data subjects on the official website of the company (using logging bots). Upon successfully being authorized on the website, the third parties would gain access to various information. The CNIL discovered that the attackers were able to gain access to surnames, first names, dates of birth, email addresses, loyalty card numbers and balance, as well as pertinent information regarding the orders they’d placed. The French DPA noted that both the company and its subcontractor failed to meet their obligations to maintain the continued security of the customers’ personal data as per Art. 32 GDPR. In an attempt to solve this issue, the two companies ineffectively started building a tool to fight against the logging bots, and undertaking that took an entire year. They ignored any other immediate countermeasures that could have had a faster impact on the prevention and/or mitigation of further attacks, as well as the negative influence these attacks would have on the customers. Due to this, more than 40,000 website customers had their personal data accessed by unauthorized third parties between March 2018 and February 2019.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA fined the company EUR 150,000 and its subcontractor EUR 75,000 for not taking the adequate countermeasures against stuffing attacks on its official website. Between June 2018 and January 2020, the French DPA (CNIL) received numerous notifications of personal data breaches on a website where millions of customers did regular shopping. The CNIL then went on to investigate the company and the subcontractor managing the website. It discovered that the official website of the company had received substantial credential stuffing attacks. This attack implies the usage of unencrypted personal identifiers or passwords on the internet to access the accounts of data subjects on the official website of the company (using logging bots). Upon successfully being authorized on the website, the third parties would gain access to various information. The CNIL discovered that the attackers were able to gain access to surnames, first names, dates of birth, email addresses, loyalty card numbers and balance, as well as pertinent information regarding the orders they’d placed. The French DPA noted that both the company and its subcontractor failed to meet their obligations to maintain the continued security of the customers’ personal data as per Art. 32 GDPR. In an attempt to solve this issue, the two companies ineffectively started building a tool to fight against the logging bots, and undertaking that took an entire year. They ignored any other immediate countermeasures that could have had a faster impact on the prevention and/or mitigation of further attacks, as well as the negative influence these attacks would have on the customers. Due to this, more than 40,000 website customers had their personal data accessed by unauthorized third parties between March 2018 and February 2019.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA fiend the company, an advertising agency, EUR 50,000, for sending soon-to-be mothers gift boxes with product samples, vouchers, and information about pregnancy and birth. However, the items in the box would be sent by third parties, to whom the company offered the personal data of the data subjects. The company would ask for the consent of all data subjects regarding the transfer of the personal data to third parties for marketing purposes. However, the Belgian DPA was notified that the company ignored the revoking of a data subject’s consent, and continued to use her personal information for the purpose of advertising calls from third parties.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company was fined because it failed to cooperate with the Polish Data Protection Authority. The company failed to provide data reguested by the UODO.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: One data controller who was using the services of the security company reported to the DPA a breach a personal data. Apparently, an employee of the company had recorded the video surveillance footage with a phone only to share it with other third parties and make it available on social media and the media. The Data Protection Authority discovered that the breach occurred due to a lack of organizational and technical measures regarding personal data security that extended two and a half years in the past. Moreover, the company had failed to foresee any such breaches of security, while also foregoing to implement any security measures after the incident to prevent or minimize the risk of future breaches from occurring. As a result, a data subject was the target of insults and social ridicule following the exposure of the recordings on social media, and the security company did nothing to remove it. While the fine is unknown as of now, the DPA listed out the aggravating factors it would take into consideration when applying the fine – (i) the data processor failed to fulfill its obligations to inform the data controller of the breach as per Art. 33 (2) GDPR, (ii) the area of expertise of the company is technical protection, including video surveillance. The DPA also notes that the company in question is a leading company in this domain in Croatia, and as such should hold relevant opinions, advice, and also propose solutions regarding the use of video surveillance systems, setting an example through its conduct.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company was fined EUR 40,000 by the Cypriot DPA for using an automated system and tool assessment based on the Brad-Factor to monitor, manage, and control the absence of employees because of sickness. The tool assessment was unlawful since the Cypriot law didn’t cover it. Moreover, the company did not offer the data subjects the liberty to offer their consent to the data processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hellenic Bank was fined with EUR 25,000 for forgetting to move out a safe containing old documents of existing customers when closing down one of its branches in Nicosia, in 2015. The safe had been installed in a wall, prompting the employees to forget about it. The bank was notified about this incident in 2019, when the new tenant of the building found the safe and notified the bank. In turn, the Hellenic Bank reported this data breach to the Cypriot DPA who concluded that the bank had breached Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, and Art. 33 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 58 (1) e) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subject of the Cypriot Real Estate Registration Authority demanded access to his personal data from the data controller, thus attempting to exercise his right under Art. 15 GDPR. However, the data controller failed to respond to his query, which prompted the data subject to notify the DPA. Following a investigation by the DPA, the data controller also failed to respond to the multiple requests of the DPA to offer comments on this allegation of the data subject.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The real estate company KEPIDES submitted a list containing the names of the properties under its management to a parliamentary committee. However, the company did not anonymize the names of the data subjects, resulting in a data breach.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: On the 12th of February 2021, the Aarhus District Court decided to fine IDdesign with EUR 13,450, disagreeing with the initially proposed fine of EUR 200,850. The Court concluded that the fine amount should instead the calculated based on the company’s subjective turnover instead of the entire group. Moreover, mitigating circumstances according to Art. 83 (2) GDPR have also been accounted for. The company hadn’t previously breached the GDPR, and the data breach only concerned general personal data, resulting in no damage suffered by the data subjects. The data breach also had a negligent nature, which the Court also took into account.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The private individual unlawfully took pictures of vehicles and, in some cases, of their drives, emailing the photos to the city of Magedburg without encrypting them, allegedly as a report of violations of the Road Traffic Regulations.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The soccer club was fined with EUR 300,000 for a negligent breach of data protection accountability. Despite this, the data controller provided ample assistance to the DPA’s investigation and took the initiative to clarify the situation.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The College Dublin had a total of seven personal data breaches when unauthorized third-party entities accessed the University’s e-mail accounts, using the login credentials posted online. Apparently, the data controller did not take appropriate security and organizational measures to protect data security when processing personal data via the email service. Moreover, the data controller stored specific personal data in an email account that made it possible to identify the data subjects for longer than it was necessary. Finally, the University College Dublin failed to notify the DPC of a personal data breach timely.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 37 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The data controller had published a document containing personal data belonging to a council member. The document also contained data pertaining to a complaint procedure field against the council member by the mayor. Anyone could download the document freely without any authentical needed. Moreover, the municipality did not appoint a data protection officer, and did not notify the DPA of any such appointment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The municipality had published on its website two documents containing data about a legal settlement of a data subject. Not only were the documents freely accessible but they could also be downloaded at any time. The personal data included about the data subject were the first and last name, confirmation of the payment of legal costs, the IBAN code of the data subject’s checking account, the amount paid in favor of the data subject, and information about the lawsuit.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Ordine degli Assistenti Sociali della Regione Lazio
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: When a data subject filed a request to the data controller demanding information about the data being processed about him and his daughters, the company gave no response to the request for information. A couple of months later, the data subject filed a complaint to the DPA, and eventually, his request for information was complied, though the company offered no explanation about the delay or the lack of an initial response.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: Regione Lazio failed to designate the company entrusted with the management of its reservations for healthcare services in 1999, as a data processor. Apparently, the company did not enter a contract with Capodarco, which would have governed the role of the company as a data processor according to the requirements of the data protection law. Only in 2019 had a contract been concluded, which means the data had been unlawfully processed for 20 years.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller had used the biometric data of its employees to register their attendance. However, the Data Protection Authority (Garante) discovered that this data processing was no proportionate, resulting in an infringement upon the rights of the data subjects. Finally, the data processing of the biometric data was unlawful!

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: In one of the hospitals controlled by the data controller, 49 patients of the oncology ward were given discharge letters containing detailed pharmacological information belonging to other patients. Before the error was corrected, 14 patients had already accessed the documentation. Apparently, the error occurred due to a manual error of a technician.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: A theft was committed, and the data controller lost an external hard drive containing personal data. The data contained copies of identity documents, payroll records, and tax records. The DPA also discovered that the external hard drive had been located in a room where all the data controller’s employees had access. Moreover, the data controller failed to back up the data, which led to a permanent loss. Finally, the DPA concluded that the data controller violated its responsibility to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the security of the data being processed.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller reported two data breaches to the DPA, in which personal patient data had been disclosed to third parties by mistake. During the first incident, parents of a minor child discovered a microbiological examination report of another patient in their child’s file. The report contained the data subject’s name, address, birth date, tax number, and other health data. In the second incident, the heir of a patient received another patient’s health data, which included the name, date of birth, and data regarding the health status of the patient.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller was fined by the DPA for mistakenly disclosing a couple’s medical report to third parties. This report contained the health status, sex life, and information about a genetic consultation of the two data subjects. Apparently, this mistake was due to an error in packaging the letter.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The hospital was fined with EUR 50,000 by the DPA. When arriving at the gynecology unit of the hospital operated by the data controller (to get an abortion), the patient specifically demanded that her health data not be disclosed to other third parties. The patient left a separate telephone number to be contacted. However, when a nurse wanted to contact her to provide further information about therapy, she did not use the telephone number provided by the patient. Instead, she used the telephone number the home telephone number obtained from her patient file. When the husband responded to the call, the nurse informed him about the wife’s treatment, going against the patient’s request. Even though the nurse provided no further medical information, it was already clear that the patient had been admitted to the abortion unit and was scheduled to receive further therapy.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Roma Servizi per La Mobilita S.r.L.
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company failed to take the adequate organizational and technical measures needed to safeguard the data of citizens who had obtained permits to access specific restricted traffic areas. The data controller was the data processor for the city of Rome during this time. Part of the data controller’s activity involved the processing of individuals’ data regarding the possession of permits for restricted traffic areas. These permits were verified by scanning a QR code located on badges on the vehicle’s windshield. This would allow the city staff to check in real time whether a vehicle was allowed to be in a particular zone, as well as who was the possessor of that permit. However, the DPA discovered that the QR code was a normal QR code which anyone could scan and access the personal information (which included the name of the user and the vehicle’s license plate number). Lastly, the DPA concluded that the data controller did not take this risk into consideration when devising the QR codes, and thus it did not implement adequate security measures to protect the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company failed to take the adequate organizational and technical measures needed to safeguard the data of citizens who had obtained permits to access specific restricted traffic areas. The data controller was the data processor for the city of Rome during this time. Part of the data controller’s activity involved the processing of individuals’ data regarding the possession of permits for restricted traffic areas. These permits were verified by scanning a QR code located on badges on the vehicle’s windshield. This would allow the city staff to check in real time whether a vehicle was allowed to be in a particular zone, as well as who was the possessor of that permit. However, the DPA discovered that the QR code was a normal QR code which anyone could scan and access the personal information (which included the name of the user and the vehicle’s license plate number). Lastly, the DPA concluded that the city of Rome was using the services of a provider for hosting and maintaining databases without a proper agreement as per Art. 28 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Fondazione di religione e di culto “Casa sollievo della sofferenza” Opera di San Pio da Pietrelcina
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Foundation for Religion and Worship “Casa sollievo della sofferenza” Opera di San Pio da Pietrelcina was fiend with €5,000 by the Italian DPA. On the 31st of January 2020, the data controller notified the DPA about a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, documents that contained information regarding the health status of patients had been mistakenly emailed to a wrong address. A mistake appeared during the creation of an invoice, which was sent to another person with the same name, and further correspondence was carried out to that same person, in the name of the original data subject.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 37 (1), (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA fined the Ministry of Economic Development with EUR 75,000 because it failed to appoint a data protection officer by the 28th of May, 2018, as well as for publishing on its website personal data of more than 5000 managers. Through the data controller, small-sized and medium-sized companies could ask for professional advice on technological and digital processes, if they’d previously received a relevant voucher. However, the Italian DPA investigated the data controller and found out that the data of more than 5000 managers who had made themselves available for consultation was freely available on its website. This personal data included names, e-mails, tax numbers, CVs, and even copies of identity cards and health cards in some cases, and all could be downloaded at any time. Moreover, the website made it possible for anyone to download the directorate resolution that had approved this list of managers, which means the data and information of the directors was also publicly visible. The Italian DPA concluded that the directorate resolution was not an adequate nor sufficient legal basis to disclose this online data which resulted in an unlawful data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller was fined with EUR 20,000 for publishing in its newspapers photos of people taken into custody regarding a murder. The photos were showing the accused in handcuffs even though the data subjects had not given their consent. Even though some of the photos had the handcuffs pixelated, the faces of the accused were visible, which made their identification possible. The Italian DPA demanded that the data controller refrain from using these photos, yet the data controller refused, for which the DPA issued a fine.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: One of the municipality’s former employees complained to the DPA that a document containing his personal data had been published on the website of the municipality. The document included information about the acceptance and confirmation of the voluntary termination of employment, and information about evaluations of his work, health, and the employment relationship at that time. Moreover, the data subject also mentioned that this information was mentioned in a newspaper article. In the article, the mayor had issued a statement where he said that the employee had asked for more flexible working hours, and that he had been absent from work during the winter holiday vacations because of an illness.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: A former employee of the municipality complained to the DPA that a document containing her personal data, information about the employment and an excerpt from the termination letter, had been published on the official website of the municipality.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), d) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA fined the Istituto Nazionale Previdenza Sociale with EUR 300,000. The Istituto had been tasked with anti-fraud investigations related to COVID-19 relief funds. A series of press reports appeared that raised suspicions with the institute’s data processing practices regarding the application review of politicians, and the Italian DPA formally investigated the INPS in August 2020. The DPA discovered several violations during the investigations. Apparently, the data controller had been collecting data related to tens of thousands of politicians from public sources, which it would crosscheck with data from the applicants. However, the data controller failed to ensure that should only be collected from those politicians who were eligible to receive these assistance funds. Because of this, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of transparency, fairness, and lawfulness as set out by the GDPR. Moreover, the data controller had infringed upon the principle of data minimization after it initiated reimbursement checks on individuals who had their applications rejected and who would never receive those reimbursements. Finally, the Istituto Nazionale Previdenza Sociale had not done an impact assessment regarding the rights and freedoms of the data subjects, nor had it assessed the risks of the data processing operation as sensitive as one on applications for social benefits.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GPDR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: Fastweb S.p.A. was fined by the Italian DPA with EUR 4,500,000 when charged with aggressive telemarketing. After hundreds of users had submitted complaints to the Italian DPA, preliminary investigations were carried out, and they discovered that the data controller had been illegally processing the personal data of millions of users for the purpose of telemarketing. More specifically, some of the call centers working for the company Fastweb S.p.A. disregarded any data protection regulations. They would use phone numbers to make calls that were not registered in any Italian register for communication operators. The company had also received contact data for promotions from external partners, which the call centers processed without the consent of the data subjects. Moreover, the users also reported about being contacted by individuals who claimed they were from Fastweb and who tried to obtain the contractors’ identity documents through WhatsApp, most likely for spamming, phishing, and other such fraudulent purposes. One last breach involved the procedures for the “call me back” service, which made it impossible to freely give their informed consent or deactivate the service automatically.

allItems.name: Latvia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company had illegally processed personal data by publishing documents containing said personal data on its official website. The Italian DPA also found out that the data controller made publicly available parts of the company’s register (which was supposed to be non-public), which contained personal data.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 58 (2) f) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company IT sprendimai sekmei was fined with EUR 3,000 by the Lithuanian DPA (VDAI) regarding a quarantine app introduced in Lithuania with the COVID-19 pandemic in tow, in spring 2020. The data controller developed the app and offered it for use to the Lithuanian National Health Service. During the DPA investigations, it was discovered that when the app was functioning, the data of 677 individuals had been processed in varying degrees. The app had collected names, phone numbers, and the addresses of data subjects. Clearly, the data controller had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing. Moreover, the company also did not carry out any data protection impact assessment even though such an assessment was necessary due to the sensitive nature of the data being processed (health data among others). Finally, the DPA concluded that the company also provided incorrect and non-transparent information in the app’s privacy policy.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 58 (2) f) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The Nacionaliniam Visuomenes Sveikatos Centrui (NVSC) was fined with EUR 12,000 by the Lithuanian DPA (VDAI) regarding a quarantine app introduced in Lithuania with the COVID-19 pandemic in tow, in spring 2020. The app was created by IT sprendimai sekmei and used by the Lithuanian National Health Service. During the DPA investigations, it was discovered that when the app was functioning, the data of 677 individuals had been processed in varying degrees. The app had collected names, phone numbers, and the addresses of data subjects. Clearly, the data controller had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing. Moreover, the company also did not carry out any data protection impact assessment even though such an assessment was necessary due to the sensitive nature of the data being processed (health data among others). Finally, the DPA concluded that the company also provided incorrect and non-transparent information in the app’s privacy policy.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller, a company managing a number of Lithuanian registers, suffered a data breach in which 22 registers were affected. The DPA discovered that the company had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of personal data. Clearly, the measures that were implement by the company were not sufficient nor adequate to safeguard the resilience, availability, and integrity of the data, nor to make the data available again after the incident.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company unlawfully forwarded e-mails from a former employee for several months, without the data subject being informed of this data processing.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA fined a company with EUR 24,400 (NOK 250,000) because the data controller had ordered an employee to set up an automatic forwarding of his/her email account to another shared company account. The company claimed this was for the improvement of the company operations. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller had no legal basis to order this forwarding.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The energy company Dragefossen AS was fined with EUR 14,900 by the Norwegian DPA for installing a webcam on the roof of the office building in the center of Rognan, which operated 24/7 and filmed the city center. The live streams could be watched on the official website of the data controller, and on YouTube. Moreover, the live streams recorded the last 12 hours, filming a public street, a parking lot, the entrances of two grocery stores, the local bank, a liquor store, a pharmacy, the city hall, and other buildings. Due to the low quality of the image, it was not possible to distinguish individual facial details or license plate numbers. However, the image quality was sufficiently good to identify the type of car the data subjects had been driving, the clothes they’d been wearing, their hair color, and several other personal characteristics. Naturally, these details were more than enough for watchers of the livestream to identify family members, friends, coworkers, etc. The Norwegian DPA decided that the live stream breached Art. 6 (1) GDPR and Art. 5 (1) GDPR. This decision of the DPA underlines the fact that the live streams showed a significant number of employees, many of whom were monitored 24/7. The employees were going to and coming back from work, some bought groceries, alcohol, medication, or were in the public areas for various reasons. Such activities are not expected to be monitored or posted on the internet, everyone to see.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: Two schools in Alesund demanded that students download a training app called Strava in order to participate in physical education classes. The teachers then gave tasks to students that would be tracked through the app. When the DPA performed an investigation, it found out that there were several data breaches since the municipality had not performed any data protection impact assessment, nor had it provided standard protection procedures for privacy-compliant apps for school use. These would have been necessary when it came to the potential risk associated with the students. The protection of the data processing was also not considered by implement the necessary organizational and technical measures.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller failed to report a personal data breach, violating Art. 33 (1) GDPR. The DPA was informed of the personal data breach by an individual who had come into unauthorized possession of the personal data. The personal data consisted of an unencrypted, non-password protected attachment sent via email by an employee of the data controller, which contained personal data of several hundred individuals.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The data controller refused to cooperate with the DPA during an investigation, failing to provide the necessary information. The company ignored two requests for information filed by the DPA regarding a complaint filed by an individual. Moreover, the company offered no reasons for its ignoring of the information requests.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Krajowa Szkoła Sądownictwa i Prokuratury (National School of Justice and Prosecution) was fined with EUR 22,200 by the Polish DPA (UODO) after an investigation initiated because of a report of a data breach on the training platform website of the data controller. The data of more than 50,000 individuals was exposed to the Internet during a test migration to a new platform. The personal data included user names, names, e-mail and postal addresses, units and departments, as well as telephone numbers of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the data controller failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the confidentiality of the data processed. Moreover, the contract between the data controller and the company that processed the data failed to comply with the legal requirements. For instance, the contract failed to mention the categories of data that would be processed.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller (ING Bank, the Bucharest Branch) had sent files for the issuance of insurance policies to a contractual partner. Though, the files contained outdated information, and the employees of the insurance policy monitoring department failed to check it, and processed the insurance policies as per the work process, affecting 270 people. This breach of confidentiality of personal data happened because the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.controller: Individual holding the position of General Secretary for a political party in Bucharest
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) fined a natural person with EUR 500 for publishing on a social network a list that contained personal data (names, nationalities, signatures, postal addresses, dates of birth) of ten supporters of the political party. The data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of the personal data. Moreover, the controller did not sufficiently cooperate with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA fined S.C. Medicover S.R.L with EUR 2,000 for violating Art. 32 (1) b), (2), (4) GDPR. After being notified multiple times by the controller about personal data breaches regarding unauthorized disclosure and access to personal data (names, email and health data, correspondence addresses) of data subjects, the DPA performed and investigation. Apparently, documents containing personal data had been sent to wrong recipients multiple times. The DPA concluded that the company failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company failed to implement the necessary security measures that would ensure the protection of the personal data being processed, and was fined with EUR 10,000 by the Romanian DPA. During the investigation, the ANSPDCP discovered that the data controller’s failure to implement these security measures resulted in a total of 99,210 data subjects having their personal data disclosed without authorization. The data included gender, telephone numbers, and customer number. Moreover, there was another data breach in which the personal data of 413 customers was accessed without authorization. The Romanian DPA considered that the company violated Art. 32 (1) and (2) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company sent a debt collection email to an individual, linking the payment of an invoice directly through the data controller’s website. However, the link showed another customer’s data, which the data subject saw. Due to the company’s acknowledgment of the debt and immediate payment, the fine was reduced from EUR 5,000 to EUR 3,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The data subject claimed his right of information had been violated according. The AEPD requested the data controller to comply with the request for information of the data controller within 10 days, and to offer evidence of this to the AEPD. The data controller failed to comply with the request within the deadline, though. However, the original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 due to immediate acknowledgement and payment of the fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: One of the company’s data subjects had terminated an existing contract with the controller because a move, and demanded that the data controller delete his/her data. The data controller rejected the data subject’s request, referencing outstanding invoices. Apparently, the data controller had been sending the invoices to the old address of the data subject. Even though the data subject notified the data controller of the change of address, further notices and invoices were sent to the old address.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The private person unlawfully used two video surveillance cameras that recorded parts of the public space and personal properties.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The private person illegally used camera surveillance. A data subject had rent out two rooms in an apartment of the data controller. The data controller had installed two video surveillance cameras in the apartment, claiming that they’d been installed for security purposes exclusively, while also monitoring the entrance area alone. However, the DPA found out that the cameras also filmed other parts of the apartment such as the living room, which is an unjustified invasion of the privacy of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data subject that issued a complaint to the Spanish DPA (AEPD) worked for a construction company and did some renovation work for them. During the working hours, the controller’s properties had been damaged. As a result, the controller sent a letter with damage claims to the complainant but also to his father, which had previously worked for the same construction company, but who was no an uninvolved third party. The Spanish DPA considered that the processing of the father’s data happened without a legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The company had no privacy policy on its website, nor did it provide any information as required by Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: One data subject received advertising calls from the controller on behalf of Vodafone Espana, S.A.U, despite the fact that the data subject was on the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The restaurant made unauthorized use of two video surveillance systems to record part of the public space without a clear cause.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Vodafone Espana, SAU received a fine of EUR 120,000 for continuously sending electronic bills to a data subject even though the data subject had objected to this several times, and had already terminated his contract. The data controller clearly processed the personal data, and has already received two fines for this in the past. The DPA classified this event as very serious and imposed a high fine of EUR 200,000 that was reduced to EUR 120,000 for immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company had no privacy policy on its website, which prompted the Spanish DPA to fine it with EUR 1,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.source: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Some data subjects reported receiving advertising calls from the data controller, even though the data subjects were on the Robinson advertising exclusion list. Due to immediate acknowledgment and payment, the fine was reduced from EUR 20,000 to EUR 12,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company was fined by the Spanish DPA with EUR 200,000. Two companies, Waitum S.L. and Servicios Aby 2018, complained to the DPA that their clients received letters from the data controller. This happened in the context where the two companies had transferred their customers’ personal data to the data controller through a network access agreement. The agreement stated that, while the customers would receive electricity from the data controller, the two companies would still be in control of their customers, just as before. However, the letters mentioned that the two companies were guilty of non-payment and breaches of contract. However, the DPA concluded during its investigation that the letters were not necessary in the context of applying the binding principles of the contract. This means that the data controller had violated the principles of data minimization and purpose limitation, unlawfully processing the customers’ personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: A website operator was fine with EUR 9,000 by the Spanish DPA for publishing photos of the data subject on its official website without obtaining the consent of the data subject first. Moreover, the website had no privacy policy in place.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: A homeowners’ association, in this case the data controller, recorded a homeowners’ meeting in the elevator of the building where the tenants lived, and publicly displayed it. In the recording, one could identify the floors, names, and apartment numbers of the meeting participants, as well as some of the neighbors. The data controller motivated this public notice by claiming that the meeting concerned the legal actions to be taken against some of the residential parties. At a later date, the residential parties would be notified of this. However, the DPA concluded that this was still a violation of Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, related to the principles of data confidentiality and integrity.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: A data subject twice complained to the DPA that the data controller had sent advertising SMS messages, even though the data subject had demanded that his personal data be deleted and that he not receive any more advertising messages. The data subject claimed he received more than 60 SMS messages within 30 days. Another complain was filed by the data subject when the data subject sent him more messages that contained the confidential data of a third party. Among the data was the login information of a customer to a company platform. On that company platform, the data subject could see personal information such as invoices. Even after the data subject informed the company of this mistake, he kept receiving mails and messages. When the data controller admitted guilt and paid the fine, the original fine of EUR 150,000 was reduced to EUR 90,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data subject was added by the data controller to a debtor register without prior notification. Apparently, the data subject had delayed rent payments with the landlord, who had sent previous requests for payment, as well as notices for payment. However, these notices and payment requests mentioned nothing about the personal data of the data subject being entered in a debtors’ register in the case of a non-payment. Moreover, the rental contract did not mention this point either, which led to the DPA concluding that the data controller had no legitimate reasons or justifications, under the GDPR, to process the personal data of the data subject.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The hospital was fined with EUR 10,000 by the Spanish DPA for violating Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR. A patient filed a complaint with the DPA concerning the data controller. An MRI was performed on the data subject in 2019, for an injury of the right knee. The cost for this examination was covered by the private health insurance of the patient. In the same month of 2019, another MRI had to be performed due to a work-related injury to the same knee, to a different hospital. However, the second hospital’s system linked the first MRI (which was privately-arranged) to the patient’s records at this second hospital. It should be clear that the first MRI had been provided through the hospital network without a medical justification, due to the private nature. This turnaround was unfavorable for the data subject because, when the second MRI came, the doctor told him to contact his private physician or a social insurance regarding this injury, because the accident can’t be considered a work-related accident. The doctor also said that, since the first MRI had a non-occupational cause, the second MRI could not have an occupational cause either.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data controller, while operating a website that provides information about internships offered by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Sports, had compiled and published the data of participants to competitions held by the ministry from public sources without the consent of the data subjects. Moreover, the data controller had not informed the data subjects beforehand, infringing upon Art. 13 and 14 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR, Art. 21 LSSI, Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA received a total of 191 complaints against Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. since 2018. All data subjects complained about receiving marketing calls and messages, all of which were unsolicited and without prior consent from the data subjects. Even though the data subjects had officially objected to the data processing, Vodafone continued sending them marketing materials. Even more, some data subjects were contacted even though they were on the Robinson data exclusion list. The Spanish DPA claims that an aggravating factor to justify the large fine is that Vodafone Espana had been receiving regular fines in more than 50 cases from 2018 to 2020, with more than 162 complaints in less than two years.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The controller approved the loan request of an identity thief who used the personal data of a third party to apply for a microcredit while pretending to be the data subject. The data controller unlawfully processed the personal data since this data did not belong to the actual loan recipient, but to another third party. There was no legal basis for the data processing, which means there was a breach of Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 12,000 for immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller installed a video surveillance system that recorded the public thoroughfare, covering parts of the shared patio of a nearby apartment complex. Moreover, the data controller also failed to place any sign in a visible place about this camera, nor has the data controller obtained the consent of any tenant before using the camera.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company was filed with EUR 600,000 after a severe data breach was reported to the AEPD. The data breach involved the unauthorized access to personal contact details and bank accounts. More than 489,000 individuals and about 1,500,000 records were affected during the data breach. The data controller had clearly failed to take the appropriate and necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing, and it also delayed the DPA notification by 41 days. One aggravating factor that led the DPA to increase the fine amount was the fact that the data breach affected people worldwide, not only in Spain, affecting sensitive financial data as well.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company’s data processing policy was not compliant with Art. 13 GDPR, and it also had no privacy policy on the website where the users would be informed about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller published pictures of a 4-year-old child on WeChat, a Chinese messenger service, without obtaining the parents’ consent first. The photos showed the child participating in the data controller’s Chinese lessons. While the data controller attempted to cover the face of the child with a digital sticker, it was still partially visible. And despite the parents’ demand that he deletes the photos and apologize, the data controller did not respond.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The complainant renewed her driver’s license with the data controller in 2009. After changing her residential address in 2018, one year later she received a mail from the data controller to her new address, even though she had not informed the data controller of this change. In this letter, the data controller informed the data subject that the driver’s license would expire soon. When asked why it possessed the data subject’s new address, the data controller claimed that its databases were being updated regularly with data from the Spanish transport authority DGT. The data subject filed a claim with the Spanish DPA against the data controller since she had not consented to the data processing. When the DPA investigated the case, they discovered that the data controller had contractual relations with DGT, as claimed beforehand. However, DGT claimed that the processing of contact data would be done to ensure the address accuracy when renewing a driver’s license or for the issuance of medical reports, though the data subject should still request and consent to the change of address. This principle was not observed in this case, so the DAP determined that the data controller had violated the purpose limitation principle.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: When the client requested his documents to submit them to the tax authorities, the company sent him an e-mail containing the documents of another client.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data subject had previously been a customer of the data controller years back. Despite this, she received payment reminders for services she had never booked or made use of. After informing the controller and demanding the deletion of her data, the data controller claimed that it would delete her data. Despite this, she kept receiving the SMS messages. Then, the data subject twice complained to the Spanish DPA about this, and the data controller assured both times that it would correct this mistake and delete the data subject’s personal data from the system. However, the mailing continued, which led the data subject to file a third complaint.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller used cameras that monitored the public space, which is a breach of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company was fined with EUR 475,000 for not reporting a data breach to the DPA in a timely manner. Back in December 2018, criminals had accessed the data of 4,109 people who had booked a hotel room through the Bookim.com booking site. The personal data included names, phone numbers, addresses, and booking details. The credit data of 283 people was also accessed, with 97 cases where the criminals managed to access the security code of the credit card. Moreover, the criminals also pretended to be employees of Booking.com in order to get the credit card details of other victims via phone or email. The company was notified of this data breach on January 13, 2019 but only notified the DPA on February 7, 2019. With 22 days of delay, the company was supposed to report the data breach to the DPA in 72 hours at most.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: OLVG, an Amsterdam hospital, was fined with EUR 440,000 for not taking sufficient security measures between 2018 and 2020 when medical records were accessed without authorization. The data controller failed to check who had accessed files and ensure that the computer systems were properly secured against foreign, unauthorized access. As a result, students and employees were able to access patient files without justification or it being a necessity for work. These files also contained social security numbers, telephone numbers, and addresses of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 8 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA fined a school with EUR 1,000 for not obtaining the consent of the students’ parents when conducting a survey on students’ wellbeing though a smartschooling system. It thus violated the principle of data minimization. After the data controller appealed the DPA’s decision, the original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,000.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subject received a phone call from the data controller on the private mobile number before the Greek parliamentary elections in July 2019. Apparently, the call was made with promotional purposes for the candidate’s election. When the data subject inquired on the use of the personal information for this purpose, the data controller responded in a contradictory manner.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subject received a phone call from the data controller on the private mobile number before the Greek parliamentary elections in July 2019. Apparently, the call was made with promotional purposes for the candidate’s election. When the data subject inquired on the use of the personal information for this purpose, the data controller responded in a contradictory manner.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller was fined with 19,900 EUR for using a surveillance system to monitor its employees and customers. The DPA concluded that the data controller had been using the camera surveillance system unlawfully, without a legal basis to do so. Moreover, the data controller also did not offer sufficient information to the data subjects regarding the use of this surveillance system.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA imposed a fine of 3,400 EUR on the company for violating Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The data controller was operating a carwash, and an act of vandalism took place at the payment terminal. The data controller sent the recorded footage of the vandalism to the employer of the alleged vandal. The Norwegian DPA concluded that the sharing of this video recording happened without a legal basis, violating the aforementioned GPDR articles. The DPA also mentioned that sharing this video recording was not done in an attempt to clarify the situation because the recordings had already been surrendered to the police.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.controller: S.C. Tip Top Food Industry S.R.L.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company had installed several security cameras that monitored the food areas and the changing rooms of the employees. This CCTV system was allegedly used to deter any theft and protect the company’s manufactured goods. However, the Romanian DPA concluded that the data controller had clearly violated the principle of data minimization because surveillance of this magnitude was not necessary. The manufactured goods could have been secured with other means that did not require an intrusion of privacy to the employees.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller was fined with 1,500 EUR for accidentally destroying personal data of customers of Raiffeisen Bank S.A., in its capacity as the bank’s data controller. The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) claimed that this incident took place due to a lack of organizational and technical measures that would ensure the security and protection of the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The data controller refused to answer to the data subject’s inquiries regarding the use of his personal data. Moreover, the data policy of the data controller, regarding data protection, failed to comply with Art. 13 GDPR. As such, the data subject was confused about the use of this personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The police found a total of 29 envelopes containing results of medical examinations, which were addressed to the data controller’s employees, in a local industrial area. The DPA also mentioned that two envelopes were found opened. In conclusion, the DPA claimed that the company had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of the employees’ personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller, Kukimbia S.L., transports, stores, and distributes goods. When documents containing personal information about the data controller’s customers and suppliers were found near a trash can next to a warehouse belonging to the data controller. In this case, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 32 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The AEPD fined Promotech Digital S.L. with EUR 2,400 for constantly sending advertising SMS messages to a data subject, even though the data subjects had not requested or agreed to receiving these SMS messages. Moreover, these SMS messages did not include any method to unsubscribe from the advertisement campaign. The data subject could cancel it via email, though. The data subject had objected in the past to receiving these SMS messages, yet the data controller kept sending SMS messages. Due to an acknowledgment of guilt and immediate payment, the fine was reduced to EUR 2,400 from EUR 3,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Originally, a fine of EUR 100,000 was imposed on Kutxabank S.A. A former customer complained that the bank failed to comply with his request for data deletion. After the DPA started investigating the data controller, it found out that the data subject had exercised his right for data deletion back when he was still a customer of the bank. When trying to open up a new account with the data controller, the data subject was informed that opening an account was not possible because his data was blocked (as a result of the request for data erasure). The data subject was informed that if he wanted to open a new account, the data would have to be unblocked. In this sense, the letter came attached with a form. This form claimed that, upon signing it, the data subject would forfeit his previous request for data erasure, thus allowing the data controller to his data again. The Spanish DPA concluded that a temporary erasure of data did not legally correspond to the right to erasure. The DPA also stated that any blocked or deleted data could not be processed again even when the data subject and the data controller enter a new contractual relationship for the same purpose as before.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Vodafone Espana S.A.U. was fined with EUR 90,000. Three data subjects had complained to the AEPD that Vodafone Espana had sent unsolicited text messages informing them of new invoices, even though the data subjects had no contractual relationships with the controller anymore. Moreover, none of the invoices were outstanding, since the amounts to be paid were zero euros. The data subjects had asked the data controller to stop sending further text messages and to delete their personal data. In turn, the data controller informed the data subjects that these messages were caused by a technical error, and the data subjects would no longer receive such text messages anymore. However, the data subjects kept receiving SMS messages. Vodafone Espana S.A.U. acknowledged its guilt and paid the fine immediately, which led to a reduction from EUR 150,000 to EUR 90,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA fined a private individual with EUR 3,000. The individual lives on the 1st floor of an apartment complex and frequently rents apartments on the 2nd and 3rd floors to tourists. He had installed four video surveillance cameras on the three floors at the entrance to the building, justifying them with security concerns regarding the rental to tourists. However, the owners’ association had not granted him any permission to operate or install these cameras. Moreover, the data controller had no signs in the building to inform others about the operation of these cameras. The AEPD discovered that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization since the cameras captured areas of the building used by the entire community, and their surveillance was not necessary to protect the data controller’s properties. The data controller failed to inform the residents of the building about the data processing, thus violating its obligation to provide information about data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller was using two unauthorized video surveillance cameras that covered areas of the public space.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller had previously published on its website a photo of the data subject without first obtaining his consent.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller had published a brochure on sex education in several schools. These brochures contained the names and photos of three data subjects who had not given their consent to the data processing. After acknowledgment and immediate payment of the fine, it was reduced from EUR 5,000 to EUR 4,000.

allItems.name: Spain
