allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A private individual had installed a surveillance video camera on his property. This camera recorded the public space and other neighboring properties. The data controller said that the cameras had been installed for security reasons related to his property. However, the AEPD concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization because the monitoring was too extensive and not necessary to protect the data controller’s property.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4), (6) GDPR, Art. 14 (2) a) GDPR, Art. 14 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 25 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: ParkkiPate Oy was fined with EUR 75,000 by the Finnish DPA. The company had issued parking tickets to several data subjects, upon which the individuals requested to know what personal data the company processed, and some individuals asked the company to delete their personal data. As a reply, the company stated that it would need the ID card number and the physical address of the data subjects to delete the data, since the name and the parking ticket number was not enough to identify them. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization and had also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing. While the DPA claimed that the company could, in theory, request further data to assist with the identification, this was only allowed if identification was not possible without the additional information. However, this was not the case. The DPA also found out that the company had violated the principle of storage limitation. Apparently, the data controller had been storing photos of illegally parked cars and copies of parking tickets without establishing a clear deadline for the deletion of this data.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.controller: 11th District Public Health Department of the Government Office of Budapest
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined the XI District Office of the Government of Budapest with EUR 27,700 for failing to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the protection of personal data. Apparently, the data controller had sent emails with health data about Covid-19 rapid tests and contact details of the people tested, to various doctors, in an unencrypted Excel file. No measures were taken to ensure the confidentiality and security of this file. Moreover, the data controller did not inform the DPA about this data violation.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: InfoMentor ehf was fined with EUR 23,100 by the Icelandic DPA for a data breach of Art. 33 GDPR reported by the data controller. This incident related to the company’s online system used by various institutions and schools to communicate and for other information purposes. During the investigations, the DPA concluded that the data controller had failed to employ the necessary technical and organizational security measures, which led to the data breach. This security leach led to the six-digit system PIN number of each individual user becoming visible publicly on the URL address of a specific page in the mentor system. This led to unauthorized individuals gaining access to the personal data of 424 children.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 21 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data controller was making calls for TIM s.p.a., with several calls being made despite the data subjects’ lack of consent or objection to said calls. Moreover, Garante found out that the data controller had also contacted a total of 47,981 telephone numbers without a legal basis. Moreover, the DPA concluded that the data controller had not respected the data subjects’ right to object. For instance, one user was contacted a total of 155 times in one month, even though he had objected to the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data controller had been making calls on behalf of TIM s.p.a. with several calls being made despite the data subjects’ lack of consent or objection to said calls. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to verify whether the data in the contact lists received from third-party companies was legitimate or not. The company also did not ensure the data subjects had given their consent for these promotional activities.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Comune di San Marco in Lamis
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The municipality uploaded documents of the data subject and his family on its official website, which was publicly available. These documents were in the form of two orders against the data subjects, and they were related to proceedings against the data subjects for engaging in construction work without a building permit. These documents contained dates of birth, names, tax numbers, places of birth, and physical addresses of the data subject and his relatives. Previously, the data subject had asked the municipality to remove the documents from their website but this request was refused.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 130 (1), (2) Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company had sent email advertisement to a data subject without obtaining consent first. The data subject filed two complaints against the company. Apparently, the data subject had complained repeatedly about the data processing, and the data controller kept sending ads. In fact, the data controller did not respond at all to the data subject’s requests for data deletion. Furthermore, the data controller also did not keep any register of the data processing activities, failing to cooperate sufficiently with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A data subject complained to the Italian DPA that the news station had published an article where he, the data subject, was referred to. The data subject legally exercised his right under Art. 17 and requested that his data be deleted from the article because it was not relevant. The data controller did not, however, respond to the request in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The municipality of Castellanza uploaded documents with personal data of various data subjects on its website. These documents which contained legal proceedings of the data subject, were freely accessible to anybody.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Back on May 5, 2021, the Norwegian DPA announced its intent to fine Disqus Inc. with EUR 2,500,000 for violating Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, and Art. 13 GDPR. Allegedly, the company had unlawfully tracked visitors of Norwegian websites that used the Disqus plugin. In turn, they sent this data to various third-party advertisers.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The company was fined With EUR 2,000 for publishing the contract termination letter of an employee on the WhatsApp group used by all employees. As a result, all the employees gained access to the personal information of the data subject, including name, address, ID number, first name, and specific information concerning the request for termination).

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c), d) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company was fined with EUR 1,000,000 by the Spanish DPA (AEPD) because of 96 complaints filed to the DPA against the data controller. Apparently, the data controller had included specific personal data of individuals associated with debts in the Judicial Claims and Public Entities File without first obtaining their consent. In fact, in many cases, the personal data was not even correct and factual. According to the AEPD, processing this personal data, even in connection to the FIJ file, was unlawful and a violation of several data protection principles (purpose limitation, data minimization, accuracy, and lawfulness and transparency). Moreover, the data controller had not even informed that data subjects about the processing of this data, clearly violating its duty as a data controller.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subjects a complaint against the company to the DPA because the company had sent SMS advertisements even though he had previously requested that his data be deleted. The data controller had also confirmed the data deletion. The fine includes EUR 10,000 for breaching Art. 17 GDPR, and EUR 5,000 for breaching Art. 21 LSSI.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subjects a complaint against the company to the DPA because the company had sent SMS advertisements even though he had previously requested that his data be deleted. The data controller had also confirmed the data deletion. Then, the data controller claimed that they could not fulfill the data subject’s request due to human error. The fine includes EUR 3,000 for breaching Art. 17 (1) GDPR, and EUR 2,000 for breaching Art. 21 LSSI. The initial fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 for admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company was fined with EUR 1,500,000 by the Spanish DPA after several complains for unlawful data processing were received by the DPA. As it stands, the data controller had not informed the data subjects about collecting their data, as per Art. 13 GDPR. Articles 15 and 22 GDPR were also breached because the data subjects were not informed of their rights. Moreover, the contact details of the data controller were also incomplete. The company would also conclude contracts with customer representatives instead of communicating directly with the customers. However, the data controller did not expressly check whether the representatives were authorized by the data subjects to represent them. The Spanish DPA found that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary security procedures to verify the allegations of the representatives.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company was fined with EUR 1,500,000 by the Spanish DPA after several complains for unlawful data processing were received by the DPA. As it stands, the data controller had not informed the data subjects about collecting their data, as per Art. 13 GDPR. Articles 15 and 22 GDPR were also breached because the data subjects were not informed of their rights. Moreover, the contact details of the data controller were also incomplete. The company would also conclude contracts with customer representatives instead of communicating directly with the customers. However, the data controller did not expressly check whether the representatives were authorized by the data subjects to represent them. The Spanish DPA found that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary security procedures to verify the allegations of the representatives.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company was fined with EUR 3,000 by the Spanish DPA because a data subject had filed a complaint against it, stating that the data controller kept sending advertisements on WhatsApp even though the data subject had requested that his data be deleted.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Back in 2017, the municipality installed special measurement boxes that would measure crowds in the center of Enschede. Special sensors in the boxes would detect the Wi-Fi signals dispatched by the cell phones of passing people registering each of them with a code. And based on these codes, it could then calculate how busy the center was. As it stands, these measurements and codes led to the tracking of individual passers-by because the boxes would track particular cell phones. Even though the municipality claimed that this wasn’t even remotely the goal of the boxes, the DPA concluded that the Wi-Fi tracking, even though unintentional, was a serious breach of the GDPR. Thus, the municipality unlawfully tracked passers-by without a legal basis, violating Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA (APD) fined a financial company with EUR 100,000. Apparently, a data subject had previously filed two complaints with the Belgian DPA against the company. These complains related to 20 queries of her personal data from the credit register of the National Bank of Belgium. The data controller had employed the data subject’s ex-husband. The husband had allegedly used his position in the company to illegally gain access to the register to obtain financial information about the data subject, thus gaining an advantage in their divorce proceedings. According to the DPA, these data violations appeared because the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational measures to protect personal data from unauthorized processing.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined A. ΕΠΙΛΟΓΗ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ with EUR 5,000. The data controller had failed to respond to multiple requests for information and data deletion from the data subject. During the DPA’s investigation, the data controller informed the DPA that it had deleted the data subject’s personal information from its databases. However, the data controller failed to notify the data subject of this. Moreover, the Hellenic DPA concluded that the data subject’s data had been collected for other purpose than the agreed ones. The data controller had not obtained any consent of the data subject regarding the new processing purpose of the personal data.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has imposed a fine of EUR 5,000 upon ΚΑΡΙΕΡΑ A.E. A data subject filed a complaint with the Hellenic DPA against the data controller because the data controller kept sending him email advertisements despite having requested the deletion of his data and the controller had confirmed the deletion. Due to a technical error, the data subject’s data had not been deleted according to his request.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA) of the municipality of Tavros Moschato
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) d) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined the Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA) of the municipality of Tavros Moschato with EUR 10,000. The data controller had unlawfully published documents containing personal data of the data subject. The documents contained, other than his name, information about his profession, place of work, and a specific evaluation of his behavior at work. The data controller also failed to respond to a deletion request from the data subject. The fine is comprised of EUR 7,000 for a violation of Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 3,000 for a violation of Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR and Art. 17 (1) d) GDPR.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (NAIH) fined with EUR 1,425 the operator of a care facility. The data controller had installed 25 cameras in all of the rooms of the facility, except the restrooms, locker rooms and the main nurses’ station. The video surveillance recorded both the employees and the residents of the facility. The data controller claims that the cameras had been installed for nothing else other than security purposes. These purposes included preventing unauthorized persons from gaining access to the facility, and preventing theft attempts. The DPA concludes that the extensive video surveillance wasn’t necessary for the processing purpose (security of the facility). Moreover, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (NAIH) fined fine with EUR 1,400 a company. During his professional activities at the company, a data subject had made a telephone call to the data controller on the 23rd of September, 2019. The data controller had then recorded the conversation without informing the data subject or obtaining his consent. Then, he provided it to the company where the data subject was employed at that time. The employer of the data subject then terminated his employment because the recorded telephone call apparently failed to meet the company’s service and professional standards. The NAIH concluded that the data controller processed the data subject’s data unlawfully and without a legal basis, and also breached its accountability obligation by failing to demonstrate the lawfulness of the data processing. Moreover, the data controller also violated its duty to provide information when requested, under Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (NAIH) fined fine with EUR 570 a company. During his professional activities at the company, a data subject had made a telephone call to the data controller on the 23rd of September, 2019. The data controller had then recorded the conversation without informing the data subject or obtaining his consent. Then, he provided it to the company where the data subject was employed at that time. The employer of the data subject then terminated his employment because the recorded telephone call apparently failed to meet the company’s service and professional standards. The NAIH concluded that the data controller processed the data subject’s data unlawfully and without a legal basis, and also breached its accountability obligation by failing to demonstrate the lawfulness of the data processing. Moreover, the data controller also violated its duty to provide information when requested, under Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (DPC) has fined with EUR 90,000 the Irish Credit Bureau (ICB). The fine was issued after a data breach was reported by the controller to the DPA on the 31st of August, 2018. The data controller is a credit reporting agency that has a database of credit contract performances held between financial institutions and borrowers. The data breach took place when the data controller changed a code to one of its databases that contained a technical error. As a consequence, between the 28th of June, 2018 and the 30th of August, 2018, the ICB database inaccurately updated the records of a total of 15,120 closed accounts. The data controller disclosed 1,062 inaccurate account records to financial institutions or affected individuals before this problem issue was solved.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 7,000 TECNOMEDICAL S.r.l. A data subject filed a complaint with the Italian DPA after the data controller failed to adequately respond to his request for personal information. The data subject had previously requested access to his personal data from the data controller. In this sense, he demanded the data controller a copy of his medical records and the medical documentation of his past dental implant surgery. However, the data controller failed to provide the complete information in due time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 2,000 Società triveneta di chirurgia. A physician had preiovusly shown slides of a clinical case at a congress he was participating at. The cases were then published on the data controller’s website. The slides contained personal data of a patient, like the patient’s initials, gender, age, and a detailed history of the patient’s pathology, as well as details of admissions from 1980 to 2016. There was also a detailed schematic of the surgical procedures performed during this period, indicating the date of admission and the surgery, the surgical department that performed these procedures, the specific days that the patient spent in hospital, various diagnostic images, and a total of 22 photographs that showed the patient during the surgeries. The data subject never consented to such processing of his personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 2,000 Società triveneta di chirurgia. A physician had preiovusly shown slides of a clinical case at a congress he was participating at. The cases were then published on the data controller’s website. The slides contained personal data of a patient, like the patient’s initials, gender, age, and a detailed history of the patient’s pathology, as well as details of admissions from 1980 to 2016. There was also a detailed schematic of the surgical procedures performed during this period, indicating the date of admission and the surgery, the surgical department that performed these procedures, the specific days that the patient spent in hospital, various diagnostic images, and a total of 22 photographs that showed the patient during the surgeries. The data subject never consented to such processing of his personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) fined with EUR 40,000 the municipality of Palermo. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the Italian DPA against the municipality of Palermo. He claimed that an unauthorized person had gained access and processed his data from a food subsidy application. The DPA determined that this data processing had occurred because the municipality failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure the security and confidentiality of the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) fined with EUR 12,000 the Italian National Institute for Social Security (Istituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociale). The fine was issued because the data controller did not respond properly to two requests for information of the data subject submitted to the data controller. These information requests were related to the unlawful disclosure of the data subject’s personal data to third parties. Initially, the data subject received no response to either request for information. During the investigation, the data controller clarified the situation and explained that the other requests had not been answered due to a technical error in the e-mail system.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 15,000 the Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma. In February 2020, a data subject complained to the DPA, talking about a breach of data protection laws regarding the booking services for medical specialists offered by the data controller. Apparently, to book an appointment on the booking portal, visitors had to complete an online form with various personal information. The DPA found that the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure that would ensure the protection of data processing. Furthermore, the data controller failed to comply with its information obligations according to Art. 13 GDPR, since it did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data when the data collection took place.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (Datatilsynet) issued a fine to the national development bank Innovasjon Norge for NOK 1,000,000 (EUR 95,500). The data controller had carried out several credit checks on the data subject without having any contractual basis. Therefore, the bank had unlawfully analyzed various financial data of the data subject without the data subject’s consent.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (Datatilsynet) has fined with EUR 39,000 the Municipality of Oslo. On a website of the data controller, there was a subpoena from the public prosecutor’s office regarding the data subject had made available to the public. The subpoena contained personal information such as health data. The incident happened because the subpoena wasn’t originally classified as confidential and wasn’t exempted from public disclosure. The document was publicly available for five hours before the municipality removed it from public access.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (UODO) fined Cyfrowy Polsat S.A. with EUR 245,000. The fine took into consideration a large number of data breaches reported by the data controller to the Polish DPA. Apparently, postal correspondence containing personal data was either lost or misdelivered. The DPA concludes that, although the data breaches had been caused by the courier company hired by the data controller, it was the data controller’s responsibility to ensure that these breaches did not occur. The controller did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures appropriate to the risk that would protect the data processing. Furthermore, the controller did not notify the data subjects about the data breaches until two to three months later.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined with EUR 2,000 Telekom Romania Communications SA. The data controller had previously made an advertising call to the data subject despite the latter having exercised his right to object to the processing of his personal data for marketing and advertising purposes. He requested the controller to delete his telephone number and e-mail address from the Telekom database.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined with EUR 200 the operator of the website declaratieppr.ro. During the Covid19 pandemic, visitors to this website were able to fill out form where they were required to enter their place of residence. Personal data such as address, name, and ID number were collected in this sense. However, the data controller wasn’t able to prove the lawfulness of the data processing. Furthermore, the data controller did not sufficiently inform the data subjects about the data processing when collecting the personal data, and had also failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of the data processing.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined with EUR 500 Asociație de Proprietari din municipiul Iași (Owners Association of Iasi Municipality). The data controller did not provide the DPA with the information it had requested.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined Banca Comercială Română S.A. with EUR 2,000. A data subject had issued a complaint with the DPA because the data controller had previously used his personal data to enforce a procedure for debts arising from a credit agreement that he was unaware of.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A. with EUR 30,000. The data controller has previosuly sent an invoice to the data subject although there wasn’t any contractual obligation between them. The data subject had concluded a motorcycle insurance policy with the data controller back in 2016, but had terminated the policy in 2017.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has issued a fine of EUR 3,000 to a physician. The data controller had left his/her former clinic and to start working in a new clinic. The data subject had then taken over the data controller’s former clinic. The purchase agreement between the two clearly stated that the selling party (the data controller) wasn’t’ allowed to make a copy of the patient’s files under any circumstances. However, the controller had informed his/her former patients that his/her services could be obtained at his/her new clinic in the future. The AEPD discovered that the data controller had acted not only in breach of contract but also in breach of data protection legislation by contacting the former patients.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The homeowners association had a video surveillance on the public space, thus violating the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, there was a violation of information obligations, as insufficient information has been provided about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Telefonica de España, S.A.U.. with EUR 75,000 A data subject had complained to the AEPD against the telecommunications company. The controller had booked a service for the data subject without the data subject having concluded a contract for it. After the data subject had not made any payments for this service, the service was canceled in that same year and a specific collection agency was hired to collect the alleged outstanding debt. The AEPD concluded that neither the data processing of the service booking nor the transfer of the data subject’s personal data to the collection agency had been lawful. The original fine of EUR 75,000 was then reduced to EUR 45,000 because of immediate payment and acknowledgement of debt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined the managing director of a company with EUR 1,500. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller with whom he had a contract. The data controller was fined because it had not adequately informed the data subject about the processing of the data when collecting it. The Spanish DPA claims this to be a violation of Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 1,500 was reduced to EUR 900 due to immediate payment and admission of guilt

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Vodafone España, S.A.U.. with EUR 100,000. A data subject had complained against the telecommunications company to the DPA. According to the complainant, he had received advertising calls from a company on behalf of Vodafone España, S.A.U., although the data subject was registered in the Robinson exclusion list. According to Vodafone’s commissioned processor, the advertising call had occurred only because of an error in the call number filtering system. During its investigation, the AEPD discovered that Vodafone Espana had failed to establish adequate measures to prevent advertising calls made to numbers on the Robinson list. In this case, Vodafone was not even aware that the specific number of the data subject was on the Robinson list. This meant that it wasn’t blocked for the commissioned company.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Alava Norte, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had three 360° video surveillance cameras installed on the facade of one of its owned buildings to secure the facility. These cameras captured parts of the public space unlawfully. The AEPD concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization because extensive video surveillance wasn’t necessary to fulfill the purpose of the processing (security the facility).

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Desolasol Restauración S.L. with EUR 6,000. The data subject had officially complained to the restaurant because he was unable to communicate at the table due to the volume of the music inside the restaurant. A copy of the form remained with the data controller. Because of an error by a restaurant employee, the copies of the form were given to other guests of the restaurant who had been present during the incident.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) fined a private individual with EUR 2,000 for the unauthorized use of various video surveillance cameras. These cameras recorded parts of public space without a legitimate reason. The data subject also published the content of the recordings online.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Avalos Consultores, S.L with EUR 4,000. The data subject had been a client of the data controller. She filed a complaint with the AEPD because the data controller had transferred all her personal data to the agency Torrent Asesores Nga, S.L. without obtaining her consent first.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Croatian IT company offers IT services to companies like banks, mobile operators, and state-run institutions in Croatia, and foreign companies (USA, Great Britain, the Netherlands, etc.), acting as a data processor in relation to personal data. The data controller in question, a telecommunications company using the services of the IT provider, told the DPA and its users of a potential breach of personal data committed by the IT provider. This was a security breach that led to unauthorized access and the processing of multiple sets of personal data (28,085 data subjects) by hackers. The security breach happened because the IT provider failed to take the adequate security measures that would protect the personal information from being stolen, thus failing to consider the existing risks. The data controller, as a data processor, would have been forced to take adequate technical and security measures in a way that ensured the consistent anonymity of the personal data, including the regular testing, evaluation and the analysis of how effective anti-hacking responses would be, on the off-chance an attack did happen. During its security assessments, the data controller should have taken into consideration specific security risks related to the personal data of the 28,085 data subjects. Because of this failure to implement the adequate security measures, the Croatian DPA imposed an administrative fine on the IT provider. We don’t know the amount of the fine at this moment. However, when implementing the fine, the DPA considered the nature of the IT provider’s business activity, whose role should have been support other companies through informed guidelines, offering solutions regarding the implementation of web applications, and how to design and introduce adequate technical and security measures.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art 27 (1) of the National Implementation Law
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The DPA had conducted an unannounced direct supervision of an insurance company with its headquarters in Zagreb. When inspecting its business facility that had to carry out technical inspections, vehicle registrations, and to contract insurance services, the DPA found out that the business facility and its surroundings were under video surveillance. However, the Croatian DPA concluded that the insurance company did not provide any notice of such surveillance, and this is a breach of Art 27 (1) of the Law on the Implementation of GDPR. The Law states that data controllers have the obligation to indicate that the object of its activity and its perimeter or surroundings are under video surveillance. Moreover, the company should post a notice of this surveillance that is visible upon entering the surveilled perimeter, and this notice should contain all the necessary information. Due to this security breach breach, the DPA imposed an administrative fine on the insurance company.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Vejle Municipality with EUR 27,000. The Danish DPA had investigated the municipality after it had previously reported a security breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The municipal dental care service was sending automated welcome letters to parents regarding the treatment of their children at the dental office. These welcome letters contained the contact details of both parents. During this process, the municipality failed to check whether making the information of one parent known to the other was allowed, or whether they had permission to do this. In many cases, one parent received the residence address of the other parent, even though the other parent had address and name protection. The DPA concluded this as a failure of the municipality to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure adequate data protection.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Nordbornholms Byggeforretning Aps with EUR 53,800. Back in 2018, the DPA was contacted by a data subject who complained that his former employer, the aforementioned Nordbornholms Byggeforretning ApS, had unlawfully disclosed personal information about him to the company’s customers. The data controller had sent emails to two company customers, in which it informed them that the former employee had committed crimes during his time working of the company, to which he had freely admitted. The data controller then went on to describe the crimes in detail. According to the Dannish DPA, the data controller in this case, had a legitimate interest in not withholding information about the former employee’s crimes to its customers. It was within its rights to inform its customers that, due to these crimes, the former employee would not continue working for the company and could not see to the customers’ needs. However, there was no need to go into details about the nature of the crime, and the DPA concluded this was an unlawful act.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Medicals Nordic I/S with EUR 80,700. Back in January 2021, the DPA as made aware that Medicals Nordic had been using WhatsApp messages to transmit confidential information and health data about citizens that were tested in the test centers of the company. The company had summoned to the WhatsApp group all employees working in a specific testing center. The members of these WhatsApp groups received all kinds of messages sent by other employees in the test center groups. All employees shared confidential information about tested citizens to the data controller’s central administration through those WhatsApp groups. However, this also meant that even employees who had no relation to the testing centers, still got access to the personal information of the citizens, which included health data, personal identity numbers, and inter alia.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (1), (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the magazine publisher with EUR 8,500. The DPA received four different complaints against the data controller because of unsolicited telephone advertising. The data controller had assumedly done direct marketing with an automated calling system, but without obtaining valid consent from the data subjects who received the marketing calls. More specifically, the data controller had obtained a form of consent for such direct marketing when any customer subscribed to the online magazine on its website. The subscriber was then required to accept the given terms of the subscription and contract, which also included a consent to direct marketing. But this is where the problem occurs. If the customer did not give his consent to the direct marketing, then he could also not subscribe to the magazine. The DPA claimed that the data controller requested and obtained consent in a way that isn’t compliant with the GDPR. Clearly, the data controller had not specifically requested consent for direct marketing, but rather got an apparent consent with a subscription and other contract terms. This form of consent does not constitute a valid form of consent for the purpose of direct marketing. Furthermore, the customers could not exercise their right to object to direct marketing, since the marketing was carried out by an automated system that could not answer specific queries of the customers. Lastly, the magazine publisher had commissioned an advertising call center to carry out this direct marketing, concluding a contract in this sense.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés, Art. L. 34-5 CPCE
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined BRICO PRIVE with EUR 500,000. The French DPA conducted three separate investigations at BRICO PRIVÉ between 2018 and 2021, and found several deficiencies in the processing of personal data of customers and prospects. In one case, the data controller failed to comply with the data retention periods that it had established. Therefore, the data controller had unlawfully retained the personal data of more than 16,000 customers because they hadn’t placed an order in the last 5 years. The same happened to approximately 130,000 customers who had not logged into the company’s accounts in the last 5 years. Furthermore, the data controller violated its information obligations under Art. 13 GDPR. It also failed to fulfill its obligations to comply with the deletion requests received by the customers. The CNIL also discovered that the data controller failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure information security. In one case, the data controller did not implement the use of a secure password when customers created an account on the company website, or when employees accessed the customer relationship management software. The fine is composed proportionately of EUR 300,000 for violations of Art. 5(1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR and Art. 32 GDPR and EUR 200,000 for violations of Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés and Art. L. 34-5 CPCE.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PURPLE SEA MΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΙΚΕ with EUR 15,000 due to having illegally installed and operated a video surveillance system. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system in its office premises without first informing its employees about it. As such, the company violated the principles of legality, fairness, transparency, purpose limitation and accountability.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA (also known as Persónuvernd) has fined Huppuis ehf with EUR 34,000. A former employee had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data. Apparently, the data controller had installed a video surveillance system that the employee did not agree with. During employee shifts, the employees wore clothing provided by the data controller. However, the room in which they had to change was a storage room that also contained large quantities of cleaning materials. This storage room was too small to allow employees (mostly minors) to change, so they changed in a general employee area (which was filmed by the video surveillance system). The data controller stated that the video surveillance system was installed for security purposes. The DPA concluded that the data controller had a legitimate interest in the video surveillance, but that it would have to take into consideration the interests of the mostly underaged employees, as well. The data controller should have tried to implement less restrictive and invasive measures. Additionally, the DPA underlined that the information provided on video surveillance was insufficient in both the employee and customer service areas. In determining the amount of the fine, the DPA concluded that it was an aggravating factor that most of the employees were minors.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Iren Mercato S.p.A. with EUR 2,856,169 for failing to verify that it had obtained consent for all transfers of data of recipients of promotional activities. Many data subjects filed complaints with the DPA against the data controller because they had received unsolicited advertising messages that they had never consented to. During its investigation against the data controller, the DPA discovered that the personal data the controller had processed for its telemarketing activities was acquire from external sources and not gathered personally. The data controller also did not check whether the addressees had given their consent for this transfer of data, for the purpose of advertising. The personal data received by Iren Mercato was from one company, who had received it from two other companies in the same way. The latter companies did indeed obtain consent from the potential customers for telemarketing purposes, but they had not given their consent for the customer data transfer to other companies. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the given consent of customers to a company for promotional activities did not automatically extend to other companies through a transfer of personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) a), b), c), f), g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple types of violations
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Foodinho s.r.l., an Italian food delivery service, with EUR 2,600,000. Garante mainly investigated the company’s drivers. During the investigation, the Italian DPA discovered very serious violations of applicable data protection regulations. Therefore, the Italian DPA identified a couple of irregularities regarding the algorithms of the Foodinho system. More specifically, the DPA found that the data controller had failed to adequately inform its employees about how the system worked, and it also didn’t guarantee the accuracy of algorithms’ results used to evaluate drivers. Furthermore, the DPA also concluded that the data controller had violated the principles of memory limitation and data minimization. For instance, the company’s systems processed the drivers’ data to an extent that was thoroughly unnecessary and exceeded the purpose of the processing. In some cases, they stored the data significantly longer than was necessary. Additionally, the controller had failed to take the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure the secure data processing. The data controller also did not conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being clearly necessary because the company was dealing with a considerable amount of customer data. The Spanish DPA are conducting separate proceedings against the mother company, GlovoApp23.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined the municipality of Bolzano with EUR 84,000. One of the former employees of the municipality filed a complaint with the DPA against the municipality. More specifically, the former employee complained that the municipality had processed personal data regarding his internet use during working hours. He received, at a later date, a notice of initiation of disciplinary proceedings. The company had accused him of improperly using the company’s resources for private purposes, having accessed Facebook for more than 40 minutes per day, and staying on YouTube for more than 3 hours. During an investigation, the DPA found out that the municipality had been actively monitoring employees’ internet browsing for over a decade, using a certain system of control and filters. They would retain data monthly, and create special reports for their network security purposes. The system would also collect information that was completely irrelevant regarding the employees’ professional activities and, in many cases, concerned the private lives of the individuals in question. The Italian DPA found out that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization, lawfulness and purpose limitation. The data controller should have clearly taken less intrusive measures to prevent the private use of their Internet network. The Italian DPA pointed out that, despite the company needing to ensure employees don’t use the internet connection for their private use and only focus on their professional goals, this does not condone the total elimination of privacy of the data subjects at the workplace. Additionally, the data controller had failed to adequately inform employees about this collection of Internet history, thus violating its obligations under Article 13 of the GDPR. Furthermore, the DPA investigation identified other violations in the processing of data regarding employees’ requests for extraordinary medical examinations, which had been made using special forms. The form offered by the data controller would be checked and assessed by the head of the organizational unit, and these circumstances led to the unlawful processing of the health data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined a dentist with EUR 20,000. One of his data subjects complained to the DPA against the dentist because he refused to treat him after the data subject had told him he had HIV in his medical history form. Apparently, in the dentist’s clinic, patients would always fill out these forms with their medical history before receiving any medical treatments. These forms contained specific information about any previous or existing infectious diseases like hepatitis, tuberculosis, or HIV. The Italian DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principles of legality. While it was legitimate for the dentist to ask for such information in order to better plan medical treatment, it still wasn’t allowed nor permissible to collect such information and then refuse treatment to the patient.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 35 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Lithuanian DPA (also known as VDAI) fined UAB VS FITNESS with EUR 20,000. After being notified by an individual who said that a certain sports club owned by the data controller required clients to scan their fingerprints, the DPA started an investigation. The DPA’s review underlined that the consent provided by the customers to have their fingerprint scanned was not voluntary since were no other identification measures in place. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller also illegally processed its employees’ fingerprints. The data controller also failed to explain the purpose and legal basis used to justify the data processing of the employees’ biometric data. The data controller also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment, failing to offer evidence for the necessity and proportionality of the processing of the employees’ fingerprints. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to comply with its information obligations pursuant to Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined BRAbank ASA with EUR 39,700. The data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA on September 6th, 2019. On the controller’s website, some customers could view data of other customers on the “My Page” section. These data sets included credit terms and residential address information of other customers. The “My Page” section had been used previously for 500 customers, to offer an overview of loans they had taken out with the data controller. Based on its investigations, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to comply with the GDPR’s requirements for risk assessments as well as taking the appropriate technical measures regarding the launch of the customer portal. According to the DPA’s assessment, the security breach would have been preventable if the data controller had previously conducted a risk assessment and review as required by law.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined a company with EUR 14,800. Apparently, a former employee filed a complaint with the DPA because the managing director of his former company had been logging into his email inbox daily over a period of six weeks even after the employee had left the company. All in all, the managing director had accessed the employee’s inbox for five months. The manager justified this data processing by way of business requirements, related to processing customer inquiries. However, the DPA soon discovered that the data controller had no legal basis to access the employee’s email account. It was unlawful. In addition, the DPA claimed that the data controller had even breached its information obligations under Art. 13 GDPR, namely its obligation to delete the contents of the data subject’s e-mail account under Art. 17 GDPR and its obligation to consider the complainant’s objection under Art. 21 GDPR.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (Datatilsynet) fined the municipality of Moss with EUR 49,200 for using inappropriate measures to secure personal data. Back in January, the municipality of Rygge was annexed to the municipality of Moss. Therefore, a couple of IT systems from both municipalities were combined in a single, encompassing system. Because of the inadequate security measures, one of the municipality’s health services suffered a data breach in one of its productive systems. This particular system processed personal and health data of ill people who lived in the municipality and used the respective health center. The system was also used for other services related to immunization programs and health checks and follow-ups for pregnant women. Approximately 2000 people were affected by this breach, and because of it, various errors appeared in the vaccine registration. So, this led to an increased risk of data subjects receiving the wrong vaccines. Not only this but their immunization data could have been misfiled in the national immunization registry because of the data breach. Moreover, the health programs for pregnant women also got an error related to the information about the week of pregnant and the motherțs drug use. Finally, health workers in a health service ward could access the patient information without ever needing a special type of access.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The data controller did not provide enough information as requested by the Polish DPA (UODO) during its investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (UODO) fined Funeda Sp z o.o. with EUR 4,900 because the company failed to provide sufficient information as requested by the DPA during its investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: Sopockie Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń ERGO Hestia S.A.
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller had previously sent an email with personal data of a customer to a wrong recipient. The leaked personal data included the name, postal address of the data subject, as well as insurance details. The data controller failed to inform the Polish DPA and the data subjects about the data breach in a timely manner within 72 hours.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Romanian DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Romanian DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company unlawfully used the personal data of a data subject without his consent to conclude contracts for electricity and gas supplies as well as a maintenance service.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Master Distancia S.A. with EUR 25,000. The data controller had included personal data of the data subject in a credit report register without having a sufficient legal basis. The data controller apparently justified this with alleged debts the data subject had with the controller. However, the truth was that both parties were still in arbitration. So, the data controller had no legal right to include the data subject’s data in the register. The original fine of EUR 25,000 was reduced to EUR 20,000 due to immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Radiotelevision del principado de Asturias with EUR 26,000. The fine consists of EUR 20,000 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 6,000 for a violation of Art. 12 GDPR. The fine was issued because the controller installed a video surveillance system of 14 video cameras and monitored the business premises. The data controller claimed that the cameras had been installed for the purpose of security of the surrounding premises. However, the cameras also captured the employees’ offices in a way that went beyond the original purpose of the surveillance system. For instance, one security camera captured a large part of the employees’ recreation room. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, the data controller hadn’t adequately informed the data subjects about the data processing via video surveillance, and thus violated its duty to inform. The fine was reduced to EUR 19,600 due to timely payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data controller failed to provide accurate information regarding the data collection, as per Art. 13 GDPR. The fine was reduced to EUR 1,200 due to immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EXPRESS WORLDWIDE SPAIN S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data subject had previously placed a private order with the data controller, but the company wrongfully entered the address of his workplace as the delivery address. So, he received the delivery correctly, yet the invoice arrived to the company where the data subject was employed and not to the data subject himself. Both the delivery bill and the invoice contained various personal data of the data subject. These were disclosed to his employer as a result of the mistake, warranting a fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Caixabank S.A. with EUR 50,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that he had received commercial advertising from the data controller, even though he had objected to the processing of his data for advertising purposes. What’s more, the data controller had said it would comply to his request.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Malagatrom S.L.U with EUR 4,000. The data subject had previously purchased a product from the data controller through the platform Amazon, which was out of order when it arrived. The data subject then decided to leave a negative review on the seller’s store page. However, the data controller published personal data of the customer, including his first and last name, address, contact of his wife, phone number, on the official store page on Amazon.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. Throughout 21 regions of Sweden, there exists a telephone hotline (1177) that offers advice on a number of health-related subjects. However, every individual region has its own health advice service which it operates internally or via contracted subcontractors. All three regions form a national network. Back in 2019, the mass media reported that a number of recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were made available on a web server without any password protection. Apparently, all calls to the 1177 number were sent to the company Inera, which maintained and developed the shared systems. All calls to the number 1177 from people living in the Sormland, Stockholm and the Värmland regions were taken by Inera to Medhelp AB, which answered the calls. In turn, Medhelp had contracted the Thai company Medicall Co Ltd. to take some of the calls on weekends and during the night. Both these companies had contracted technology company Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA fined Region Sörmland for collecting call data from data subjects without obtaining the consent of the data subjects first.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA fined Region Varmland for collecting call data from data subjects without obtaining the consent of the data subjects first.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing

allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security

There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA concluded that MedHelp had clearly failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the adequate level of security to protect the data subjects’ personal data, as well as prevent unauthorized people from accessing it. Moreover, MedHelp AB did not inform its callers that it would process their personal data, as per Art. 13 GDPR. Finally, the DPA further claimed that MedHelp AB’s outsourcing of personal data of the callers to Medicall was a clear breach of the legality principle as outlined in the GDPR. That’s because Medicall isn’t covered by the Swedish health legislation, and is not subject to confidentiality obligation existent in the Swedish healthcare sector.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. Throughout 21 regions of Sweden, there exists a telephone hotline (1177) that offers advice on a number of health-related subjects. However, every individual region has its own health advice service which it operates internally or via contracted subcontractors. All three regions form a national network. Back in 2019, the mass media reported that a number of recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were made available on a web server without any password protection. Apparently, all calls to the 1177 number were sent to the company Inera, which maintained and developed the shared systems. All calls to the number 1177 from people living in the Sormland, Stockholm and the Värmland regions were taken by Inera to Medhelp AB, which answered the calls. In turn, Medhelp had contracted the Thai company Medicall Co Ltd. to take some of the calls on weekends and during the night. Both these companies had contracted technology company Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA discovered that Voice Integrate did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper protection of the personal data of the callers.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.controller: Directorate of the Ostra Skaraborg Rescure Service
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Directorate of the Ostra Skaraborg Rescure Service with EUR 34,800. The DPA had received specific information that a couple fire stations in Östra Skaraborg were operating surveillance cameras that captured areas where firefighters were changing during an emergency, and in that situation, the DPA it requested a review of the camera surveillance. The video surveillance was taking place 24/7, although the data controller itself claimed that the video surveillance wasn’t needed in cases of non-emergency. The DPA stated that the 24/7 monitoring was unlawful and went beyond the purpose of the surveillance, but also notes that the controller had weighty reasons for the camera surveillance. However, the camera surveillance should be limited to emergency cases only. The fine is composed proportionally of EUR 29,800 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for a violation of Art. 32 (1), (4) GDPR.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Storstockholms Lokaltrafik (Stockholm Local Transport Company) with EUR 1,600,000. The data controller had equipped its ticket inspectors with body-worn cameras. They had to prevent threatening situations, document any dangerous incidents, and fine people who traveled without valid tickets on the public transportation in Stockholm. The ticket inspectors had to keep the camera on during their shift, and were able to capture all passengers who passed the inspector. Because a couple hundred thousand people use the public transportation daily, this was a major incident of potential data leakage because of the inspectors’ body cam footage that captured all these people. While the DPA understands how the body-worn surveillance system technology could prevent threatening situations, the pre-recording time should still be reduced to 15 seconds at best. Any longer than that and the recording becomes redundant and goes above the purpose of the body cam footage. The DPA also discovered that the audio recordings weren’t used to identify the individuals with no valid tickets. So, the DPA stated that capturing the audio recordings was a violation of the principles of transparency, data minimization, and legality. The DPA also firmly criticized the data controller for failing to provide adequate information about the camera surveillance, including the fact that both sounds and images were recorded.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined UWV (the Dutch employee insurance service provider – ‘Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen) with EUR 450,000. The UWV had improperly secured the group messages of the ‘My Workbook’ online environment. This is a personal environment on the UWV website where those seeking a job can contact with the UWV. Therefore, there were multiple data breaches of personal information, including health information, for a total of more than 15,000 individuals.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The ICO has fined the transgender charity Mermaids with EUR 29,000 for using inadequate methods to secure the personal data of its users, in a breach of Art. 5 (1) f) UK GPDR and Art. 32 (1), (2) UK GDPR. The ICO conducted an investigation after it received a report of a data breach related to an internal email group. The ICO discovered that the group had insufficient security countermeasures, resulting in about 780 pages of confidential emails being made public online for three years. This led to an online leakage of personal information like names and email addresses, of about 550 people. The ICO states that Mermaids could have encrypted the access to its email group, and it could have used pseudonymization or encryption methods to offer additional protection for the personal data. Organizations like Mermaids, who are responsible for personal data of thousands of people, are obliged to ensure the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of that personal data.

allItems.name: Liechtenstein
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: There was an unlawful operation of a video surveillance system. No furthrr data is available.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,900. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent unauthorized entry by random individuals. However, the surveillance cameras had captured parts of the public space without a solid or justified reason. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization under Article 5 (1) c) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also finds that the data controller stored the recordings longer than was legally permitted and had thus violated Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 2,400. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent unauthorized entry by random individuals.
