Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Midtjylland Region had failed to take adequate security measures to store the personal data. Moreover, the region had further failed to establish enough guidelines for access restrictions when creating the security key cards, and had also failed to conduct the necessary periodic testing, assessment, and evaluation of the security measures it had taken. In assessing the question of whether a fine should be imposed, the Danish DPA took into account, as an aggravating factor, that the region processed large amounts of sensitive data, such as health data.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with EUR 1,400. Vodafone had previously sent marketing SMS, emails, and made telephone calls without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. Despite several complaints of the data subjects, Vodafone continued sending SMS messages, emails, and making calls to the data subjects. In one case, a former customer had contacted Vodafone a total of seven times, asking not to receive any more advertising calls on his cell phone. Despite his request, he continued to receive advertising calls. In another case, a customer had received an advertising call on his mobile phone number and told Vodafone that he did not want to receive more advertising calls. Despite this complaint, Vodafone made twelve more marketing calls to his cell phone. Another data subject filled out a form where he stated that he wanted Vodafone to refrain from making advertising calls to his cell phone. However, the employee who processed his request did not register the customer’s marketing preferences. So, the customer subsequently received fourteen more unsolicited commercial messages – seven emails and seven text messages.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Region of Lombardy with EUR 200,000. The region had previously published on its website the personal data of more than 100,000 students who had applied for state scholarships or financial grants to buy technical equipment, textbooks, and teaching materials. During the preliminary audit of Garante, one could view and download the full list of approved and funded applications, as well as the lists of state scholarship recipients, and the list containing ineligible applications on the official website of the region. These lists contained personal data that could identify each individual, including the names, IDs, grades, names and codes of the school, and the application number. The DPA concluded that the personal data of applications applying for these economic benefits should be protected at all times through special ways in order to prevent and social and economic problems.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Roma Capitale with EUR. The DPA had previously launched an investigation after an individual had complained to the authority about the newest parking meters installed in the city in 2018. In fact, the company who managed the parking lots and who was contracted by the city, Atac s.p.a., had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by another company called Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then pooled and managed through a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. The DPA investigation found some irregularities with this process. The city of Rome, as the data controller, had failed to provid information on the processing of the drivers’ data, failed to designate the company Atac as its data processor, and has also failed to provide the necessary instructions to process the data collected. Also, the subcontractor that the city had hired did not receive any formal instructions on how to proceed with the data processing. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits. When calculating the fine for this unlawful data processing, the DPA took into account and aggravating factor, that of the large amount of personal data processed (from June 2018 to November 2019, the system established by Atac had already finished collecting the data of approximately 8,600,000 stops. This could potentially affect all users of the paid parking service in the city area), as well as the sanctions already received for data protection violations, but also the helpful cooperation offered by the city officials and the companies to remedy some violations detected during the inspection.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Flowbird Italia s.r.l.  with EUR 30,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. During the investigation, Garante discovered that Flowbird Italia had not established a data processing register either.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Atac s.p.a.  with EUR 400,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: President of the Zgierz District Court
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the president of the Zgierz District Court with EUR 2,200. The president had previously reported a data breach that involved the loss of an unencrypted USB stick by a probation officer. The stick was used to store the data of about 400 persons under probation supervision. The lost and unencrypted data carrier has been found yet, so this means that unauthorized persons could still be able to access the personal data it contained. The president had wrongfully assumed that the duty to secure the data wasn’t his but the respective probation officers’ who were using this data stick. However, the DPA found that the president himself should have secured the USB sticks.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Actamedica SRL with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously informed a data subject about the misplacement of her biological samples as well as a sum of money sent via a courier service. When the data subject inquired on the specific personal data that had been discloses during this data breach, and whether the company had informed the ANSPDCP, the data controller provided only the contact details of its lawyer as well as the email address of the courier service that the data subject could complain to. The ANSPDCP discovered a data breach regarding the controller’s obligation to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk to data subjects, as well as a breach of the controller’s obligation to notify the ANSPDCP of the data breach.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an employer with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system without properly informing employees.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company owner with EUR 2,000. A private individual had applied for a job at the data controller’s company and sent the controller his CV through WhatsApp. From that point on, the data subject was not informed about the processing of his personal or his data subject rights. The AEPD considered this to be a violation of Art. 13 of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an agency with EUR 1,800. The data controller had improperly disposed of documents containing personal data of its clients in the garbage. The AEPD claimed this to be a total lack of security and data protection countermeasures as outlined by Art. 32 GDPR, which states that ‘the controller and processor shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure an adequate level of security.’ The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, S.A with EUR 120,000. This happened because a private individual had complained to the AEPD about a lack of authentication. More specifically, when providing information via telephone, the bank would only request the ID number as sufficient identification. Theoretically, this means that anyone could call the bank, provide an ID number and impersonate the owner of the ID number to access private information about that person. No further authentication was needed. The DPA concluded this was a failure to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk posed to the data subjects. The original fine of EUR 200,000 was reduced to EUR 120,000 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an owners’ association with EUR 1,000. The data controller had illegally installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex that recorded, among others, public areas like the swimming pool, and of the public space. Additionally, surveillance cameras had been installed in the rooms where the guards of the residential complex changed their clothing, without any notice being given. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined FurnishYourSpace S.L. with EUR 6,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from the Berlin DPA through the EU Internal Market Information System regarding the inadequate design of the data controller’s privacy notice. More specifically, both the contact data and the identity of the data controller were included in the privacy notice, but they were provided under false pretenses. Additionally, the data controller did not clarify the goals of the data processing. Moreover, he provided no legal basis for the processing and retention of the personal data, and no information was offered regarding the data subjects’ rightto object. Also, the privacy notice was complicated, with the wording containing grammatical errors and making use of uncommon and needlessly complex terminology. Finally, the privacy notice also required a tax identification number in order to issue a simplified invoice, i.e., an invoice that did not exceed the amount of EUR 3,000. The AEPD stated that this was a violation of the principle of legality. The fine is composed as follows: EUR 3,000 for a breach of Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR; EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 (4) GDPR; and EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 21 LSSI
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Automecanica Jerez, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had previously sent several commercial e-mails to a large number of people without obtaining their consent. By doing so, the data controller did not anonymize the personal data of the recipients, such as the surname, first name and email address. This allowed the other recipients to view the data of other recipients, as well. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of Article 5 (1) f) GDPR and Article 32 GDPR, since the controller had ultimately failed to implement technical and organizational measures that would ensure a sufficient level of security in the processing of personal data. Furthermorem the AEPD found a breach of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club APOEL FC with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined AC Omonia and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club AC Omonia with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA fined the Hellenic Technical Enterprise Ltd. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had designed the ticket sales system for the two soccer clubs, APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC for the same violations.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Favrskov Municipality with EUR 10,000. Back on the 19th of August, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Favrskov Municipality regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. The notification claimed that, during a break-in at the municipality’s premises, a laptop had been stolen that contained a program which provided overviews of the municipality’s care facilities and information about the names and personal identity numbers of more than 100 individuals with mental or physical disabilities. The specific computer hard drive was unencrypted and the program, which contained sensitive and private personal data, wasn’t equipped with any security measures. While investigating the case, the DPA discovered that the Favrskov Municipality had failed to ensure the encryption of the laptops’ hard drives for a long time before August 12, 2020, which resulted in an inadequate level of security. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of protection commensurate with the risk.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA fined the Syddanmark Region with EUR 67,200 on. On March 9, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Syddanmark Region regarding a personal data breach pertaining to Art. 33 GDPR. The Syddanmark Region claims that, since May 2011, a PowerPoint presentation made at Odense University Hospital for training purposes and containing personal data (ID card number details and health information of 3,915 patients, was made public on the official website of the region. The region had been using a screening tool to analyze for inadvertent posting of any personal identity numbers on its website. But this tool couldn’t scan any data in PowerPoint presentations. As such, the DPA discovered that the region had failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the adequate level of protection appropriate to the risk at hand. When assessing the necessity of a fine, the DPA also considered that aggravating factor of the region’s processing of large amounts of personal data, which also included health data.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined Société nouvelle de l’annuaire français (SNAF) with EUR 3,000. SNAF operates the website annuairefrancais.fr, which lists French companies based on data published by the French Statistical Office. Between 2018 and 2019, the CNIL received a total of sixteen complaints that indicated problems when requesting the erasure and rectification of personal data. As a response, the CNIL promptly requested that SNAF complies with the requests within two months, which SNAF failed to do. Henceforth, the CNIL imposed the fine on SNAF, mainly for failing to comply with the rights of rectification and erasure of the data subjects, as well as for the lack of cooperation with the CNIL.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItems.summary: The DPA from Hamburg has fined Vattenfal Europe Sales GmbH with EUR 900,000. The fine relates to data matching, which the data controller had carried out between August 2018 and December 2019 in the course of contract inquiries for special contracts. These special contracts were issued in order to attract potential new customers, and also came with bonus payments for these customers. The data controller made a comparison between contracts concluded by existing customers and potential customers who had previously submitted inquiries for special contracts. The data controller would reject the application for special contract if it was revealed that the application had previously signed a contract with the data controller then switched to another supplier. This was done to avoid any “bonus shopping”, which companies find unprofitable. However, the data controller failed to inform the customers about the data processing involving these comparisons. The DPA then concluded that the data controller had violated the company’s transparency policies and information obligations, since over 500,000 people had been affected in this data breach.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Dixons South East Europe ΑΕΒΕ-ΚΩΤΣΟΒΟΛΟΣ with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller after it failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the National Bank of Greence with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the bank and a company after the data controllers failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: NOW DOCTOR – Εταιρία Παροχής Ηλεκτρονικών Υπηρεσιών Αναζήτησης και Προβολής Ιατρών Ε.Π.Ε.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the operator of the nowdoctor.gr medical platform that enables the online booking of medical appointments. A doctor had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. At the same time, she had also repeatedly stated that she didn’t wish to work with the data controller, while requesting the deletion of her data on the platform. The data controller failed to comply with the request of the data subject on the spot. Instead, the data deletion took place 18 months later, after the DPA had requested to data controller to proceed with the deletion. The DPA concluded that this was a clear breach of the data controller’s accountability obligations. It was further found that the data controller had been storing the data of the data subject for longer that was necessary for the intended processing purposes (providing online display services). These display services would stop existing at the moment the data subject used her right to stop working with the data controller. Additionally, the DPA found out that the data controller failed to facilitate the data subject’s access to her rights as per Art. 12 GDPR. Finally, while the data controller provided a public email address on its website through which the data subject could maintain communication, the controller was understaffed and there was no one to process this communication.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Greek DPA fined the Rhodes Municipal Transport Company with a fine of EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the transport company filed a complaint against it with the DPA. At that time, the employee was engaged in a legal dispute with the transport company after the employer had reported him for alleged embezzlement. In this context, the employee had requested from the employer a copy of the video recordings taken by the bus’s video surveillance system during the data that the alleged embezzlement occurred. This video recording was necessary for this defense. However, the data controller failed to respond to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a clear violation of the data subject’s right to information, as per Art. 12 (3) GDPR and Art. 15 GDPR. Moreover, the data controller provided the former employee with a certificate of his former employment. Among others, the certificate contained the duration and type of the employment, as well as a notice of dismissal on charges of criminal offenses. This was a violation of the principle of proportionality as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, according to the GDPR. The issued fine consists of EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for violating Art. 12 (3) and Art. 15 GDPR.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with a fine of EUR 1,400. Apparently, Vodafone had repeatedly sent marketing emails and SMS messages, as well as telephone calls to data subjects without obtaining their consent. Despite the data subjects’ attempts to stop this, the company kept sending them unsolicited marketing. At one time, a former customer of the company contacted Vodafone seven times and repeatedly requested them to stop with the marketing material. However, the company did not stop sending him marketing emails and SMS messages. Another customer had been receiving advertising calls on his telephone number, at which point he informed Vodafone during such a call that he did not want to receive further advertising calls. Against this request, the company made another twelve calls to his phone number. Yet another data subject filed outa form where he clearly stated that he did not want to receive more marketing calls from Vodafone. Despite this, the company employees that had processed this request failed to register the marketing preferences of the customer. This resulted in the customer receiving seven other emails and seven text messages.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Ferde AS, which is a Norwegian toll company, with EUR 496,000. After receiving a report from NRK, state-owned broadcasting company, the Norwegian DPA started investigating Ferde AS, discovering that the company had been transferring information on passages in various toll rings to a data processor in China. In this context, the DPA started a large-scale investigation into the company, with the purpose of finding out whether the company had implemented measures and routines that could ensure the information security of this information transfer to China. It should be noted that Ferde AS was also responsible for registering passages at toll booths through a chip in the car. If a car had no chip or if the chip wasn’t properly registered, a photo of the car’s license plate would be taken. These images would then be sent to an automatic optical character recognition system that would digitally read the license plate. If the image wasn’t clear enough, it would go through manual processing. Ferde AS had contracted Unitel Bratseth Services (UBS) to do this job. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the subcontractor also had employees in China. Moreover, Ferde AS had violated many obligations under the GDPR for 1-2 years. In on instance, Ferde failed to conduct a risk management assessment before the processing of personal data and the processing of manual images. This risk assessment was necessary to assess any underlying risks associated with the data transfer, and to also determine whether further security measures should be taken. Additionally, the DPA discovered that Ferde did not enter an official processor contract with UBS. Therefore, the transfer of personal data to China occurred without a legal basis. When determining the value of the fine, the DPA also considered the large amount of the affected personal data as an aggravating factor. However, the implicated data subjects received no material or immaterial damage, which had a mitigating effect on this whole affair.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GESTIONES AUTO LOW COST S.L. with EUR 1,000 because the company’s website did not contain a privacy policy.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hairdressing salon with EUR 1,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a website operator with EUR 9,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller had publicly published his first and last name and a screenshot of his LinkedIn profile on his website. The data controller hadn’t previously obtained the consent of the data subject for this, and it also did not inform the data subject about the imminent data processing. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 6 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000 on charges of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that multiple telephone lines had been registered in his name, despite never signing any contract with the company for these telephone lines. These contracts had been concluded by fraudsters on behalf of the data subject. However, Vodafone never verified the data subject’s personal data when entering it into its information systems. They did not check whether the contracts are lawful and if they’d actually been concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000 on charges of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that multiple telephone lines had been registered in his name, despite never signing any contract with the company for these telephone lines. These contracts had been concluded by fraudsters on behalf of the data subject. However, Vodafone never verified the data subject’s personal data when entering it into its information systems. They did not check whether the contracts are lawful and if they’d actually been concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) imposed a fine on Vodafone España, S.A.U. due to insufficient legal basis for data processing. The data subject stated that, unauthorized third parties had gained access to her Vodafone account and had booked the Vodafone Unlimited package in her name, as well as purchased an iPhone 11 Pro Max in installments. The DPA notes that the controller had not adequately verified whether the contracts had been lawfully and actually concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 due to the voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPNA (AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000 because of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that unauthorized third parties hijacked his Vodafone account and signed three mobile phone contracts in his name. The DPA also found out that Vodafone did not verify whether these contracts were lawful and whether the data subject had actually concluded them. In this context, the contracts weren’t even signed and the information inputted by the fraudsters (date of birth, address) weren’t those of the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined Vodafone España, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000 for insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that Vodafone had requested that he pay for three telephone lines. During the call, the data subject explained that he had not ordered or authorized those telephone lines, and he requested that they sent the invoices to him. The data subject said that the telephone and account numbers on the invoices weren’t his. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the contracts had been concluded by an unauthorized third party. Additionally, the DPA also found that Vodafone failed to verify the identity of the third party who had concluded the contracts, and also failed to take security measures to prevent these incidents from occurring. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Frigorifica Botana S.L. with EUR 4,000. The company’s main activity is freezing, processing, and storing seafood. A data subject issued a complaint with the AEPD against the data controller, which prompted the DPA to begin investigations. Apparently, the data controller had installed an audio and video surveillance system that captured certain parts of the conference room. The DPA stated that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by processing this data without having a legal basis. It also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined CEDICO, CENTRO DE DIAGNOSTICO POR LA IMAGEN, S.L. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller. He had previously gone to get an MRI scan of his knee because of a work-related accident. He had also contacted his insurance company for a sick leave. After the insurance company contacted the data controller, the latter transmitted the medical records of the data subject to the insurance company. But by doing so, the data controller offered the insurer a report of another MRI scan of the knew that the data subject had received for an event outside of work. While assessing the need for a sick leave, the insurer considered the MRI report in the medical records outside working hours, attributing the data subject’s incapacity to work to this event. So, they granted no sic leave to the data subject. The DPA considered that the data controller unlawfully disclosed the MRI report to the insurer, violating the principle of integrity and confidentiality. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was briefly reduced to EUR 18,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 3,000. The company in question had requested personal data from customers for appointment bookings. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: No data processing agreement has been concluded with the company whose servers contained the resources of the Public Information Bulletin (BIP) of the Municipal Office in Aleksandrów Kujawski. For this reason, a fine of 40.000 PLN (9400 EUR) was imposed on the mayor of the city.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A controller was sanctioned because he had unlawfully processed the personal data (CNP), and images of employees obtained through the surveillance system. The disclosure of the CNP in a report for the ISCIR training in 2018 wasn’t legal, as per Art.6 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had unlawfully processed the personal data despite the subject’s request to stop doing so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to cooperate with supervisory authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Iberdrola Clientes violated Article 13 of the GDPR when it showed a complete lack of cooperation with the AEPD. The latter had requested Iberdrola Clientes to provide the necessary information needed to add a person to the solvency list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Raiffeisen Bank Romania did not observe the necessary security measures required by the GDPR when it assessed the scores of individuals on the WhatsApp platform. The personal data was exchanged via WhatsApp.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company sent personal information through the WhatsApp platform to Raiffeisen Bank in order to facilitate the assessment of personal scores. The results were returned on the same platform.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Despite the clear refusal of telemarketing calls by the customers, the company proceeded to ignore this because of technical errors.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Vueling Airlines made it impossible for users to access their website without accepting the cookies. Therefore, one couldn’t browse the website unless they accepted the cookies. The AEPD sanctioned the company with 30.000 euros

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An operator utilized an unfilled checkbox through which users could request that they do not receive any emails from the company. Since they couldn’t do that, they continued receiving information via email.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company had retained the personal data of customers who had expressed their desire to discontinue receiving emails from the company. Eight customers complained to have received such emails, despite not having solicited them. Moreover, the company refused to share information with five subjects regarding their rights to withdraw consent in the processing of personal information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A merchant was found guilty of trying to create a customer card using an electronic identity card. In doing so, the merchant would have needed access to personal information on the electronic identity card, including photo and barcode. The fine was 10.000 euros.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Morele.net was sanctioned with a fine of PLN 2.8 million because it hadn’t ensured the proper security standards of customers’ data. As a consequence, more than 2.2 million people had their personal data accessed illegally.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined because it had refused to comply with the obligation of appointing a data protection officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Because of the inappropriate handling of personal data, more than 6 million individuals had their data hacked. This informational leak was a direct cause of the company’s security laxity.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Data leakage due to the inappropriate security and organizational measures of the company. Information related to more than 23.000 credits records belonging to more than 33.000 customers were made public. The data included names, ID numbers, biometric data, addresses, and copies of identity cards.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Latvia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The merchant had ignored a client’s demands to stop processing personal data, in particular, the phone number. The merchant had continued sending the subject advertising messages to the subject’s phone number.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 36 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A school attempted to introduce the use of facial recognition software to facilitate the attendance process of students. The school was ultimately fined because the means used to monitor attendance were disproportionate to the goal itself. Moreover, students and their parents couldn’t freely withdraw consent from being monitored to validate attendance. Furthermore, one case of processing activity presented elevated risks since it involved children dependent on the high-school board. Ultimately, the school didn’t observe Art. 35 of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A client had complained that AVOND COSMETICS hadn’t observed the law when it processed his personal data erroneously. His identity wasn’t properly verified, which led to the erroneous matching of that client with a register of claims. As a result, the client wasn’t able to work with his bank. Moreover, a third-party utilized the client’s personal data unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A soccer coach was fined for having covertly filmed female players while they were taking showers. This had taken place for many years.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 14 (1) c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully processed the employer’s data while creating the illusion that it acted under the legal basis of consent. Whereas, the company was using a different legal basis. This is a strict violation of the transparency principle. Moreover, the company violated the accountability principle when it failed to bring evidence related to the proper assessment of the employer’s data using the right legal bases.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had allowed for personal data belonging to clients (including copies of the driver’s license) to be publicized online. Apparently, unauthorized access was detected, and the fault lies with the inappropriate security measures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: In a cyber incident previously notified to the ICO on November 18, Marriott International unintentionally exposed the personal data of over 330 million guest records globally, out of which 30 million were residents of 31 countries in the European Economic Area. About seven million were residents of the UK. This cyber vulnerability is related to the data breach of the Starwood hotels group in 2014. Marriott bought Starwood in 2016, yet the data breach was only identified in 2018, when Marriott notified the ICO about it. During the investigation, the ICO found that Marriott had employed inadequate security check-ups on its systems after acquiring Starwood. Recently, the ICO decided to fine Marriott with £18.4 million (about EUR 20.4 million). When calculating this fine, the ICO took into consideration the company’s absence of prior violations of GDPR regulations, as well as the company’s full cooperation during the investigation, and personal initiative to notify the affected individuals regarding the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Back in July 2019, the ICO notified the British Airways that it would impose a fine of £183,39M for having infringed on several GDPR regulations, including a breach of Art. 32 GDPR. This fine was related to an incident notified in September 2018 by British Airways, involving the user traffic on the official website of the British Airways being diverted to a fraudulent website. This fraudulent website would harvest the customer details of all clients taken there. The personal data of more than 500,000 customers was harvested during the incident. During the ICO’s investigation, it was found that British Airways was mainly to blame for much of the compromised information, due to inadequate security measures, such as log-in, payment card, and travel booking details. The ICO eventually decided to lower the fine to £20 million (about EUR 22,046,000), taking into consideration the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the airline industry.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had not imposed sufficient security measures, which led to the unauthorized access of personal information related to the people who had made transactions with the website avocatoo.ro. This information includes names, emails, phone numbers, jobs, surnames, mailing addresses, and transaction details). Documents dated 10th of November 2018 – 1st of February 2019 had become publicly accessible to anyone. The company was sanctioned following a notification by the National Supervisory Authority when transaction details were publicly accessible via two links.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A printed checklist used to verify the attendance of breakfast customers (approx. 46 clients) was photographed by unauthorized people. As a result, the personal data of those clients was disclosed to the public. The operator working for the hotel was sanctioned because of insufficient security measures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company was issued a fine because it had failed to provide the necessary security and organization measures in two cases. Firstly, it failed in the appropriate determination of the data processing means. Secondly, it failed in the appropriate implementation of necessary security safeguards, which led to the public disclosure of the personal data of over 337.042 people.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controllers didn’t exert sufficient rigorousness when handling personal client data, which led to the displacement of a flash memory stick with personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: After a serious investigation, the DDPA surmised that the Hague Hospital failed to provide the appropriate security measures for possession of patient records. This investigation had started following several events when multiple staff hospital members had checked the personal data of a Dutch person. Measures were taken, and the hospital was warned – it would have to update its security measures by the 2nd of October 2019 or it would incur e penalty of 100.000 EUR every two weeks.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Complaints from the employees were received that they were unlawfully filmed in the workspace.  The company failed to observe the rules pertaining to the unlawful filming of employees all the time, and the necessity of providing information related to the data processing to the employees. The CNIL performed an audit in October 2018, and the company wasn’t observing the data protection laws. Therefore, fines were issued.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A fine was issued to the National Football League (LaLiga) because it had failed to inform users of the implications contained within the app it offered. This app remotely accessed the users’ microphones once every minute to check pubs screening football matches. The AEPD thinks that the users were not sufficiently informed of this. Moreover, the users did not have the adequate possibility to withdraw their consent, once given.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: After an inspection in 2018 when irregularities were noticed, the company IDdesign was fined. The company had overused the data of over 380.000 customers for a longer period of time than they were allowed to, as per the initial goals of the data processing. Moreover, the company had no clear deadlines regarding the deletion of personal data. The controller had also ignored the necessity of having a clear policy on the data deletion procedures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Several
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A mayor was fined for having misused people’s personal data during a political campaign.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined because of two reasons – the complete lack of security measures, and excessive data storage. Regarding the former reason, personal data, including health cards, IDs, divorce judgments, and account statements were available online with no authentication procedure. Moreover, the company breached the data storage deadline it had in place and kept clients’ data for more than it should have.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Organizer of SZIGET festival and VOLT festival
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing and information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The subjects had not been informed about the data processing, and the data controllers had not complied with the principle of purpose limitation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security and information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controllers had overextended his authority to collect unwarranted information about the clients. Moreover, a data breach took place from 09-10 July 2018, when payment data was made available on the internet. Moreover, the data controllers had not reported the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Not known
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Not available.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The police officer acted outside the boundaries of the law when he used the Central Traffic Information System to find out the personal data of the license plate of an unknown person. Moreover, he then proceeded with a SARS inquiry, gathering personal data of the injured parties (mobile and home phone numbers). The police officer then contacted the wounded party. These actions were done outside his lawful prerogatives, and it is an infringement of personal data. However, he acted not in trying to exercise official duties but to satisfy personal inquiries. Therefore, the police department is not to blame.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Not available.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The fine was issued on the following grounds: insufficient security measures established on the app launched by an Oslo school. This app allowed students and parents to contact teachers in real-time. However, unauthorized access was detected, and unknown people gained access to personal data related to students and school employees.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The sports association published personal data related to judges who had received judicial licenses online. Moreover, the exact addresses and PESEL numbers of these judges became public. As the sports association acted outside the law, fines were in order. However, there were mitigating circumstances in that the sports association immediately noticed its mistakes and attempted to remove the data from the public domain. Still, these attempts were ineffective, and a penalty was issued. The 585 judges had suffered no damage because of this, so the penalty was adjusted by the president of the Office of Competition and Consumer Protection.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Website affiliated with the Movimento 5 Stelle, an Italian political party, had a data breach in 2017. Rousseau, the data processor running these websites, had insufficient security measures in place. Garante, the Italian Data Protection Authority, issued a request to update these measures and the privacy information notice, for more transparency on the processing of data. The information issue was completed on time. However, Rousseau failed to adopt new security measures, and it was fined by Garante.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had no legal basis to process data in conformity with art 6.1.b, related to the claims.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The medical centers unlawfully processed personal data of the subject G.B. Software was used to generate the registration form for changing the GP, and it went ahead to the Regional Health Insurance Fund. After it arrived at another medical center, it was concluded that all parts had taken part in the unlawful processing of data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 (5) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The political party did not notify the NAIH about a data breach. Moreover, it didn’t document the data breach as per GDPR article 33.5. Therefore, the political party received a fine of HUF 11.000.000 (equivalent to 34.375 EUR). The hacker behind the breach had used a redirection attack on the official website of the political party and disclosed information about more than 6.000 people.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The municipality had employed insufficient security measures in protecting its computer systems. As a result, personal data related to more than 35.000 individuals became publicly accessible. In the case of a few schools, anyone could access information related to the staff, the pupils, and the employees of the school. Moreover, the municipality has received warnings about the weakness of its security measures before but chose not to do anything.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The private company was fined for having breached the information obligation in the case of personal data of several entrepreneurs. The data was taken from public sources (Central Electronic Register and Information on Economic Activity) and used for commercial purposes. In accordance with Art. 14(1) – (3) of the GDPR, the company was obligated to inform all the individuals concerned about the data processing. However, the company informed only those individuals for whom it had email addresses. For the rest, the high operational costs made them ignore the information obligation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The personal data administrator unlawfully processed personal data of subject D.D related to an Employment Contract, while the subject was imprisoned.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Portugal
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Not available

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A bank had retained the personal data of former customers in order to create a blacklist. Apparently, they wanted to prevent those customers from opening up new accounts at their bank because they were suspected of money laundering. While the bank wanted to hand-wave away this unlawful act by appealing to the German Banking Act, the Berlin Supervisory Authority found this to be illegal.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The fine was issued after the Mayor’s Office unlawfully disclosed personal information related to a whistleblower. The individual complained to the NAIH about his employer. Afterward, the company requested information about the complaint, and the Mayor’s Office “accidentally” released the name of the complainant. The individual was fired as a result.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Bulgarian Commission for Personal Data Protection (KZLD)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The complainant was unlawfully and unknowingly been registered for the prepaid services of a telecommunication service provider. The employees had used personal data illegally and without express consent from the subject. Moreover, the signature on the application was found to be incongruent and dissimilar to the subject’s own signature. The identity card number on the prepaid application was also fake.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Bulgarian Commission for Personal Data Protection (KZLD)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An employee requested access to his personal data from his employer. The request was partially completed and delayed without justification.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Malta
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Lands Authority had a data breach where 10 GB worth of personal data was publicly accessible on the internet. The data contained sensitive information about data subjects. The Data Protection Commissioner might issue a fine of 25.000 Euros for each of the violations (data breaches).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The bank erroneously sent the subject’s credit card data to another person via SMS. Despite the data subject’s request to erase the data, the bank continued to send SMS messages to that incorrect telephone number. The bank was fined about 0.00016% of the annual net revenue.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A private person sent several emails containing the email addresses of several subjects, and each subject could see other recipients of that email. In the person’s mailing list, more than 131 email addresses had been found. He was accused of ten such offenses.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company sold a card that was constantly tracked through GPS. The owner found this out and reported it since the company had no information related to this GPS tracking. The Czech Data Protection Authority decreed that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) of the GDPR, and issued a fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company did not process the data using the appropriate security measures required to prevent unlawful alteration or destruction of the data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 4 GDPR, Art. 5 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Several
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French NGO “La Quadrature du Net” and the Austrian organization “None Of Your Business” complained about the creation of a Google account related to the configuration of the Android system in a mobile phone. A fine of 50 million euros was issued because the following principles were not observed: the principle of transparency (Art. 5 GDPR), the sufficiency of information (Art.13 / 14 GDPR), and the presence of legal basis (Art. 6 GDPR).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Bulgarian Commission for Personal Data Protection (KZLD)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The bank unlawfully came into possession of personal data related to a student.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The employer complained that the former company where he/she worked for refused to delete personal information posted on Facebook. Even after the termination of the employment contract, the company did not delete the personal information of the former employee.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller could not provide access to personal information to a patient because the dossier could not be identified. The patient complained to the Commissioner about this, and the hospital was fined 5.000 Euros.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Kolibri Image Regina und Dirk Maass GbR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to collect sufficient data processing consent
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: This fine was apparently withdrawn. The case concerned the Kolibri Image who lodged a complaint that a service provider did not want to sign a processing agreement. Afterward, the Kolibri Image was fined because it didn’t have any processing agreement with the service provider. However, the company argued that the service provider was not a processor, and therefore the fine was unreasonable and unwarranted.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The betting place used a system of video surveillance illegally because it filmed the public space (the sidewalk). Private individuals are not allowed to do this on a large scale like in this case.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A hack revealed the personal data that included email addresses and passwords of around 330,000 users.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Portugal
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The hospital was found to create fake doctor profiles for the personnel to unlawfully access patient data. The management system found 985 registered doctors when the hospital only had 296 doctors.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: <b>Update:

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Two companies working in finances didn’t follow the procedure when disposing of personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: <b>Update:

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Vodafone Espana called the complainant to offer its services but the data subject refused. His personal data had been acquired by the company through his daughter. Despite his refusal, Vodafone Espana provided the services and demanded payment for them. Therefore, the company had unlawfully processed the complainant’s personal data without express consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with the right of consent
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company failed to observe Art.14 of the GDPR, which states that the data controller must inform the data subject of the processing of personal data. The DPA has stated that Bisnode has three months to notify a total of 6 million people of this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with the right of consent
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company sent marketing messages to over 2.5 million customers without their consent. The marketing message encouraged data subjects the “My EE” app to manage their accounts. Furthermore, the Company sent another batch of marketing messages to other customers afterward.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance (Data Breach)
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company shared personal driver details with other third-parties, including parking firms.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance (Data Breach)
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company experienced the data breach when it transferred the personal data of 18,610 customers to a partner organization. In doing so, the company allowed anyone to access the personal data because the “Anonymous Authentication” function was switched on. The data breach was active for two years.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with the right of consent
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Leave.EU subscriber emails contained marketing ads related to the GoSkippy services of the Eldon Insurance firm. The data subjects did not give their consent to this, hence the fine issued by the ICO.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: https://dataprivacy.foxrothschild.com/2019/01/articles/european-union/hessian-dpa-fines-shipping-company-for-missing-data-processing-agreement/
allItemsPriceGrouped.source: The data controller company lacked a data processing agreement with the Spanish service provider.
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller company lacked a data processing agreement with the Spanish service provider.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Gestion De Cobros Yo Cobro SL
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An online credit agency transferred an undue credit claim to a debt collecting agency, providing the agency with the subject’s email address. However, the debt collecting agency sent emails to the company where the subject worked. This institutional email was accessible by all employees of that company. The online credit agency had not provided these emails.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: ENDESA erroneously charged the claimant’s bank account, as the beneficiary of the energy supply company’s services was a third party. Upon request of the claimant that her data be deleted, ENDESA handled the data improperly and mistakenly sent it to the third party. Therefore, the AEPD considered that ENDESA had breached the confidentiality principle. It’s worth noting that the third party had been given a 2-year restraining order regarding the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The restaurant wanted to sanction an employee using images taken by another employee in the restaurant, to be used as evidence.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Slovakia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Improper information security measures in place.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller could not provide access to personal information to a patient because the dossier could not be identified. The patient complained to the Commissioner about this, and the hospital was fined 5.000 Euros.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The taxi company was discovered having over 9 million person records that it stored unlawfully. Because the company hadn’t deleted this personal data, the Danish Data Protection Authority issued a fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch employee insurance service provider – “Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen – UWV did not use multi-factor authentication for accessing the employer web portal. Health and safety services, as well as employers, were able to view and collect data from employees, data to which normally they should not have had access to.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Company did not have the appropriate organizational measures in place that would allow data subjects to withdraw their consent to the processing of personal data. Moreover, the data subjects also couldn’t easily request the deletion of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The gas company did not have the necessary technical measures in place to verify the identity of the subjects’ data. It was alleged by a third party that the company emailed their information to a third party in regards to a request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Postal advertisements and commercial offers were sent by Jocker Premium Invex to a registrant to a local census, even though the registrant did not consent to receive such advertisements and offers.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
