allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller was fined with EUR 20,000 for publishing in its newspapers photos of people taken into custody regarding a murder. The photos were showing the accused in handcuffs even though the data subjects had not given their consent. Even though some of the photos had the handcuffs pixelated, the faces of the accused were visible, which made their identification possible. The Italian DPA demanded that the data controller refrain from using these photos, yet the data controller refused, for which the DPA issued a fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One of the municipality’s former employees complained to the DPA that a document containing his personal data had been published on the website of the municipality. The document included information about the acceptance and confirmation of the voluntary termination of employment, and information about evaluations of his work, health, and the employment relationship at that time. Moreover, the data subject also mentioned that this information was mentioned in a newspaper article. In the article, the mayor had issued a statement where he said that the employee had asked for more flexible working hours, and that he had been absent from work during the winter holiday vacations because of an illness.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A former employee of the municipality complained to the DPA that a document containing her personal data, information about the employment and an excerpt from the termination letter, had been published on the official website of the municipality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), d) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA fined the Istituto Nazionale Previdenza Sociale with EUR 300,000. The Istituto had been tasked with anti-fraud investigations related to COVID-19 relief funds. A series of press reports appeared that raised suspicions with the institute’s data processing practices regarding the application review of politicians, and the Italian DPA formally investigated the INPS in August 2020. The DPA discovered several violations during the investigations. Apparently, the data controller had been collecting data related to tens of thousands of politicians from public sources, which it would crosscheck with data from the applicants. However, the data controller failed to ensure that should only be collected from those politicians who were eligible to receive these assistance funds. Because of this, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of transparency, fairness, and lawfulness as set out by the GDPR. Moreover, the data controller had infringed upon the principle of data minimization after it initiated reimbursement checks on individuals who had their applications rejected and who would never receive those reimbursements. Finally, the Istituto Nazionale Previdenza Sociale had not done an impact assessment regarding the rights and freedoms of the data subjects, nor had it assessed the risks of the data processing operation as sensitive as one on applications for social benefits.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GPDR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Fastweb S.p.A. was fined by the Italian DPA with EUR 4,500,000 when charged with aggressive telemarketing. After hundreds of users had submitted complaints to the Italian DPA, preliminary investigations were carried out, and they discovered that the data controller had been illegally processing the personal data of millions of users for the purpose of telemarketing. More specifically, some of the call centers working for the company Fastweb S.p.A. disregarded any data protection regulations. They would use phone numbers to make calls that were not registered in any Italian register for communication operators. The company had also received contact data for promotions from external partners, which the call centers processed without the consent of the data subjects. Moreover, the users also reported about being contacted by individuals who claimed they were from Fastweb and who tried to obtain the contractors’ identity documents through WhatsApp, most likely for spamming, phishing, and other such fraudulent purposes. One last breach involved the procedures for the “call me back” service, which made it impossible to freely give their informed consent or deactivate the service automatically.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Latvia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had illegally processed personal data by publishing documents containing said personal data on its official website. The Italian DPA also found out that the data controller made publicly available parts of the company’s register (which was supposed to be non-public), which contained personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 58 (2) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company IT sprendimai sekmei was fined with EUR 3,000 by the Lithuanian DPA (VDAI) regarding a quarantine app introduced in Lithuania with the COVID-19 pandemic in tow, in spring 2020. The data controller developed the app and offered it for use to the Lithuanian National Health Service. During the DPA investigations, it was discovered that when the app was functioning, the data of 677 individuals had been processed in varying degrees. The app had collected names, phone numbers, and the addresses of data subjects. Clearly, the data controller had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing. Moreover, the company also did not carry out any data protection impact assessment even though such an assessment was necessary due to the sensitive nature of the data being processed (health data among others). Finally, the DPA concluded that the company also provided incorrect and non-transparent information in the app’s privacy policy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 58 (2) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Nacionaliniam Visuomenes Sveikatos Centrui (NVSC) was fined with EUR 12,000 by the Lithuanian DPA (VDAI) regarding a quarantine app introduced in Lithuania with the COVID-19 pandemic in tow, in spring 2020. The app was created by IT sprendimai sekmei and used by the Lithuanian National Health Service. During the DPA investigations, it was discovered that when the app was functioning, the data of 677 individuals had been processed in varying degrees. The app had collected names, phone numbers, and the addresses of data subjects. Clearly, the data controller had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing. Moreover, the company also did not carry out any data protection impact assessment even though such an assessment was necessary due to the sensitive nature of the data being processed (health data among others). Finally, the DPA concluded that the company also provided incorrect and non-transparent information in the app’s privacy policy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller, a company managing a number of Lithuanian registers, suffered a data breach in which 22 registers were affected. The DPA discovered that the company had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of personal data. Clearly, the measures that were implement by the company were not sufficient nor adequate to safeguard the resilience, availability, and integrity of the data, nor to make the data available again after the incident.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully forwarded e-mails from a former employee for several months, without the data subject being informed of this data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The energy company Dragefossen AS was fined with EUR 14,900 by the Norwegian DPA for installing a webcam on the roof of the office building in the center of Rognan, which operated 24/7 and filmed the city center. The live streams could be watched on the official website of the data controller, and on YouTube. Moreover, the live streams recorded the last 12 hours, filming a public street, a parking lot, the entrances of two grocery stores, the local bank, a liquor store, a pharmacy, the city hall, and other buildings. Due to the low quality of the image, it was not possible to distinguish individual facial details or license plate numbers. However, the image quality was sufficiently good to identify the type of car the data subjects had been driving, the clothes they’d been wearing, their hair color, and several other personal characteristics. Naturally, these details were more than enough for watchers of the livestream to identify family members, friends, coworkers, etc. The Norwegian DPA decided that the live stream breached Art. 6 (1) GDPR and Art. 5 (1) GDPR. This decision of the DPA underlines the fact that the live streams showed a significant number of employees, many of whom were monitored 24/7. The employees were going to and coming back from work, some bought groceries, alcohol, medication, or were in the public areas for various reasons. Such activities are not expected to be monitored or posted on the internet, everyone to see.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Two schools in Alesund demanded that students download a training app called Strava in order to participate in physical education classes. The teachers then gave tasks to students that would be tracked through the app. When the DPA performed an investigation, it found out that there were several data breaches since the municipality had not performed any data protection impact assessment, nor had it provided standard protection procedures for privacy-compliant apps for school use. These would have been necessary when it came to the potential risk associated with the students. The protection of the data processing was also not considered by implement the necessary organizational and technical measures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller failed to report a personal data breach, violating Art. 33 (1) GDPR. The DPA was informed of the personal data breach by an individual who had come into unauthorized possession of the personal data. The personal data consisted of an unencrypted, non-password protected attachment sent via email by an employee of the data controller, which contained personal data of several hundred individuals.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller refused to cooperate with the DPA during an investigation, failing to provide the necessary information. The company ignored two requests for information filed by the DPA regarding a complaint filed by an individual. Moreover, the company offered no reasons for its ignoring of the information requests.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Krajowa Szkoła Sądownictwa i Prokuratury (National School of Justice and Prosecution) was fined with EUR 22,200 by the Polish DPA (UODO) after an investigation initiated because of a report of a data breach on the training platform website of the data controller. The data of more than 50,000 individuals was exposed to the Internet during a test migration to a new platform. The personal data included user names, names, e-mail and postal addresses, units and departments, as well as telephone numbers of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the data controller failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the confidentiality of the data processed. Moreover, the contract between the data controller and the company that processed the data failed to comply with the legal requirements. For instance, the contract failed to mention the categories of data that would be processed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller (ING Bank, the Bucharest Branch) had sent files for the issuance of insurance policies to a contractual partner. Though, the files contained outdated information, and the employees of the insurance policy monitoring department failed to check it, and processed the insurance policies as per the work process, affecting 270 people. This breach of confidentiality of personal data happened because the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Individual holding the position of General Secretary for a political party in Bucharest
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) fined a natural person with EUR 500 for publishing on a social network a list that contained personal data (names, nationalities, signatures, postal addresses, dates of birth) of ten supporters of the political party. The data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of the personal data. Moreover, the controller did not sufficiently cooperate with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA fined S.C. Medicover S.R.L with EUR 2,000 for violating Art. 32 (1) b), (2), (4) GDPR. After being notified multiple times by the controller about personal data breaches regarding unauthorized disclosure and access to personal data (names, email and health data, correspondence addresses) of data subjects, the DPA performed and investigation. Apparently, documents containing personal data had been sent to wrong recipients multiple times. The DPA concluded that the company failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to implement the necessary security measures that would ensure the protection of the personal data being processed, and was fined with EUR 10,000 by the Romanian DPA. During the investigation, the ANSPDCP discovered that the data controller’s failure to implement these security measures resulted in a total of 99,210 data subjects having their personal data disclosed without authorization. The data included gender, telephone numbers, and customer number. Moreover, there was another data breach in which the personal data of 413 customers was accessed without authorization. The Romanian DPA considered that the company violated Art. 32 (1) and (2) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company sent a debt collection email to an individual, linking the payment of an invoice directly through the data controller’s website. However, the link showed another customer’s data, which the data subject saw. Due to the company’s acknowledgment of the debt and immediate payment, the fine was reduced from EUR 5,000 to EUR 3,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject that issued a complaint to the Spanish DPA (AEPD) worked for a construction company and did some renovation work for them. During the working hours, the controller’s properties had been damaged. As a result, the controller sent a letter with damage claims to the complainant but also to his father, which had previously worked for the same construction company, but who was no an uninvolved third party. The Spanish DPA considered that the processing of the father’s data happened without a legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had no privacy policy on its website, nor did it provide any information as required by Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD, Art. 28 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One data subject received advertising calls from the controller on behalf of Vodafone Espana, S.A.U, despite the fact that the data subject was on the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The restaurant made unauthorized use of two video surveillance systems to record part of the public space without a clear cause.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had no privacy policy on its website, which prompted the Spanish DPA to fine it with EUR 1,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.source: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Some data subjects reported receiving advertising calls from the data controller, even though the data subjects were on the Robinson advertising exclusion list. Due to immediate acknowledgment and payment, the fine was reduced from EUR 20,000 to EUR 12,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined by the Spanish DPA with EUR 200,000. Two companies, Waitum S.L. and Servicios Aby 2018, complained to the DPA that their clients received letters from the data controller. This happened in the context where the two companies had transferred their customers’ personal data to the data controller through a network access agreement. The agreement stated that, while the customers would receive electricity from the data controller, the two companies would still be in control of their customers, just as before. However, the letters mentioned that the two companies were guilty of non-payment and breaches of contract. However, the DPA concluded during its investigation that the letters were not necessary in the context of applying the binding principles of the contract. This means that the data controller had violated the principles of data minimization and purpose limitation, unlawfully processing the customers’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subject twice complained to the DPA that the data controller had sent advertising SMS messages, even though the data subject had demanded that his personal data be deleted and that he not receive any more advertising messages. The data subject claimed he received more than 60 SMS messages within 30 days. Another complain was filed by the data subject when the data subject sent him more messages that contained the confidential data of a third party. Among the data was the login information of a customer to a company platform. On that company platform, the data subject could see personal information such as invoices. Even after the data subject informed the company of this mistake, he kept receiving mails and messages. When the data controller admitted guilt and paid the fine, the original fine of EUR 150,000 was reduced to EUR 90,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject was added by the data controller to a debtor register without prior notification. Apparently, the data subject had delayed rent payments with the landlord, who had sent previous requests for payment, as well as notices for payment. However, these notices and payment requests mentioned nothing about the personal data of the data subject being entered in a debtors’ register in the case of a non-payment. Moreover, the rental contract did not mention this point either, which led to the DPA concluding that the data controller had no legitimate reasons or justifications, under the GDPR, to process the personal data of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The hospital was fined with EUR 10,000 by the Spanish DPA for violating Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR. A patient filed a complaint with the DPA concerning the data controller. An MRI was performed on the data subject in 2019, for an injury of the right knee. The cost for this examination was covered by the private health insurance of the patient. In the same month of 2019, another MRI had to be performed due to a work-related injury to the same knee, to a different hospital. However, the second hospital’s system linked the first MRI (which was privately-arranged) to the patient’s records at this second hospital. It should be clear that the first MRI had been provided through the hospital network without a medical justification, due to the private nature. This turnaround was unfavorable for the data subject because, when the second MRI came, the doctor told him to contact his private physician or a social insurance regarding this injury, because the accident can’t be considered a work-related accident. The doctor also said that, since the first MRI had a non-occupational cause, the second MRI could not have an occupational cause either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller, while operating a website that provides information about internships offered by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Sports, had compiled and published the data of participants to competitions held by the ministry from public sources without the consent of the data subjects. Moreover, the data controller had not informed the data subjects beforehand, infringing upon Art. 13 and 14 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The controller approved the loan request of an identity thief who used the personal data of a third party to apply for a microcredit while pretending to be the data subject. The data controller unlawfully processed the personal data since this data did not belong to the actual loan recipient, but to another third party. There was no legal basis for the data processing, which means there was a breach of Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 12,000 for immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was filed with EUR 600,000 after a severe data breach was reported to the AEPD. The data breach involved the unauthorized access to personal contact details and bank accounts. More than 489,000 individuals and about 1,500,000 records were affected during the data breach. The data controller had clearly failed to take the appropriate and necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the data processing, and it also delayed the DPA notification by 41 days. One aggravating factor that led the DPA to increase the fine amount was the fact that the data breach affected people worldwide, not only in Spain, affecting sensitive financial data as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company’s data processing policy was not compliant with Art. 13 GDPR, and it also had no privacy policy on the website where the users would be informed about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller published pictures of a 4-year-old child on WeChat, a Chinese messenger service, without obtaining the parents’ consent first. The photos showed the child participating in the data controller’s Chinese lessons. While the data controller attempted to cover the face of the child with a digital sticker, it was still partially visible. And despite the parents’ demand that he deletes the photos and apologize, the data controller did not respond.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The complainant renewed her driver’s license with the data controller in 2009. After changing her residential address in 2018, one year later she received a mail from the data controller to her new address, even though she had not informed the data controller of this change. In this letter, the data controller informed the data subject that the driver’s license would expire soon. When asked why it possessed the data subject’s new address, the data controller claimed that its databases were being updated regularly with data from the Spanish transport authority DGT. The data subject filed a claim with the Spanish DPA against the data controller since she had not consented to the data processing. When the DPA investigated the case, they discovered that the data controller had contractual relations with DGT, as claimed beforehand. However, DGT claimed that the processing of contact data would be done to ensure the address accuracy when renewing a driver’s license or for the issuance of medical reports, though the data subject should still request and consent to the change of address. This principle was not observed in this case, so the DAP determined that the data controller had violated the purpose limitation principle.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: When the client requested his documents to submit them to the tax authorities, the company sent him an e-mail containing the documents of another client.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject had previously been a customer of the data controller years back. Despite this, she received payment reminders for services she had never booked or made use of. After informing the controller and demanding the deletion of her data, the data controller claimed that it would delete her data. Despite this, she kept receiving the SMS messages. Then, the data subject twice complained to the Spanish DPA about this, and the data controller assured both times that it would correct this mistake and delete the data subject’s personal data from the system. However, the mailing continued, which led the data subject to file a third complaint.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller used cameras that monitored the public space, which is a breach of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined with EUR 475,000 for not reporting a data breach to the DPA in a timely manner. Back in December 2018, criminals had accessed the data of 4,109 people who had booked a hotel room through the Bookim.com booking site. The personal data included names, phone numbers, addresses, and booking details. The credit data of 283 people was also accessed, with 97 cases where the criminals managed to access the security code of the credit card. Moreover, the criminals also pretended to be employees of Booking.com in order to get the credit card details of other victims via phone or email. The company was notified of this data breach on January 13, 2019 but only notified the DPA on February 7, 2019. With 22 days of delay, the company was supposed to report the data breach to the DPA in 72 hours at most.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: OLVG, an Amsterdam hospital, was fined with EUR 440,000 for not taking sufficient security measures between 2018 and 2020 when medical records were accessed without authorization. The data controller failed to check who had accessed files and ensure that the computer systems were properly secured against foreign, unauthorized access. As a result, students and employees were able to access patient files without justification or it being a necessity for work. These files also contained social security numbers, telephone numbers, and addresses of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller was fined with 19,900 EUR for using a surveillance system to monitor its employees and customers. The DPA concluded that the data controller had been using the camera surveillance system unlawfully, without a legal basis to do so. Moreover, the data controller also did not offer sufficient information to the data subjects regarding the use of this surveillance system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA imposed a fine of 3,400 EUR on the company for violating Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The data controller was operating a carwash, and an act of vandalism took place at the payment terminal. The data controller sent the recorded footage of the vandalism to the employer of the alleged vandal. The Norwegian DPA concluded that the sharing of this video recording happened without a legal basis, violating the aforementioned GPDR articles. The DPA also mentioned that sharing this video recording was not done in an attempt to clarify the situation because the recordings had already been surrendered to the police.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: S.C. Tip Top Food Industry S.R.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had installed several security cameras that monitored the food areas and the changing rooms of the employees. This CCTV system was allegedly used to deter any theft and protect the company’s manufactured goods. However, the Romanian DPA concluded that the data controller had clearly violated the principle of data minimization because surveillance of this magnitude was not necessary. The manufactured goods could have been secured with other means that did not require an intrusion of privacy to the employees.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller was fined with 1,500 EUR for accidentally destroying personal data of customers of Raiffeisen Bank S.A., in its capacity as the bank’s data controller. The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) claimed that this incident took place due to a lack of organizational and technical measures that would ensure the security and protection of the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller refused to answer to the data subject’s inquiries regarding the use of his personal data. Moreover, the data policy of the data controller, regarding data protection, failed to comply with Art. 13 GDPR. As such, the data subject was confused about the use of this personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The police found a total of 29 envelopes containing results of medical examinations, which were addressed to the data controller’s employees, in a local industrial area. The DPA also mentioned that two envelopes were found opened. In conclusion, the DPA claimed that the company had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the processing of the employees’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller, Kukimbia S.L., transports, stores, and distributes goods. When documents containing personal information about the data controller’s customers and suppliers were found near a trash can next to a warehouse belonging to the data controller. In this case, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 32 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The AEPD fined Promotech Digital S.L. with EUR 2,400 for constantly sending advertising SMS messages to a data subject, even though the data subjects had not requested or agreed to receiving these SMS messages. Moreover, these SMS messages did not include any method to unsubscribe from the advertisement campaign. The data subject could cancel it via email, though. The data subject had objected in the past to receiving these SMS messages, yet the data controller kept sending SMS messages. Due to an acknowledgment of guilt and immediate payment, the fine was reduced to EUR 2,400 from EUR 3,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Originally, a fine of EUR 100,000 was imposed on Kutxabank S.A. A former customer complained that the bank failed to comply with his request for data deletion. After the DPA started investigating the data controller, it found out that the data subject had exercised his right for data deletion back when he was still a customer of the bank. When trying to open up a new account with the data controller, the data subject was informed that opening an account was not possible because his data was blocked (as a result of the request for data erasure). The data subject was informed that if he wanted to open a new account, the data would have to be unblocked. In this sense, the letter came attached with a form. This form claimed that, upon signing it, the data subject would forfeit his previous request for data erasure, thus allowing the data controller to his data again. The Spanish DPA concluded that a temporary erasure of data did not legally correspond to the right to erasure. The DPA also stated that any blocked or deleted data could not be processed again even when the data subject and the data controller enter a new contractual relationship for the same purpose as before.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller was using two unauthorized video surveillance cameras that covered areas of the public space.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had previously published on its website a photo of the data subject without first obtaining his consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had published a brochure on sex education in several schools. These brochures contained the names and photos of three data subjects who had not given their consent to the data processing. After acknowledgment and immediate payment of the fine, it was reduced from EUR 5,000 to EUR 4,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4), (6) GDPR, Art. 14 (2) a) GDPR, Art. 14 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 25 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: ParkkiPate Oy was fined with EUR 75,000 by the Finnish DPA. The company had issued parking tickets to several data subjects, upon which the individuals requested to know what personal data the company processed, and some individuals asked the company to delete their personal data. As a reply, the company stated that it would need the ID card number and the physical address of the data subjects to delete the data, since the name and the parking ticket number was not enough to identify them. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization and had also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing. While the DPA claimed that the company could, in theory, request further data to assist with the identification, this was only allowed if identification was not possible without the additional information. However, this was not the case. The DPA also found out that the company had violated the principle of storage limitation. Apparently, the data controller had been storing photos of illegally parked cars and copies of parking tickets without establishing a clear deadline for the deletion of this data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: 11th District Public Health Department of the Government Office of Budapest
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined the XI District Office of the Government of Budapest with EUR 27,700 for failing to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the protection of personal data. Apparently, the data controller had sent emails with health data about Covid-19 rapid tests and contact details of the people tested, to various doctors, in an unencrypted Excel file. No measures were taken to ensure the confidentiality and security of this file. Moreover, the data controller did not inform the DPA about this data violation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: InfoMentor ehf was fined with EUR 23,100 by the Icelandic DPA for a data breach of Art. 33 GDPR reported by the data controller. This incident related to the company’s online system used by various institutions and schools to communicate and for other information purposes. During the investigations, the DPA concluded that the data controller had failed to employ the necessary technical and organizational security measures, which led to the data breach. This security leach led to the six-digit system PIN number of each individual user becoming visible publicly on the URL address of a specific page in the mentor system. This led to unauthorized individuals gaining access to the personal data of 424 children.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 21 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller was making calls for TIM s.p.a., with several calls being made despite the data subjects’ lack of consent or objection to said calls. Moreover, Garante found out that the data controller had also contacted a total of 47,981 telephone numbers without a legal basis. Moreover, the DPA concluded that the data controller had not respected the data subjects’ right to object. For instance, one user was contacted a total of 155 times in one month, even though he had objected to the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had been making calls on behalf of TIM s.p.a. with several calls being made despite the data subjects’ lack of consent or objection to said calls. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to verify whether the data in the contact lists received from third-party companies was legitimate or not. The company also did not ensure the data subjects had given their consent for these promotional activities.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Comune di San Marco in Lamis
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The municipality uploaded documents of the data subject and his family on its official website, which was publicly available. These documents were in the form of two orders against the data subjects, and they were related to proceedings against the data subjects for engaging in construction work without a building permit. These documents contained dates of birth, names, tax numbers, places of birth, and physical addresses of the data subject and his relatives. Previously, the data subject had asked the municipality to remove the documents from their website but this request was refused.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 130 (1), (2) Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had sent email advertisement to a data subject without obtaining consent first. The data subject filed two complaints against the company. Apparently, the data subject had complained repeatedly about the data processing, and the data controller kept sending ads. In fact, the data controller did not respond at all to the data subject’s requests for data deletion. Furthermore, the data controller also did not keep any register of the data processing activities, failing to cooperate sufficiently with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subject complained to the Italian DPA that the news station had published an article where he, the data subject, was referred to. The data subject legally exercised his right under Art. 17 and requested that his data be deleted from the article because it was not relevant. The data controller did not, however, respond to the request in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The municipality of Castellanza uploaded documents with personal data of various data subjects on its website. These documents which contained legal proceedings of the data subject, were freely accessible to anybody.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Back on May 5, 2021, the Norwegian DPA announced its intent to fine Disqus Inc. with EUR 2,500,000 for violating Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, and Art. 13 GDPR. Allegedly, the company had unlawfully tracked visitors of Norwegian websites that used the Disqus plugin. In turn, they sent this data to various third-party advertisers.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined With EUR 2,000 for publishing the contract termination letter of an employee on the WhatsApp group used by all employees. As a result, all the employees gained access to the personal information of the data subject, including name, address, ID number, first name, and specific information concerning the request for termination).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subjects a complaint against the company to the DPA because the company had sent SMS advertisements even though he had previously requested that his data be deleted. The data controller had also confirmed the data deletion. The fine includes EUR 10,000 for breaching Art. 17 GDPR, and EUR 5,000 for breaching Art. 21 LSSI.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subjects a complaint against the company to the DPA because the company had sent SMS advertisements even though he had previously requested that his data be deleted. The data controller had also confirmed the data deletion. Then, the data controller claimed that they could not fulfill the data subject’s request due to human error. The fine includes EUR 3,000 for breaching Art. 17 (1) GDPR, and EUR 2,000 for breaching Art. 21 LSSI. The initial fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 for admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined with EUR 1,500,000 by the Spanish DPA after several complains for unlawful data processing were received by the DPA. As it stands, the data controller had not informed the data subjects about collecting their data, as per Art. 13 GDPR. Articles 15 and 22 GDPR were also breached because the data subjects were not informed of their rights. Moreover, the contact details of the data controller were also incomplete. The company would also conclude contracts with customer representatives instead of communicating directly with the customers. However, the data controller did not expressly check whether the representatives were authorized by the data subjects to represent them. The Spanish DPA found that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary security procedures to verify the allegations of the representatives.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined with EUR 3,000 by the Spanish DPA because a data subject had filed a complaint against it, stating that the data controller kept sending advertisements on WhatsApp even though the data subject had requested that his data be deleted.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Back in 2017, the municipality installed special measurement boxes that would measure crowds in the center of Enschede. Special sensors in the boxes would detect the Wi-Fi signals dispatched by the cell phones of passing people registering each of them with a code. And based on these codes, it could then calculate how busy the center was. As it stands, these measurements and codes led to the tracking of individual passers-by because the boxes would track particular cell phones. Even though the municipality claimed that this wasn’t even remotely the goal of the boxes, the DPA concluded that the Wi-Fi tracking, even though unintentional, was a serious breach of the GDPR. Thus, the municipality unlawfully tracked passers-by without a legal basis, violating Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA (APD) fined a financial company with EUR 100,000. Apparently, a data subject had previously filed two complaints with the Belgian DPA against the company. These complains related to 20 queries of her personal data from the credit register of the National Bank of Belgium. The data controller had employed the data subject’s ex-husband. The husband had allegedly used his position in the company to illegally gain access to the register to obtain financial information about the data subject, thus gaining an advantage in their divorce proceedings. According to the DPA, these data violations appeared because the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational measures to protect personal data from unauthorized processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined A. ΕΠΙΛΟΓΗ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ with EUR 5,000. The data controller had failed to respond to multiple requests for information and data deletion from the data subject. During the DPA’s investigation, the data controller informed the DPA that it had deleted the data subject’s personal information from its databases. However, the data controller failed to notify the data subject of this. Moreover, the Hellenic DPA concluded that the data subject’s data had been collected for other purpose than the agreed ones. The data controller had not obtained any consent of the data subject regarding the new processing purpose of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has imposed a fine of EUR 5,000 upon ΚΑΡΙΕΡΑ A.E. A data subject filed a complaint with the Hellenic DPA against the data controller because the data controller kept sending him email advertisements despite having requested the deletion of his data and the controller had confirmed the deletion. Due to a technical error, the data subject’s data had not been deleted according to his request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA) of the municipality of Tavros Moschato
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) d) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined the Municipal Organization for Pre-School Education and Social Solidarity (DOPAKA) of the municipality of Tavros Moschato with EUR 10,000. The data controller had unlawfully published documents containing personal data of the data subject. The documents contained, other than his name, information about his profession, place of work, and a specific evaluation of his behavior at work. The data controller also failed to respond to a deletion request from the data subject. The fine is comprised of EUR 7,000 for a violation of Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 3,000 for a violation of Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR and Art. 17 (1) d) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA (NAIH) fined with EUR 1,425 the operator of a care facility. The data controller had installed 25 cameras in all of the rooms of the facility, except the restrooms, locker rooms and the main nurses’ station. The video surveillance recorded both the employees and the residents of the facility. The data controller claims that the cameras had been installed for nothing else other than security purposes. These purposes included preventing unauthorized persons from gaining access to the facility, and preventing theft attempts. The DPA concludes that the extensive video surveillance wasn’t necessary for the processing purpose (security of the facility). Moreover, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA (DPC) has fined with EUR 90,000 the Irish Credit Bureau (ICB). The fine was issued after a data breach was reported by the controller to the DPA on the 31st of August, 2018. The data controller is a credit reporting agency that has a database of credit contract performances held between financial institutions and borrowers. The data breach took place when the data controller changed a code to one of its databases that contained a technical error. As a consequence, between the 28th of June, 2018 and the 30th of August, 2018, the ICB database inaccurately updated the records of a total of 15,120 closed accounts. The data controller disclosed 1,062 inaccurate account records to financial institutions or affected individuals before this problem issue was solved.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 7,000 TECNOMEDICAL S.r.l. A data subject filed a complaint with the Italian DPA after the data controller failed to adequately respond to his request for personal information. The data subject had previously requested access to his personal data from the data controller. In this sense, he demanded the data controller a copy of his medical records and the medical documentation of his past dental implant surgery. However, the data controller failed to provide the complete information in due time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 2,000 Società triveneta di chirurgia. A physician had preiovusly shown slides of a clinical case at a congress he was participating at. The cases were then published on the data controller’s website. The slides contained personal data of a patient, like the patient’s initials, gender, age, and a detailed history of the patient’s pathology, as well as details of admissions from 1980 to 2016. There was also a detailed schematic of the surgical procedures performed during this period, indicating the date of admission and the surgery, the surgical department that performed these procedures, the specific days that the patient spent in hospital, various diagnostic images, and a total of 22 photographs that showed the patient during the surgeries. The data subject never consented to such processing of his personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 2,000 Società triveneta di chirurgia. A physician had preiovusly shown slides of a clinical case at a congress he was participating at. The cases were then published on the data controller’s website. The slides contained personal data of a patient, like the patient’s initials, gender, age, and a detailed history of the patient’s pathology, as well as details of admissions from 1980 to 2016. There was also a detailed schematic of the surgical procedures performed during this period, indicating the date of admission and the surgery, the surgical department that performed these procedures, the specific days that the patient spent in hospital, various diagnostic images, and a total of 22 photographs that showed the patient during the surgeries. The data subject never consented to such processing of his personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) fined with EUR 40,000 the municipality of Palermo. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the Italian DPA against the municipality of Palermo. He claimed that an unauthorized person had gained access and processed his data from a food subsidy application. The DPA determined that this data processing had occurred because the municipality failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure the security and confidentiality of the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (Garante) has fined with EUR 15,000 the Fondazione Policlinico Tor Vergata di Roma. In February 2020, a data subject complained to the DPA, talking about a breach of data protection laws regarding the booking services for medical specialists offered by the data controller. Apparently, to book an appointment on the booking portal, visitors had to complete an online form with various personal information. The DPA found that the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure that would ensure the protection of data processing. Furthermore, the data controller failed to comply with its information obligations according to Art. 13 GDPR, since it did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data when the data collection took place.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (Datatilsynet) has fined with EUR 39,000 the Municipality of Oslo. On a website of the data controller, there was a subpoena from the public prosecutor’s office regarding the data subject had made available to the public. The subpoena contained personal information such as health data. The incident happened because the subpoena wasn’t originally classified as confidential and wasn’t exempted from public disclosure. The document was publicly available for five hours before the municipality removed it from public access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (UODO) fined Cyfrowy Polsat S.A. with EUR 245,000. The fine took into consideration a large number of data breaches reported by the data controller to the Polish DPA. Apparently, postal correspondence containing personal data was either lost or misdelivered. The DPA concludes that, although the data breaches had been caused by the courier company hired by the data controller, it was the data controller’s responsibility to ensure that these breaches did not occur. The controller did not implement adequate technical and organizational measures appropriate to the risk that would protect the data processing. Furthermore, the controller did not notify the data subjects about the data breaches until two to three months later.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined with EUR 200 the operator of the website declaratieppr.ro. During the Covid19 pandemic, visitors to this website were able to fill out form where they were required to enter their place of residence. Personal data such as address, name, and ID number were collected in this sense. However, the data controller wasn’t able to prove the lawfulness of the data processing. Furthermore, the data controller did not sufficiently inform the data subjects about the data processing when collecting the personal data, and had also failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined with EUR 500 Asociație de Proprietari din municipiul Iași (Owners Association of Iasi Municipality). The data controller did not provide the DPA with the information it had requested.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined Banca Comercială Română S.A. with EUR 2,000. A data subject had issued a complaint with the DPA because the data controller had previously used his personal data to enforce a procedure for debts arising from a credit agreement that he was unaware of.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Allianz Compañia de Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A. with EUR 30,000. The data controller has previosuly sent an invoice to the data subject although there wasn’t any contractual obligation between them. The data subject had concluded a motorcycle insurance policy with the data controller back in 2016, but had terminated the policy in 2017.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Telefonica de España, S.A.U.. with EUR 75,000 A data subject had complained to the AEPD against the telecommunications company. The controller had booked a service for the data subject without the data subject having concluded a contract for it. After the data subject had not made any payments for this service, the service was canceled in that same year and a specific collection agency was hired to collect the alleged outstanding debt. The AEPD concluded that neither the data processing of the service booking nor the transfer of the data subject’s personal data to the collection agency had been lawful. The original fine of EUR 75,000 was then reduced to EUR 45,000 because of immediate payment and acknowledgement of debt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined the managing director of a company with EUR 1,500. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller with whom he had a contract. The data controller was fined because it had not adequately informed the data subject about the processing of the data when collecting it. The Spanish DPA claims this to be a violation of Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 1,500 was reduced to EUR 900 due to immediate payment and admission of guilt

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Alava Norte, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had three 360° video surveillance cameras installed on the facade of one of its owned buildings to secure the facility. These cameras captured parts of the public space unlawfully. The AEPD concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization because extensive video surveillance wasn’t necessary to fulfill the purpose of the processing (security the facility).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Desolasol Restauración S.L. with EUR 6,000. The data subject had officially complained to the restaurant because he was unable to communicate at the table due to the volume of the music inside the restaurant. A copy of the form remained with the data controller. Because of an error by a restaurant employee, the copies of the form were given to other guests of the restaurant who had been present during the incident.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined Avalos Consultores, S.L with EUR 4,000. The data subject had been a client of the data controller. She filed a complaint with the AEPD because the data controller had transferred all her personal data to the agency Torrent Asesores Nga, S.L. without obtaining her consent first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian IT company offers IT services to companies like banks, mobile operators, and state-run institutions in Croatia, and foreign companies (USA, Great Britain, the Netherlands, etc.), acting as a data processor in relation to personal data. The data controller in question, a telecommunications company using the services of the IT provider, told the DPA and its users of a potential breach of personal data committed by the IT provider. This was a security breach that led to unauthorized access and the processing of multiple sets of personal data (28,085 data subjects) by hackers. The security breach happened because the IT provider failed to take the adequate security measures that would protect the personal information from being stolen, thus failing to consider the existing risks. The data controller, as a data processor, would have been forced to take adequate technical and security measures in a way that ensured the consistent anonymity of the personal data, including the regular testing, evaluation and the analysis of how effective anti-hacking responses would be, on the off-chance an attack did happen. During its security assessments, the data controller should have taken into consideration specific security risks related to the personal data of the 28,085 data subjects. Because of this failure to implement the adequate security measures, the Croatian DPA imposed an administrative fine on the IT provider. We don’t know the amount of the fine at this moment. However, when implementing the fine, the DPA considered the nature of the IT provider’s business activity, whose role should have been support other companies through informed guidelines, offering solutions regarding the implementation of web applications, and how to design and introduce adequate technical and security measures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art 27 (1) of the National Implementation Law
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA had conducted an unannounced direct supervision of an insurance company with its headquarters in Zagreb. When inspecting its business facility that had to carry out technical inspections, vehicle registrations, and to contract insurance services, the DPA found out that the business facility and its surroundings were under video surveillance. However, the Croatian DPA concluded that the insurance company did not provide any notice of such surveillance, and this is a breach of Art 27 (1) of the Law on the Implementation of GDPR. The Law states that data controllers have the obligation to indicate that the object of its activity and its perimeter or surroundings are under video surveillance. Moreover, the company should post a notice of this surveillance that is visible upon entering the surveilled perimeter, and this notice should contain all the necessary information. Due to this security breach breach, the DPA imposed an administrative fine on the insurance company.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Vejle Municipality with EUR 27,000. The Danish DPA had investigated the municipality after it had previously reported a security breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The municipal dental care service was sending automated welcome letters to parents regarding the treatment of their children at the dental office. These welcome letters contained the contact details of both parents. During this process, the municipality failed to check whether making the information of one parent known to the other was allowed, or whether they had permission to do this. In many cases, one parent received the residence address of the other parent, even though the other parent had address and name protection. The DPA concluded this as a failure of the municipality to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure adequate data protection.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Nordbornholms Byggeforretning Aps with EUR 53,800. Back in 2018, the DPA was contacted by a data subject who complained that his former employer, the aforementioned Nordbornholms Byggeforretning ApS, had unlawfully disclosed personal information about him to the company’s customers. The data controller had sent emails to two company customers, in which it informed them that the former employee had committed crimes during his time working of the company, to which he had freely admitted. The data controller then went on to describe the crimes in detail. According to the Dannish DPA, the data controller in this case, had a legitimate interest in not withholding information about the former employee’s crimes to its customers. It was within its rights to inform its customers that, due to these crimes, the former employee would not continue working for the company and could not see to the customers’ needs. However, there was no need to go into details about the nature of the crime, and the DPA concluded this was an unlawful act.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Medicals Nordic I/S with EUR 80,700. Back in January 2021, the DPA as made aware that Medicals Nordic had been using WhatsApp messages to transmit confidential information and health data about citizens that were tested in the test centers of the company. The company had summoned to the WhatsApp group all employees working in a specific testing center. The members of these WhatsApp groups received all kinds of messages sent by other employees in the test center groups. All employees shared confidential information about tested citizens to the data controller’s central administration through those WhatsApp groups. However, this also meant that even employees who had no relation to the testing centers, still got access to the personal information of the citizens, which included health data, personal identity numbers, and inter alia.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (1), (3) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the magazine publisher with EUR 8,500. The DPA received four different complaints against the data controller because of unsolicited telephone advertising. The data controller had assumedly done direct marketing with an automated calling system, but without obtaining valid consent from the data subjects who received the marketing calls. More specifically, the data controller had obtained a form of consent for such direct marketing when any customer subscribed to the online magazine on its website. The subscriber was then required to accept the given terms of the subscription and contract, which also included a consent to direct marketing. But this is where the problem occurs. If the customer did not give his consent to the direct marketing, then he could also not subscribe to the magazine. The DPA claimed that the data controller requested and obtained consent in a way that isn’t compliant with the GDPR. Clearly, the data controller had not specifically requested consent for direct marketing, but rather got an apparent consent with a subscription and other contract terms. This form of consent does not constitute a valid form of consent for the purpose of direct marketing. Furthermore, the customers could not exercise their right to object to direct marketing, since the marketing was carried out by an automated system that could not answer specific queries of the customers. Lastly, the magazine publisher had commissioned an advertising call center to carry out this direct marketing, concluding a contract in this sense.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés, Art. L. 34-5 CPCE
