allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined BRICO PRIVE with EUR 500,000. The French DPA conducted three separate investigations at BRICO PRIVÉ between 2018 and 2021, and found several deficiencies in the processing of personal data of customers and prospects. In one case, the data controller failed to comply with the data retention periods that it had established. Therefore, the data controller had unlawfully retained the personal data of more than 16,000 customers because they hadn’t placed an order in the last 5 years. The same happened to approximately 130,000 customers who had not logged into the company’s accounts in the last 5 years. Furthermore, the data controller violated its information obligations under Art. 13 GDPR. It also failed to fulfill its obligations to comply with the deletion requests received by the customers. The CNIL also discovered that the data controller failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure information security. In one case, the data controller did not implement the use of a secure password when customers created an account on the company website, or when employees accessed the customer relationship management software. The fine is composed proportionately of EUR 300,000 for violations of Art. 5(1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR and Art. 32 GDPR and EUR 200,000 for violations of Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés and Art. L. 34-5 CPCE.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PURPLE SEA MΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΙΚΕ with EUR 15,000 due to having illegally installed and operated a video surveillance system. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system in its office premises without first informing its employees about it. As such, the company violated the principles of legality, fairness, transparency, purpose limitation and accountability.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Icelandic DPA (also known as Persónuvernd) has fined Huppuis ehf with EUR 34,000. A former employee had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data. Apparently, the data controller had installed a video surveillance system that the employee did not agree with. During employee shifts, the employees wore clothing provided by the data controller. However, the room in which they had to change was a storage room that also contained large quantities of cleaning materials. This storage room was too small to allow employees (mostly minors) to change, so they changed in a general employee area (which was filmed by the video surveillance system). The data controller stated that the video surveillance system was installed for security purposes. The DPA concluded that the data controller had a legitimate interest in the video surveillance, but that it would have to take into consideration the interests of the mostly underaged employees, as well. The data controller should have tried to implement less restrictive and invasive measures. Additionally, the DPA underlined that the information provided on video surveillance was insufficient in both the employee and customer service areas. In determining the amount of the fine, the DPA concluded that it was an aggravating factor that most of the employees were minors.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Iren Mercato S.p.A. with EUR 2,856,169 for failing to verify that it had obtained consent for all transfers of data of recipients of promotional activities. Many data subjects filed complaints with the DPA against the data controller because they had received unsolicited advertising messages that they had never consented to. During its investigation against the data controller, the DPA discovered that the personal data the controller had processed for its telemarketing activities was acquire from external sources and not gathered personally. The data controller also did not check whether the addressees had given their consent for this transfer of data, for the purpose of advertising. The personal data received by Iren Mercato was from one company, who had received it from two other companies in the same way. The latter companies did indeed obtain consent from the potential customers for telemarketing purposes, but they had not given their consent for the customer data transfer to other companies. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the given consent of customers to a company for promotional activities did not automatically extend to other companies through a transfer of personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) a), b), c), f), g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple types of violations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Foodinho s.r.l., an Italian food delivery service, with EUR 2,600,000. Garante mainly investigated the company’s drivers. During the investigation, the Italian DPA discovered very serious violations of applicable data protection regulations. Therefore, the Italian DPA identified a couple of irregularities regarding the algorithms of the Foodinho system. More specifically, the DPA found that the data controller had failed to adequately inform its employees about how the system worked, and it also didn’t guarantee the accuracy of algorithms’ results used to evaluate drivers. Furthermore, the DPA also concluded that the data controller had violated the principles of memory limitation and data minimization. For instance, the company’s systems processed the drivers’ data to an extent that was thoroughly unnecessary and exceeded the purpose of the processing. In some cases, they stored the data significantly longer than was necessary. Additionally, the controller had failed to take the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure the secure data processing. The data controller also did not conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being clearly necessary because the company was dealing with a considerable amount of customer data. The Spanish DPA are conducting separate proceedings against the mother company, GlovoApp23.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined the municipality of Bolzano with EUR 84,000. One of the former employees of the municipality filed a complaint with the DPA against the municipality. More specifically, the former employee complained that the municipality had processed personal data regarding his internet use during working hours. He received, at a later date, a notice of initiation of disciplinary proceedings. The company had accused him of improperly using the company’s resources for private purposes, having accessed Facebook for more than 40 minutes per day, and staying on YouTube for more than 3 hours. During an investigation, the DPA found out that the municipality had been actively monitoring employees’ internet browsing for over a decade, using a certain system of control and filters. They would retain data monthly, and create special reports for their network security purposes. The system would also collect information that was completely irrelevant regarding the employees’ professional activities and, in many cases, concerned the private lives of the individuals in question. The Italian DPA found out that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization, lawfulness and purpose limitation. The data controller should have clearly taken less intrusive measures to prevent the private use of their Internet network. The Italian DPA pointed out that, despite the company needing to ensure employees don’t use the internet connection for their private use and only focus on their professional goals, this does not condone the total elimination of privacy of the data subjects at the workplace. Additionally, the data controller had failed to adequately inform employees about this collection of Internet history, thus violating its obligations under Article 13 of the GDPR. Furthermore, the DPA investigation identified other violations in the processing of data regarding employees’ requests for extraordinary medical examinations, which had been made using special forms. The form offered by the data controller would be checked and assessed by the head of the organizational unit, and these circumstances led to the unlawful processing of the health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined a dentist with EUR 20,000. One of his data subjects complained to the DPA against the dentist because he refused to treat him after the data subject had told him he had HIV in his medical history form. Apparently, in the dentist’s clinic, patients would always fill out these forms with their medical history before receiving any medical treatments. These forms contained specific information about any previous or existing infectious diseases like hepatitis, tuberculosis, or HIV. The Italian DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principles of legality. While it was legitimate for the dentist to ask for such information in order to better plan medical treatment, it still wasn’t allowed nor permissible to collect such information and then refuse treatment to the patient.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 35 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Lithuanian DPA (also known as VDAI) fined UAB VS FITNESS with EUR 20,000. After being notified by an individual who said that a certain sports club owned by the data controller required clients to scan their fingerprints, the DPA started an investigation. The DPA’s review underlined that the consent provided by the customers to have their fingerprint scanned was not voluntary since were no other identification measures in place. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller also illegally processed its employees’ fingerprints. The data controller also failed to explain the purpose and legal basis used to justify the data processing of the employees’ biometric data. The data controller also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment, failing to offer evidence for the necessity and proportionality of the processing of the employees’ fingerprints. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to comply with its information obligations pursuant to Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined BRAbank ASA with EUR 39,700. The data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA on September 6th, 2019. On the controller’s website, some customers could view data of other customers on the “My Page” section. These data sets included credit terms and residential address information of other customers. The “My Page” section had been used previously for 500 customers, to offer an overview of loans they had taken out with the data controller. Based on its investigations, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to comply with the GDPR’s requirements for risk assessments as well as taking the appropriate technical measures regarding the launch of the customer portal. According to the DPA’s assessment, the security breach would have been preventable if the data controller had previously conducted a risk assessment and review as required by law.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (Datatilsynet) fined the municipality of Moss with EUR 49,200 for using inappropriate measures to secure personal data. Back in January, the municipality of Rygge was annexed to the municipality of Moss. Therefore, a couple of IT systems from both municipalities were combined in a single, encompassing system. Because of the inadequate security measures, one of the municipality’s health services suffered a data breach in one of its productive systems. This particular system processed personal and health data of ill people who lived in the municipality and used the respective health center. The system was also used for other services related to immunization programs and health checks and follow-ups for pregnant women. Approximately 2000 people were affected by this breach, and because of it, various errors appeared in the vaccine registration. So, this led to an increased risk of data subjects receiving the wrong vaccines. Not only this but their immunization data could have been misfiled in the national immunization registry because of the data breach. Moreover, the health programs for pregnant women also got an error related to the information about the week of pregnant and the motherțs drug use. Finally, health workers in a health service ward could access the patient information without ever needing a special type of access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller did not provide enough information as requested by the Polish DPA (UODO) during its investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (UODO) fined Funeda Sp z o.o. with EUR 4,900 because the company failed to provide sufficient information as requested by the DPA during its investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Sopockie Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń ERGO Hestia S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had previously sent an email with personal data of a customer to a wrong recipient. The leaked personal data included the name, postal address of the data subject, as well as insurance details. The data controller failed to inform the Polish DPA and the data subjects about the data breach in a timely manner within 72 hours.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Romanian DPA during an investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Romanian DPA during an investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully used the personal data of a data subject without his consent to conclude contracts for electricity and gas supplies as well as a maintenance service.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Master Distancia S.A. with EUR 25,000. The data controller had included personal data of the data subject in a credit report register without having a sufficient legal basis. The data controller apparently justified this with alleged debts the data subject had with the controller. However, the truth was that both parties were still in arbitration. So, the data controller had no legal right to include the data subject’s data in the register. The original fine of EUR 25,000 was reduced to EUR 20,000 due to immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Radiotelevision del principado de Asturias with EUR 26,000. The fine consists of EUR 20,000 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 6,000 for a violation of Art. 12 GDPR. The fine was issued because the controller installed a video surveillance system of 14 video cameras and monitored the business premises. The data controller claimed that the cameras had been installed for the purpose of security of the surrounding premises. However, the cameras also captured the employees’ offices in a way that went beyond the original purpose of the surveillance system. For instance, one security camera captured a large part of the employees’ recreation room. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, the data controller hadn’t adequately informed the data subjects about the data processing via video surveillance, and thus violated its duty to inform. The fine was reduced to EUR 19,600 due to timely payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller failed to provide accurate information regarding the data collection, as per Art. 13 GDPR. The fine was reduced to EUR 1,200 due to immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EXPRESS WORLDWIDE SPAIN S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data subject had previously placed a private order with the data controller, but the company wrongfully entered the address of his workplace as the delivery address. So, he received the delivery correctly, yet the invoice arrived to the company where the data subject was employed and not to the data subject himself. Both the delivery bill and the invoice contained various personal data of the data subject. These were disclosed to his employer as a result of the mistake, warranting a fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Caixabank S.A. with EUR 50,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that he had received commercial advertising from the data controller, even though he had objected to the processing of his data for advertising purposes. What’s more, the data controller had said it would comply to his request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Malagatrom S.L.U with EUR 4,000. The data subject had previously purchased a product from the data controller through the platform Amazon, which was out of order when it arrived. The data subject then decided to leave a negative review on the seller’s store page. However, the data controller published personal data of the customer, including his first and last name, address, contact of his wife, phone number, on the official store page on Amazon.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. Throughout 21 regions of Sweden, there exists a telephone hotline (1177) that offers advice on a number of health-related subjects. However, every individual region has its own health advice service which it operates internally or via contracted subcontractors. All three regions form a national network. Back in 2019, the mass media reported that a number of recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were made available on a web server without any password protection. Apparently, all calls to the 1177 number were sent to the company Inera, which maintained and developed the shared systems. All calls to the number 1177 from people living in the Sormland, Stockholm and the Värmland regions were taken by Inera to Medhelp AB, which answered the calls. In turn, Medhelp had contracted the Thai company Medicall Co Ltd. to take some of the calls on weekends and during the night. Both these companies had contracted technology company Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA fined Region Sörmland for collecting call data from data subjects without obtaining the consent of the data subjects first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. Throughout 21 regions of Sweden, there exists a telephone hotline (1177) that offers advice on a number of health-related subjects. However, every individual region has its own health advice service which it operates internally or via contracted subcontractors. All three regions form a national network. Back in 2019, the mass media reported that a number of recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were made available on a web server without any password protection. Apparently, all calls to the 1177 number were sent to the company Inera, which maintained and developed the shared systems. All calls to the number 1177 from people living in the Sormland, Stockholm and the Värmland regions were taken by Inera to Medhelp AB, which answered the calls. In turn, Medhelp had contracted the Thai company Medicall Co Ltd. to take some of the calls on weekends and during the night. Both these companies had contracted technology company Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA concluded that MedHelp had clearly failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the adequate level of security to protect the data subjects’ personal data, as well as prevent unauthorized people from accessing it. Moreover, MedHelp AB did not inform its callers that it would process their personal data, as per Art. 13 GDPR. Finally, the DPA further claimed that MedHelp AB’s outsourcing of personal data of the callers to Medicall was a clear breach of the legality principle as outlined in the GDPR. That’s because Medicall isn’t covered by the Swedish health legislation, and is not subject to confidentiality obligation existent in the Swedish healthcare sector.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Region Sormland with EUR 25,000. The fine was issued because of an investigation against three companies and three Swedish regions. Throughout 21 regions of Sweden, there exists a telephone hotline (1177) that offers advice on a number of health-related subjects. However, every individual region has its own health advice service which it operates internally or via contracted subcontractors. All three regions form a national network. Back in 2019, the mass media reported that a number of recorded calls to the 1177 helpline were made available on a web server without any password protection. Apparently, all calls to the 1177 number were sent to the company Inera, which maintained and developed the shared systems. All calls to the number 1177 from people living in the Sormland, Stockholm and the Värmland regions were taken by Inera to Medhelp AB, which answered the calls. In turn, Medhelp had contracted the Thai company Medicall Co Ltd. to take some of the calls on weekends and during the night. Both these companies had contracted technology company Voice Integrate Nordic AB for call recordings. There was a data breach that involved many calls to 1177 being made public on the Internet, from a storage server that belonged to Voice Integrate. This data breach was caused by the bad configuration of a network-attached storage device that was made publicly available on the Internet and which also did not use encrypted communications. Many calls to 1177 could be accessed due to this security vulnerability. The DPA discovered that Voice Integrate did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper protection of the personal data of the callers.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Directorate of the Ostra Skaraborg Rescure Service
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Directorate of the Ostra Skaraborg Rescure Service with EUR 34,800. The DPA had received specific information that a couple fire stations in Östra Skaraborg were operating surveillance cameras that captured areas where firefighters were changing during an emergency, and in that situation, the DPA it requested a review of the camera surveillance. The video surveillance was taking place 24/7, although the data controller itself claimed that the video surveillance wasn’t needed in cases of non-emergency. The DPA stated that the 24/7 monitoring was unlawful and went beyond the purpose of the surveillance, but also notes that the controller had weighty reasons for the camera surveillance. However, the camera surveillance should be limited to emergency cases only. The fine is composed proportionally of EUR 29,800 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for a violation of Art. 32 (1), (4) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Storstockholms Lokaltrafik (Stockholm Local Transport Company) with EUR 1,600,000. The data controller had equipped its ticket inspectors with body-worn cameras. They had to prevent threatening situations, document any dangerous incidents, and fine people who traveled without valid tickets on the public transportation in Stockholm. The ticket inspectors had to keep the camera on during their shift, and were able to capture all passengers who passed the inspector. Because a couple hundred thousand people use the public transportation daily, this was a major incident of potential data leakage because of the inspectors’ body cam footage that captured all these people. While the DPA understands how the body-worn surveillance system technology could prevent threatening situations, the pre-recording time should still be reduced to 15 seconds at best. Any longer than that and the recording becomes redundant and goes above the purpose of the body cam footage. The DPA also discovered that the audio recordings weren’t used to identify the individuals with no valid tickets. So, the DPA stated that capturing the audio recordings was a violation of the principles of transparency, data minimization, and legality. The DPA also firmly criticized the data controller for failing to provide adequate information about the camera surveillance, including the fact that both sounds and images were recorded.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined UWV (the Dutch employee insurance service provider – ‘Uitvoeringsinstituut Werknemersverzekeringen) with EUR 450,000. The UWV had improperly secured the group messages of the ‘My Workbook’ online environment. This is a personal environment on the UWV website where those seeking a job can contact with the UWV. Therefore, there were multiple data breaches of personal information, including health information, for a total of more than 15,000 individuals.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The ICO has fined the transgender charity Mermaids with EUR 29,000 for using inadequate methods to secure the personal data of its users, in a breach of Art. 5 (1) f) UK GPDR and Art. 32 (1), (2) UK GDPR. The ICO conducted an investigation after it received a report of a data breach related to an internal email group. The ICO discovered that the group had insufficient security countermeasures, resulting in about 780 pages of confidential emails being made public online for three years. This led to an online leakage of personal information like names and email addresses, of about 550 people. The ICO states that Mermaids could have encrypted the access to its email group, and it could have used pseudonymization or encryption methods to offer additional protection for the personal data. Organizations like Mermaids, who are responsible for personal data of thousands of people, are obliged to ensure the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of that personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as EPD) has fined Aparcamiento Arcusa S.L.U with EUR 1,500. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that also covered the public space. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the data processing through the video surveillance and had thus violated its duty to inform. The fine includes EUR 1,000 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 500 for a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Region of Syddanmark with EUR 67,900 for failing to comply with its data controller obligations to implement proper security measures. The issue at hand came to the attention of the DPA when a citizen issued a complaint to the authority in 2020, regarding improper use of security in the personal data processing of the citizen’s child by the region. Afterwards, the region reported the matter to the authority as a personal data breach. The Region of Syddanmark had kept at the time a database for research and clinical purposes for a period of more than 1.5 years. However, the database inadequately secured against unauthorized access by unknown individuals. Through a manipulation of URLs, everyone could technically gain access to PDF documents stored in the database. This allowed all citizens who were registered in the database – and who also had login information to the database – to access the personal data of all the individuals registered in the database. The database also contained questionnaires with health information on more than 30,000 children receiving psychiatric care.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art .14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the private insurer SGAM AG2R LA MONDIALE with EUR 1,750,000. The CNIL had performed an inspection at the AG2R LA MONDIALE group back in 2019. Then, the CNIL discovered that the data controller was keeping the data of millions of individuals for an unjustified period of time and also failed to comply with their information obligations regarding the telephone canvassing campaigns. Regarding the data of prospects, the data controller failed to comply with the maximum retention period of three years as outlined in the reference framework and in the Group’s processing register. Therefore, the data controller kept the data of nearly 2,000 customers who hadn’t maintained contact with the controller for a period greater than three years, and in some cases five years. Regarding the customer personal data, the data controller failed to comply with the maximum statutory retention periods as stipulated in the Insurance Code and the Commercial Code. In this case, the data controller had retained the data of more than 2 million customers. Some sets of this data were sensitive (health data and banking data), and the company wasn’t legally permitted to retain this data for as long as it did.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Luxembourg
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles, and others
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA authority in Luxembourg fined Amazon Europe Core S.a.r.l. with EUR 746,000,000 ($887,000,000) because the US subsidiary did not process personal data according to the GDPR regulations. Apparently, Amazon Europe Core had misused its customer data for targeted advertising. But the company defends itself, saying that there was no data breach and at not time was customer data exposed to other unauthorized third parties. The fine enforced by the Luxembourg DPA came as a result of a 2018 complaint by French privacy rights group, La Quadrature du Net. They argued that Amazon, among other big companies, manipulate customers through targeted content and advertising. They further argued that this was against the principles or privacy and information freedoms of all Europeans. Whether Amazon’s defense wins the case remains to be seen.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) c), f), g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the food delivery service Deliveroo Italy s.r.l. with EUR 2,500,000 because the company had unlawfully processed personal data of approximately 8000 drivers. During the investigation, Garante discovered several serious data protection violations. These violations included a clear lack of transparency regarding the algorithms used to manage drivers, both during the assignment of jobs and when they booked work shifts. Deliveroo had been using a centralized system to manage its drivers, but the system also processed the assignment of orders and the booking of work shifts. However, Garante noticed that the data controller failed to properly inform its drivers about how the system they had installed on their smartphones worked, and also failed to ensure the accuracy and correctness of the algorithmic systems they used to evaluate the drivers. Additionally, Garante also found that Deliveroo had underwent a detailed assessment of the drivers’ work performance – through the continuous geolocation of their device, which was disproportionate to the assignment of the order (e.g., recording the drivers’ position every 12 seconds) – and through the retainment and storage of a certain amount of personal data the company collected during the execution of the orders, including any communication with customer service. In this sense, the company failed to mention or define the storage period of the personal data they had collected from the drivers. Instead, the data controller had only defined a flat storage period of six years. Moreover, Garante discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure adequate security of the data processing. Deliveroo Italy also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being necessary, considering the risk the drivers were exposed to.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller did not have an adequate privacy statement on its website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Fincas Miguel García S.L. with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller, claiming of a breach of Art. 13 GDPR. The DPA discovered that the information provided to the data subject by the controller wasn’t compliant with the regulations of Art. 13 GDPR. More specifically, there were certain aspects missing, such as information regarding the purposes of the data processing, the purpose for this data collection, and a legal basis for the collection, as well as any information regarding the legitimate interests of the company for collecting the data. The company also had to mention the period for which the personal data will be stored, as well as the right to withdraw consent at any time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined MONSANTO with EUR 400,000. Back in May 2019, several media outlets revealed that MONSANTO possessed a file that contained the personal data of more than 200 political figures or members of civil society (e.g., scientists, farmers, journalists, or environmental activists) who would most likely be influential in the public debate regarding the renewal and authorization of glyphosate across Europe. The CNIL also received seven complaints from various data subjects affected by this file. For each of these individuals, the aforementioned file contained information regarding the organization the data subjects belonged to, the position they held, their cell phone number, business email address, business address, business phone number, and even Twitter accounts. Additionally, CNIL stated that each person had been assigned a score from 1 to 5 to evaluate their credibility, support, and influence for Monsanto on several issues. The DPA believes that the company had critically violated the regulations of the GDPR by failing to inform the data subjects that their personal data was processed and stored in this file. Furthermore, the CNIL claimed that the company had foregone the contractual guarantees which would have regulated the relationships between the company and other subcontractors. Still, creating contact files for lobbying purposes by stakeholders is not illegal. But the data subjects were still within their rights to be informed about their data being in this file, in order to exercise other rights, such as the right to object to the data storage. Moreover, the CNIL discovered that the data collection had been carried out by a data provider that Monsanto had contracted, though in violation of Article 28 of the General Data Protection Regulation because it failed to include in its contracts with the data processor the provisions stated in the GDPR, more specifically the provisions regarding data security.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Mercadona S.A. with EUR 2,520,000. The data controller had previously installed facial recognition systems in many Mercadona stores to track individuals with criminal convictions or restraining orders. However, the system also captured everyone who entered the stores, including minors and employees of MERCADONA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered numerous privacy violations. For example, the system violated the principle of data minimization, and the principle of necessity and proportionality. Apparently, the data controller would process multiple biometric data that went beyond the purpose of the system. Additionally, the DPA claimed that Mercadona’s privacy impact assessment was insufficient because it failed to take into account the specific risks to Mercadona’s employees, which were posed by data processing through the facial recognition systems. Moreover, MERCADONA had also violated its duty to inform accordingly by by failing to properly provide data subjects with information about the personal data processing. The original fine of EUR 3,150,000 consisted of EUR 500,000 associated with a violation of Art. 5(1)(c), EUR 2,000,000 associated with a violation of Art. 6, and Art. 9 of the GDPR, EUR 100,000 associated with a violation of Art. 12 and Art. 13 of the GDPR, EUR 500,000 associated with a violation of Art. 25(1) of the GDPR, and EUR 50,000 associated with a violation of Art. 35 of the GDPR. The original fine was reduced to EUR 2,250,000 due to voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined by the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) because one website of the data controller did not properly provide data about the owner (postal address and tax number).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subject filed a complain against the company to the DPA, claiming that she had been receiving promotional text messages from the data controller. The data subject had previously requested the deletion of her personal data from the databases of the data controller several times before.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the political party PODEMOS PARTIDO POLÍTICO with EUR 2,400. The data controller had installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space. The DPA claimed this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the data processing by the video surveillance, thus violating violated its duty to inform. Because of voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt, the original fine of EUR 4,000 was reduced to EUR 2,400.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An owners’ association was fined with EUR 900 by the Spanish DPA for installing a video surveillance camera on the house of a data subject, which covered both the public pool area and certain parts of the house. Because of voluntary payment and acknowledgment of guilt, the original fine of EUR 1500 was reduced to EUR 900.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An owners’ association was fined with EUR 2000 by the Spanish DPA for installing a video surveillance camera on the house of a data subject. The data subject complained that the camera captured both the public pool area and the interior of several rooms in the data subject’s house.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PRA Iberia S.L. with EUR 60,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller with the AEPD. The data subject complained that the data controller had made a claim based on a contract that the data subject had no knowledge of, and which he hadn’t concluded with the data controller. The AEPD also concluded that the data subject had previously attempted to exercise his right to information, but he received no response from the data controller. Instead, the data controller continued to add interest to the data subject’s alleged debt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Universidad A Distancia De Madrid, S.A
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UNIVERSIDAD A DISTANCIA DE MADRID, S.A. with EUR 3,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the distance-learning university. He claimed that he had requested from the controller the deletion of all his personal data, and a guarantee that the data controller would not process his data again. He received a confirmation, that his data had been completely deleted. However, the data subject received email advertising from the data controller, despite his request for data deletion. The AEPD then imposed a fine of EUR 5,000, which was reduced to EUR 3,000 due to acknowledgement of guilt and immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Club Náutico el Estacio with EUR 3,000. A data subject complained against the controller to the DPA because the data controller had previously announced publicly a record of the club’s meetings on its website. By doing this, it disclosed personal data of the data subject because the records had no access restrictions.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined APARTAMENTOS PLAYA DE COVACHOS, S.L. with EUR 1,000. The data controller had installed a security surveillance system at the resort and proceed to inform about the system on information posters. However, the posters offered no details about the contact details and identity of the person responsible for the security system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UST GLOBAL ESPANA, S.A. with EUR. An employee had filed a complaint against the data controller with the AEPD. UST GLOBAL ESPAÑA, S.A. was, at the time, acting as a service provider for OpenBank regarding a project. On the 1st of August 2020, the data controller emailed OpenBank that two new employees (one of them the complainant) would join the specified project, and proceeded to request access to various applications, including a VPN. This email included the professional email addresses, first and last names, as well as ID card numbers of both employees. This way, both OpenBank and the other employee gained unauthorized access to the complainant’s data. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INSTAPACK, S.L.  with EUR 3,000. A data subject complained to the DPA that he had been receiving many SMS messages on his phone every month in which he was informed of the receipt of orders and deliveries. He was also asked to rate the company. He’d stated that he had previously sent a request for deletion of his data to the contact address on the controller’s website, but that he had received no reply. Instead, the messages kept on coming even after he submitted the deletion request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a gas inspector. The data controller had performed butane gas checks in the private homes of the data subjects based on a list containing their surnames, first names, addresses and telephone numbers. But, the data subjects hadn’t consented to this list. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 4,000 due to acknowledgement of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined Rewe affiliate Ö-Bonus Club GmbH with EUR 2,000,000. During the signing up procedure for the jö Bonus Club customer loyalty program, the data controller failed to adequately explain that customers’ data and shopping behavior are directly used to create individual profiles, and that the collected information is also passed on to partner companies. According to the GDPR, the information provided must be easily accessible understood. However, the data controller had designed the registration procedure for the jö Bonus Club in a way that the clarification about the data usage and profiling was only accessible after scrolling down. But the consent was located higher up, so in all cases, the customers would give the consent before reading the clarification. Moreover, the physical flyers also contained a signature bottom on the bottom that not only acted as a confirmation in the enrollment to the club, but also a consent to the data profiling (which wasn’t stated as such). The DPA concluded that the data controller violated its duty as a data controller to provide consent and clarification in an understandable and easily accessible form in clear and simple language. As such, the DPA deemed the consents to be invalid, and the profiling that had been performed based on these consents were unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The AEPD (Spanish DPA) fined Future Vinline S.L. because its privacy policy did not comply with the regulations of the GDPR. However, the original fine of EUR 10,000 was reduced to EUR 6,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller used surveillance cameras without offering proper contact information, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB GIMNASIA RITMICA SAN ANTONIO with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained against the data controller with the AEPD because the data controller had posted pictures and videos of her two underage daughters on Instagram. The complainant had previously informed the data controller that she did not want pictures of her daughters on social media, and she refused to give permission for her daughters to be photographed and recorded.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined DESPACHO TEJEDOR INFANTES CONSULTORES ASESORES with EUR 2,000 because the data controller had mistakenly sent an employee two emails containing personal information (payroll as well as extension of working hours) of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined a waxing salon operator of Waxing Palace A.S. with EUR 9,600. Apparently, the data controller was using camera surveillance that captured the reception area. The DPA found out that the data controller didn’t have a legal basis for this camera surveillance, and also did not provide adequate information about it. This camera surveillance affected both customers and employees.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: CNIL fined the French newspaper Le Figaro with €50,000 for placing cookies on its lefigaro.fr website without users consent. This is one of the very few fines issued against a website for cookie consent violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A TV broadcaster was offering an online section on its website about the processing of persona, yet the section was both hidden and inaccessible because of inaccurate links.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) fined Mall.tv with EUR 2,700 for because the company had recorded parts of the public space unlawfully. The DPA investigated this event and found out that the company had used two security cameras for the recordings. These cameras were recording parts of the public space which they would then broadcast in real time over internet television. These recordings were such high-quality that anyone could identify passing pedestrians and vehicles as well as their license plates.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) investigated the operator of a non-governmental medical facility due to an alleged data security breach. The data operator offers diagnostic tests for medical patients. During one such operation, the test results of several patients were posted on the operator’s website, as a communication method to physicians and patients. This security breach on the data operator’s website was the result of an unknown individuals’ actions, no less. After the incident, the data controller stopped using its website and thought of technical and organizational measures to implement that would increase overall security. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller was using other websites for the same purposes, and these websites suffered from the same security weaknesses. Still, the data controller did not stop using these other websites, and it did not propose the implementation of new security measures either. So, the UOOU fined the company with EUR 387.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 18 GDPR, Art. 19 GDPR, Art. 20 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple types of violations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) fined a ski rental company because the data controller asked its customers to provide a full copy of their IDS or a financial deposit when they rented sports equipment. Apparently, the company requested consent for these ID copies in the sports equipment rental agreements. So, when the customers signed the sports equipment rental agreement, they also consented to their IDs copies being obtained by the data controller. However, the DPA claimed this method of obtaining consent was unlawful and had no legal basis. Additionally, the data subjects received no clear clarification about this personal data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The public university demanded their students to provide personal data during the application procedures, which was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (2), (3) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The healthcare provider used a software from a third party to collect personal data from its patients without informing them about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Czech Republic
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 (3) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A public school disclosed personal information with the municipality mayor, who further released this information on the city radio mobile application.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Estonia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Estonian DPA fined Südameapteegi e-apteek with EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Estonia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Estonian DPA fined Azeeta.ee e-apteek with EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, § 3 Law 759/2004
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A higher education institution received a fine of EUR 25,000 from the Finnish DPA for violating data protection regulations during the processing of employee location data. The data controller had previously implemented a mobile application, allowing teleworkers to clock in and out. However, to use this application on a mobile device, the workers had to provide location data. The data collection took place automatically when the workers clocked in, and it was an in-built feature of the app. Without this feature, the workers couldn’t clock in. Based on the information provided by the data controller, this location data was not used nor exploited in any specific way, but rather it was only processed when the workers clocked in, for technical reasons. However, the simple fact that the app doesn’t allow workers to clock in without collecting their location data doesn’t make it a necessity to collect that data. The company could have devised the app differently. At that point, the Finnish DPA concluded that the company had violated data collection principles as well as the principle of data minimization, since it wasn’t necessary to collect location data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA (also known as HDPA) fined Ιγνατιάδης Νικόλαος και ΣΙΑ Ε.Ε. with EUR 2,000 because the data controller had installed and used surveillance security cameras in areas where company employees were present. The data controller claims that these cameras were there for security purposes after some theft incidents had occurred in the past. The security system was meant to detect and take notice of anyone entering the facilities. However, the DPA found out that the camera installations weren’t only used for property protection purposes. So, the DPA concluded that the company had violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined a pediatrician with EUR 5,000. The data controller did not comply with a father’s request to view his son’s medical records through e-mail.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Budapesti Műszaki és Gazdaságtudományi Egyetem (Budapest University of Technology and Economics)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) fined the Budapest University of Technology and Economics with EUR 22,200. The data controller had unlawfully processed the personal data of many individuals during the audit of social scholarship applications. The data controller had no legal basis to process the personal data, especially sensitive data, since there was no good reason to process it for the evaluation of the applications.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: he Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) has fined Magyar Telekom Nyrt. with EUR 28,400. The data controller had mistakenly sent email newsletters to the data subject because a third-party had entered the wrong email address to the newsletter list. Then, the data subject requested numerous times for the data controller to delete his personal contact data. But despite this, he continued receiving the newsletter, and the data controller sent him a link that he could use to unsubscribe from the newsletter.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Mapei S.p.A. did not respond to the request for access to personal data from a data subject. Additionally, the company did not close down the email account of the data subject even after terminating the work contract.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Charly Mike s.r.l with EUR 3,000. The data controller is an operator of Hotel Olimpo in Alberobello. The Italian DPA received a complaint about the hotel’s video surveillance system. The investigation pointed out that the hotel had installed 17 fixed cameras and one with 360° recording. These cameras were placed both inside and outside the hotel, and they recorded customers and employees alike. This system had been operated without any sign of its existence, as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Unita Sanitaria Locale Toscana Sud Est
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda USL Toscana Sud Est with EUR 100,000. The data controller works in the healthcare sector and has launched the “Sanita di iniziativa” program. This program encompasses participating companies transmitting healthcare data of chronically ill patients to the data controller. Then, the controller will develop personalized health plans for these patients, based on the provided health data. However, the Italian DPA noticed several data protection violations regarding the program. One such violation regarded the consent that data subjects would have to provide to have their health data processed. The data subjects weren’t properly informed about the length of the data storage, their rights (right of access and complaint), for what purpose and how their data would be processed. Moreover, the data controller didn’t keep a register of the processing activities. It also did not protect the data processing and also did not conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being necessary because of the sensitive nature of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Istituti ospedalieri Bergamaschi with EUR 45,000. During an investigation prompted by a report of a data breach, the DPA found out that a patient had mistakenly received clinical documentation and medical records from seven patients in this digital medical record.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Careggi with EUR 6,000 for violating Art. 5 GDPR and Art. 9 GDPR. The institution had previously notified the Italian DPA of a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR, regarding the transmission of health data to a wrong individual. Apparently, the institution had sent medical documents belonging to a patient to another person, by mistake. The data controller claims that this incident took place because of a printing process. Out of two printers present at the ward where the affected patient was being treated, one had preloaded medical health data of another patient, which a doctor sent to his print job (documents of the wrong recipient).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Ministero dell’Istruzione, Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per il Lazio
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Lazio Region School Authority with EUR 4,000. A parent had previously filed a complained against the school authority because it had forwarded personal data of his disabled son to the Office of Public Administration. This personal data included information about the underaged child’s health condition. The parent had complained in the past about various irregularities found in the allocation of support hours for disabled students at the I.C.G. Pitocco school of Castelnuovo di Porto. Apparently, the school authority had transmitted that personal data to discard this allegation, but the DPA concluded that the data transfer was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitari di Trento
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitary di Trento with EUR 150,000. The data controller mistakenly sent 293 medical records of 175 patients to their respective general practitioners, despite the patients requesting them not to do this. Two of the affected patients were minors, and several other patients were women who had undergone abortions. During the investigation, Garante discovered that the health data was transmitted because of an error in the patient report management software.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Usl della Romagna with EUR 120,000. The health authority of Romagna had mistakenly transmitted the abortion health report of a patient to a general practitioner despite the patient requesting not to inform her general practitioner about the abortion. The report was transmitted via the regional network “Sole.” During the investigation, Garante found out that the software that manages discharges, transfers, and patient admissions glitched, which resulted in the data transmission.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The identity of the whistleblowers that contributed to this report requires protection from special confidentiality because the processed information is sensitive. Moreover, the risk of retaliation and discrimination in the work environment is unusually high. Moving on, the data controller is always obliged to comply with the principle of data protection, as well as ensure the security and integrity of the data. In this context, the Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a. with EUR 4,000 and its software supplier, aiComply S.r.l. with EUR 20,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the application used for managing and collecting criminal reports had been accessed without a security protocol. Moreover, the application failed to provide encryption for the reporting party’s identification data, the attached documents, and any information about the reports. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the obligation to take adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security relevant to the risk to the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA found out that the data controller should have carried out an impact assessment, considering how sensitive the processed data was, and the magnitude of the vulnerabilities of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) fined the municipality of Asker with EUR 100,000. Back on the 20th of May 2020, the DPA received a complaint about the unlawful publishing of personal data on the municipality’s official website. Anyone could view document names that were previously sent through the municipality’s email distribution list. Additionally, these documents also contained dates of birth and names of more than 127 people, and this included children. Even though the distribution lists were checked by two people daily, the municipality failed to detect this security breach. The Norwegian DPA states that this data breach was at least partly caused by a lacking security routine regarding the email lists.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) fined ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o. with EUR 235,300. Because of an error during the restart of a server, a server’s security server suffered an error and its settings were reset. This made the personal data of 140,699 individuals become publicly available. This data contained information about their addresses, first and last names, marital status, and nationalities. Moreover, the database containing this information was downloaded and deleted from the servers by an unknown third party who later asked the company for a ransom if they wanted the database back. The DPA concluded that the data controller had taken inadequate and insufficient organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing, despite the existence of a high risk for the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Marbella Resorts S.L. with EUR 7,000. In this case, a data subject had previously booked a room in the company’s hotel complex. When the data subject was scheduled to arrive, a concierge copied the data subject’s data despite not being authorized to do this. The concierge should only have verified the data subject’s reservation and give the data subject the keys to the room. After the provided the concierge with his personal data, the data subject noticed that his personal data was published on a website with online content for adults.
