Therefore, the DPA concluded that the data controller didn’t show enough diligence in taking care of its clients’ personal data, violating Art. 29 (3) GDPR. The fine is composed proportionally of EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 22(2) LSSI and 5,000 EUR for a breach of Art. 28(3) GDPR. However, the original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 4,200 due to the immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Västerbotten Region failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the company carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system Cosmic had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) fined Overijssel with EUR 7,500 because it failed to notify the DPA of a personal data breach, violating Art. 33 GDPR. Due to a human error, an email containing information about a meeting had been set through an open distribution list. All 101 recipients were addressed as “Friends of the PVV” in this email, which openly stated their political beliefs, something that’s unlawful and against their basic privacy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (AP) has imposed a fine of EUR 525,000 on Locatefamily.com. Locatefamily.com is a platform where people can search for the contact information of family members they have lost contact with or other people they would like to get in touch with. The data subjects complained that their contact information (name, address, phone number) was published on the website without their knowledge. The data subjects were not able to request the deletion of their data published on the site easily, because Locatefamily.com did not have any representation in the European Union. Organizations offering goods or services in the EU must have a representative to whom EU citizens can turn to obtain information or exercise their data protection rights. Accordingly, the Dutch data protection authority found a breach of Art. 27 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined CP&A with EUR 15,000. As part of the recording procedures of employee absences due to illness, the data controller documented the causes of illness and complaints of the data subject. However, the DPA discovered that this was unlawful because health data has special protection from this. Employers aren’t allowed to record the causes or reasons of sick leave. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing when recording absences. More specifically, the absence registration was accessible online with no authentical procedure in place. Normally, when the absence system is available online, it should have a multi-factor authentication procedure in place. According to the DPA, a more complex form of authentication. should have been put in place, aside from the normal login procedure.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined an orthodontic clinic with EUR 12,000. As part of the online sign-up procedure for new patients (mostly underaged), there were mandatory fields with various patient personal data. This data, after being entered into the fields, was sent to the orthodontic clinic through an unencrypted connection. Clearly, this pose a massive risk of unauthorized access from unknown third parties, exposing the data subjects to danger.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as DPA) has fined TikTok, a video portal, with EUR 750,000 because it violated the privacy of young children. The privacy policies presented to Dutch users (mostly underaged children) was in English, making it difficult for them to understand the policies. Because the privacy policies were not in Dutch, TikTok failed to adequately explain how their app processes, collects, and reuses personal data. The DPA concluded that this is a violation of the company’s duty to provide accurate information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Facebook owned messaging app WhatsApp has been fined by the Data Protection Authority of Ireland with a huge sum of €225 million. This concludes an investigation spanning from 2018. The Data Protection Authority of Ireland commented that WhatsApp discharged its GDPR transparency obligations with regard to the provision of information and the transparency of that information to both users and non-users of WhatsApp’s service. This includes information provided to data subjects about the processing of information between WhatsApp and other Facebook companies.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra with EUR 3,000. The institution promoted the mediation and legal education. But the data controller did not inform the DPA about a data breach regarding some data subjects. A couple of folders with personal data were stolen from the data controller in 2020. These folders had names, addresses, telephone numbers, and even PESEL numbers of more than 96 data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Midtjylland Region with EUR 53,800. On the 12th of June, 2020, the DPA was notified by the region regarding a personal data security breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. According to the region, all staff and patients at a lifestyle center could access a building where approximately 100,000 physical patient records were stored. These records included health information and personal identity number details. This data breach took place because both staff and patients had received key cards that allowed them to access all three buildings of the lifestyle center, even though the users may not require to use them. Additionally, passersby could see the covers of some records though a window on the building. These covers showed personal data such as identity numbers and names. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Midtjylland Region had failed to take adequate security measures to store the personal data. Moreover, the region had further failed to establish enough guidelines for access restrictions when creating the security key cards, and had also failed to conduct the necessary periodic testing, assessment, and evaluation of the security measures it had taken. In assessing the question of whether a fine should be imposed, the Danish DPA took into account, as an aggravating factor, that the region processed large amounts of sensitive data, such as health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with EUR 1,400. Vodafone had previously sent marketing SMS, emails, and made telephone calls without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. Despite several complaints of the data subjects, Vodafone continued sending SMS messages, emails, and making calls to the data subjects. In one case, a former customer had contacted Vodafone a total of seven times, asking not to receive any more advertising calls on his cell phone. Despite his request, he continued to receive advertising calls. In another case, a customer had received an advertising call on his mobile phone number and told Vodafone that he did not want to receive more advertising calls. Despite this complaint, Vodafone made twelve more marketing calls to his cell phone. Another data subject filled out a form where he stated that he wanted Vodafone to refrain from making advertising calls to his cell phone. However, the employee who processed his request did not register the customer’s marketing preferences. So, the customer subsequently received fourteen more unsolicited commercial messages – seven emails and seven text messages.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Region of Lombardy with EUR 200,000. The region had previously published on its website the personal data of more than 100,000 students who had applied for state scholarships or financial grants to buy technical equipment, textbooks, and teaching materials. During the preliminary audit of Garante, one could view and download the full list of approved and funded applications, as well as the lists of state scholarship recipients, and the list containing ineligible applications on the official website of the region. These lists contained personal data that could identify each individual, including the names, IDs, grades, names and codes of the school, and the application number. The DPA concluded that the personal data of applications applying for these economic benefits should be protected at all times through special ways in order to prevent and social and economic problems.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Flowbird Italia s.r.l.  with EUR 30,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. During the investigation, Garante discovered that Flowbird Italia had not established a data processing register either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Atac s.p.a.  with EUR 400,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: President of the Zgierz District Court
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the president of the Zgierz District Court with EUR 2,200. The president had previously reported a data breach that involved the loss of an unencrypted USB stick by a probation officer. The stick was used to store the data of about 400 persons under probation supervision. The lost and unencrypted data carrier has been found yet, so this means that unauthorized persons could still be able to access the personal data it contained. The president had wrongfully assumed that the duty to secure the data wasn’t his but the respective probation officers’ who were using this data stick. However, the DPA found that the president himself should have secured the USB sticks.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Actamedica SRL with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously informed a data subject about the misplacement of her biological samples as well as a sum of money sent via a courier service. When the data subject inquired on the specific personal data that had been discloses during this data breach, and whether the company had informed the ANSPDCP, the data controller provided only the contact details of its lawyer as well as the email address of the courier service that the data subject could complain to. The ANSPDCP discovered a data breach regarding the controller’s obligation to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk to data subjects, as well as a breach of the controller’s obligation to notify the ANSPDCP of the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company owner with EUR 2,000. A private individual had applied for a job at the data controller’s company and sent the controller his CV through WhatsApp. From that point on, the data subject was not informed about the processing of his personal or his data subject rights. The AEPD considered this to be a violation of Art. 13 of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an agency with EUR 1,800. The data controller had improperly disposed of documents containing personal data of its clients in the garbage. The AEPD claimed this to be a total lack of security and data protection countermeasures as outlined by Art. 32 GDPR, which states that ‘the controller and processor shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure an adequate level of security.’ The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an owners’ association with EUR 1,000. The data controller had illegally installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex that recorded, among others, public areas like the swimming pool, and of the public space. Additionally, surveillance cameras had been installed in the rooms where the guards of the residential complex changed their clothing, without any notice being given. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined FurnishYourSpace S.L. with EUR 6,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from the Berlin DPA through the EU Internal Market Information System regarding the inadequate design of the data controller’s privacy notice. More specifically, both the contact data and the identity of the data controller were included in the privacy notice, but they were provided under false pretenses. Additionally, the data controller did not clarify the goals of the data processing. Moreover, he provided no legal basis for the processing and retention of the personal data, and no information was offered regarding the data subjects’ rightto object. Also, the privacy notice was complicated, with the wording containing grammatical errors and making use of uncommon and needlessly complex terminology. Finally, the privacy notice also required a tax identification number in order to issue a simplified invoice, i.e., an invoice that did not exceed the amount of EUR 3,000. The AEPD stated that this was a violation of the principle of legality. The fine is composed as follows: EUR 3,000 for a breach of Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR; EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 (4) GDPR; and EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 21 LSSI
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Automecanica Jerez, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had previously sent several commercial e-mails to a large number of people without obtaining their consent. By doing so, the data controller did not anonymize the personal data of the recipients, such as the surname, first name and email address. This allowed the other recipients to view the data of other recipients, as well. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of Article 5 (1) f) GDPR and Article 32 GDPR, since the controller had ultimately failed to implement technical and organizational measures that would ensure a sufficient level of security in the processing of personal data. Furthermorem the AEPD found a breach of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club APOEL FC with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined AC Omonia and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club AC Omonia with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA fined the Hellenic Technical Enterprise Ltd. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had designed the ticket sales system for the two soccer clubs, APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Favrskov Municipality with EUR 10,000. Back on the 19th of August, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Favrskov Municipality regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. The notification claimed that, during a break-in at the municipality’s premises, a laptop had been stolen that contained a program which provided overviews of the municipality’s care facilities and information about the names and personal identity numbers of more than 100 individuals with mental or physical disabilities. The specific computer hard drive was unencrypted and the program, which contained sensitive and private personal data, wasn’t equipped with any security measures. While investigating the case, the DPA discovered that the Favrskov Municipality had failed to ensure the encryption of the laptops’ hard drives for a long time before August 12, 2020, which resulted in an inadequate level of security. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of protection commensurate with the risk.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA fined the Syddanmark Region with EUR 67,200 on. On March 9, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Syddanmark Region regarding a personal data breach pertaining to Art. 33 GDPR. The Syddanmark Region claims that, since May 2011, a PowerPoint presentation made at Odense University Hospital for training purposes and containing personal data (ID card number details and health information of 3,915 patients, was made public on the official website of the region. The region had been using a screening tool to analyze for inadvertent posting of any personal identity numbers on its website. But this tool couldn’t scan any data in PowerPoint presentations. As such, the DPA discovered that the region had failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the adequate level of protection appropriate to the risk at hand. When assessing the necessity of a fine, the DPA also considered that aggravating factor of the region’s processing of large amounts of personal data, which also included health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined Société nouvelle de l’annuaire français (SNAF) with EUR 3,000. SNAF operates the website annuairefrancais.fr, which lists French companies based on data published by the French Statistical Office. Between 2018 and 2019, the CNIL received a total of sixteen complaints that indicated problems when requesting the erasure and rectification of personal data. As a response, the CNIL promptly requested that SNAF complies with the requests within two months, which SNAF failed to do. Henceforth, the CNIL imposed the fine on SNAF, mainly for failing to comply with the rights of rectification and erasure of the data subjects, as well as for the lack of cooperation with the CNIL.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA from Hamburg has fined Vattenfal Europe Sales GmbH with EUR 900,000. The fine relates to data matching, which the data controller had carried out between August 2018 and December 2019 in the course of contract inquiries for special contracts. These special contracts were issued in order to attract potential new customers, and also came with bonus payments for these customers. The data controller made a comparison between contracts concluded by existing customers and potential customers who had previously submitted inquiries for special contracts. The data controller would reject the application for special contract if it was revealed that the application had previously signed a contract with the data controller then switched to another supplier. This was done to avoid any “bonus shopping”, which companies find unprofitable. However, the data controller failed to inform the customers about the data processing involving these comparisons. The DPA then concluded that the data controller had violated the company’s transparency policies and information obligations, since over 500,000 people had been affected in this data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Dixons South East Europe ΑΕΒΕ-ΚΩΤΣΟΒΟΛΟΣ with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller after it failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the National Bank of Greence with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the bank and a company after the data controllers failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: NOW DOCTOR – Εταιρία Παροχής Ηλεκτρονικών Υπηρεσιών Αναζήτησης και Προβολής Ιατρών Ε.Π.Ε.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the operator of the nowdoctor.gr medical platform that enables the online booking of medical appointments. A doctor had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. At the same time, she had also repeatedly stated that she didn’t wish to work with the data controller, while requesting the deletion of her data on the platform. The data controller failed to comply with the request of the data subject on the spot. Instead, the data deletion took place 18 months later, after the DPA had requested to data controller to proceed with the deletion. The DPA concluded that this was a clear breach of the data controller’s accountability obligations. It was further found that the data controller had been storing the data of the data subject for longer that was necessary for the intended processing purposes (providing online display services). These display services would stop existing at the moment the data subject used her right to stop working with the data controller. Additionally, the DPA found out that the data controller failed to facilitate the data subject’s access to her rights as per Art. 12 GDPR. Finally, while the data controller provided a public email address on its website through which the data subject could maintain communication, the controller was understaffed and there was no one to process this communication.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Greek DPA fined the Rhodes Municipal Transport Company with a fine of EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the transport company filed a complaint against it with the DPA. At that time, the employee was engaged in a legal dispute with the transport company after the employer had reported him for alleged embezzlement. In this context, the employee had requested from the employer a copy of the video recordings taken by the bus’s video surveillance system during the data that the alleged embezzlement occurred. This video recording was necessary for this defense. However, the data controller failed to respond to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a clear violation of the data subject’s right to information, as per Art. 12 (3) GDPR and Art. 15 GDPR. Moreover, the data controller provided the former employee with a certificate of his former employment. Among others, the certificate contained the duration and type of the employment, as well as a notice of dismissal on charges of criminal offenses. This was a violation of the principle of proportionality as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, according to the GDPR. The issued fine consists of EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for violating Art. 12 (3) and Art. 15 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Ferde AS, which is a Norwegian toll company, with EUR 496,000. After receiving a report from NRK, state-owned broadcasting company, the Norwegian DPA started investigating Ferde AS, discovering that the company had been transferring information on passages in various toll rings to a data processor in China. In this context, the DPA started a large-scale investigation into the company, with the purpose of finding out whether the company had implemented measures and routines that could ensure the information security of this information transfer to China. It should be noted that Ferde AS was also responsible for registering passages at toll booths through a chip in the car. If a car had no chip or if the chip wasn’t properly registered, a photo of the car’s license plate would be taken. These images would then be sent to an automatic optical character recognition system that would digitally read the license plate. If the image wasn’t clear enough, it would go through manual processing. Ferde AS had contracted Unitel Bratseth Services (UBS) to do this job. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the subcontractor also had employees in China. Moreover, Ferde AS had violated many obligations under the GDPR for 1-2 years. In on instance, Ferde failed to conduct a risk management assessment before the processing of personal data and the processing of manual images. This risk assessment was necessary to assess any underlying risks associated with the data transfer, and to also determine whether further security measures should be taken. Additionally, the DPA discovered that Ferde did not enter an official processor contract with UBS. Therefore, the transfer of personal data to China occurred without a legal basis. When determining the value of the fine, the DPA also considered the large amount of the affected personal data as an aggravating factor. However, the implicated data subjects received no material or immaterial damage, which had a mitigating effect on this whole affair.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GESTIONES AUTO LOW COST S.L. with EUR 1,000 because the company’s website did not contain a privacy policy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hairdressing salon with EUR 1,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Frigorifica Botana S.L. with EUR 4,000. The company’s main activity is freezing, processing, and storing seafood. A data subject issued a complaint with the AEPD against the data controller, which prompted the DPA to begin investigations. Apparently, the data controller had installed an audio and video surveillance system that captured certain parts of the conference room. The DPA stated that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by processing this data without having a legal basis. It also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined CEDICO, CENTRO DE DIAGNOSTICO POR LA IMAGEN, S.L. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller. He had previously gone to get an MRI scan of his knee because of a work-related accident. He had also contacted his insurance company for a sick leave. After the insurance company contacted the data controller, the latter transmitted the medical records of the data subject to the insurance company. But by doing so, the data controller offered the insurer a report of another MRI scan of the knew that the data subject had received for an event outside of work. While assessing the need for a sick leave, the insurer considered the MRI report in the medical records outside working hours, attributing the data subject’s incapacity to work to this event. So, they granted no sic leave to the data subject. The DPA considered that the data controller unlawfully disclosed the MRI report to the insurer, violating the principle of integrity and confidentiality. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was briefly reduced to EUR 18,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.
